Plant_Description:
**Acer campestre**, commonly known as field maple or hedge maple, is a **small to medium deciduous tree** in the **Sapindaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is planted as an ornamental and street tree in North America, occasionally naturalizing in disturbed areas.

**Growth habit**  
A small tree or large shrub, typically 10–15 meters tall, with a **rounded, dense crown**. Bark is grayish-brown, becoming corky and fissured with age. Twigs sometimes develop corky wings.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **simple**, **palmately 3–5 lobed**, 5–10 cm across, with **rounded lobes** and few or no teeth. Lobes are blunt-tipped, separated by shallow sinuses. Leaves are dark green above, paler and softly hairy beneath. Fall color is yellow, sometimes tinged purple.

**Flowers**  
Flowers appear **with the leaves** in spring, small, **yellow-green**, in erect **corymbs**. Plants are polygamous (male, female, and perfect flowers on same tree). Blooms April–May.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a paired **samara** with wings spreading **horizontally** (180°)—nearly in a straight line. Samaras are 2–3 cm long, often tinged red.

**Seeds**  
Each samara contains one seed; wind-dispersed in fall.

**Morphology**  
**A. campestre** is identified by its **small stature**, **blunt-lobed leaves**, **corky bark**, and **horizontally spreading samara wings**. Distinguished from **A. platanoides** (Norway maple) by smaller size and blunt (not pointed) leaf lobes. The milky sap of Norway maple is absent in field maple. Useful for hedgerows and small spaces.

**Achillea distans**, commonly known as alpine yarrow, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to the mountains of Europe, this species occasionally appears in North American gardens and may escape locally.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, arising from creeping rhizomes. Stems are simple below the inflorescence, sparsely hairy to nearly smooth.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately dissected** into narrow segments, 5–15 cm long, fern-like in appearance. Lower leaves are petioled; upper leaves are sessile and smaller. Leaves are aromatic when crushed, less so than common yarrow.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in **flat-topped corymbs** at stem tips. Each head is small, 6–10 mm across, with **white ray florets** (typically 5) surrounding **cream to yellowish disk florets**. Rays are broader than in common yarrow. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are small, flattened, lacking pappus.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed or fall near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**A. distans** is identified by its **finely dissected leaves**, **flat-topped white flower clusters**, and **rhizomatous habit**. Distinguished from **A. millefolium** (common yarrow) by broader ray florets and larger flower heads. Less common in North America than common yarrow. Part of a taxonomically complex group.

**Actaea pachypoda**, commonly known as white baneberry or doll's eyes, is a **clump-forming perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often on calcareous soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 40–80 cm tall, arising from a thick, knotted rhizome. Stems are smooth, branched above, often reddish-tinged.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times ternately compound**, creating a large, spreading, lacy form. Leaflets are **ovate to oblong**, 5–10 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are thin-textured, bright green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **dense, oblong terminal raceme**, 3–6 cm long. Individual flowers are small, white, with 4–10 narrow petals that fall early, leaving a **fuzzy cluster of white stamens**. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is the distinctive feature: **white berries** with a **prominent black spot** at the tip, resembling doll's eyes, borne on **thick, bright red pedicels**. The red stalks and white-black berries are unmistakable. Berries are **HIGHLY TOXIC**.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains several seeds; dispersed by birds despite toxicity.

**Morphology**  
**A. pachypoda** is unmistakable in fruit: **white berries with black "pupils" on thick red stalks**. Distinguished from **A. rubra** (red baneberry) which has red berries on thin green stalks. CAUTION: All parts are toxic; even a few berries can be fatal to children. One of the most distinctive and dangerous woodland plants.

**Aesculus glabra**, commonly known as Ohio buckeye, is a **medium-sized deciduous tree** in the **Sapindaceae** family. Native to the central United States, this species inhabits **moist bottomlands, ravines, and rich woods**, often along streams.

**Growth habit**  
A medium tree, typically 15–25 meters tall, with a **rounded to broadly spreading crown**. Bark is gray, becoming **deeply furrowed and scaly** with age—often described as "alligator bark." Twigs emit a foul odor when broken.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **palmately compound** with **5 leaflets** (occasionally 7). Leaflets are **elliptic to obovate**, 8–15 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and pointed tips, arranged like fingers of a hand. Leaves are dull green, turning yellow-orange in fall. Fall color develops early; leaves drop early.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **erect, terminal panicles**, 10–15 cm long. Individual flowers are **greenish-yellow**, 4-petaled, tubular, not showy. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **spiny capsule**, 3–5 cm across, with **short, scattered spines** (not as densely spiny as horse chestnut). Capsule splits to reveal **1–3 shiny, brown seeds** with a pale scar (the "buck's eye").

**Seeds**  
Seeds are large, shiny, chestnut-brown with a pale hilum. **TOXIC** to humans and livestock but eaten by squirrels.

**Morphology**  
**A. glabra** is identified by its **5-palmately compound opposite leaves**, **spiny fruit capsules**, and **malodorous twigs**. Distinguished from **A. hippocastanum** (horse chestnut) by greenish-yellow (not white) flowers and less densely spiny fruit. State tree of Ohio. All parts toxic; seeds historically carried as good luck charms.

**Agrimonia eupatoria**, commonly known as common agrimony or church steeples, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America along **roadsides, field edges, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–100 cm tall, with stems covered in soft hairs arising from a short rhizome. Plants have a characteristic scent when crushed.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **5–9 major leaflets** interspersed with smaller leaflets between pairs. Major leaflets are **elliptic to obovate**, 3–6 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and hairy undersides. The interstitial small leaflets are diagnostic for the genus.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **long, slender, spike-like raceme** 10–30 cm long. Individual flowers are small, 5–10 mm across, with **5 yellow petals**. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small burr** formed by the persistent calyx tube (hypanthium), which is grooved and covered with **hooked bristles** that catch on fur and clothing.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are enclosed in the bristly hypanthium; dispersed by clinging to animals.

**Morphology**  
**A. eupatoria** is identified by its **pinnate leaves with small leaflets between large ones**, **spike-like racemes of yellow flowers**, and **hooked bur-like fruits**. Distinguished from **A. gryposepala** (native agrimony) by minor technical features. The hooked fruits are effective hitchhikers. Used historically in herbal medicine.

**Agrostis capillaris**, commonly known as colonial bentgrass or browntop, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, meadows, roadsides, and disturbed areas**, and is cultivated for turf.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted to loosely mat-forming grass, 20–60 cm tall, with fine-textured foliage. Spreads by short rhizomes and stolons, forming a dense turf. Culms are erect, slender.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 2–10 cm long, 2–4 mm wide, flat to slightly inrolled, bright green. Ligule is short, membranous, truncate (squared-off)—a key identifier.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is an **open, diffuse panicle**, 5–20 cm long, with delicate, spreading branches bearing tiny spikelets at the tips. Spikelets are one-flowered, 2–3 mm long, purplish to green. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** (grain) enclosed in the lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are tiny, dispersed by wind and water.

**Morphology**  
**A. capillaris** is identified by its **fine texture**, **open delicate panicle**, and **short truncate ligule**. Distinguished from **A. stolonifera** (creeping bentgrass) which has a longer, pointed ligule and spreads more by stolons. Common component of cool-season lawns and meadows. Tolerates close mowing.

**Allium cepa**, commonly known as onion, is a **bulb-forming biennial herb** (cultivated as annual) in the **Amaryllidaceae** family. Native to central Asia, this culinary staple is widely cultivated worldwide and occasionally persists from cultivation or as a garden escape.

**Growth habit**  
A bulb-forming herb with erect, hollow leaves, typically 30–100 cm tall when flowering. The bulb consists of concentric, fleshy leaf bases wrapped around a central growing point.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **cylindrical and hollow**, 15–50 cm long, blue-green with a waxy bloom. Leaves arise directly from the bulb apex, forming a cluster. The hollow cross-section distinguishes onion from solid-leaved relatives.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **dense, spherical umbel** atop a tall, hollow scape, 50–150 cm tall. Umbel is 5–10 cm across, containing dozens to hundreds of small **white to greenish-white** (or pinkish) flowers. Each flower has 6 tepals. Blooms summer if allowed to bolt.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **3-lobed capsule** containing black seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are black, angular, wrinkled.

**Morphology**  
**A. cepa** is identified by its **hollow, cylindrical leaves**, **large bulb**, and **spherical umbel of white flowers**. Distinguished from **A. fistulosum** (Welsh onion) which does not form a true bulb. The pungent sulfur compounds responsible for onion flavor and tear-inducing properties are characteristic of the genus. One of the oldest cultivated vegetables.

**Alnus alnobetula**, commonly known as green alder or mountain alder, is a **large deciduous shrub** in the **Betulaceae** family. Native to northern and montane regions of the Northern Hemisphere, this species inhabits **subalpine areas, stream banks, avalanche chutes, and disturbed sites**.

**Growth habit**  
A multi-stemmed shrub, 1–4 meters tall, often forming dense thickets. Bark is smooth, grayish to reddish-brown. Young twigs are often sticky-resinous.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly ovate to nearly round**, 4–10 cm long, with **doubly serrate margins** and **pointed tips**. Leaves are dark green and glossy above, paler beneath with resinous glands when young. Veins are prominent.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers in **pendant catkins**, 3–8 cm long, yellowish, appearing before or with leaves. Female flowers in **short, erect catkins**, 5–10 mm, developing into woody cones.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small woody "cone"** (strobile), 1–1.5 cm long, resembling a tiny pinecone. Cones persist on the plant, releasing tiny winged nutlets.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are small with papery wings, wind- and water-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**A. alnobetula** is identified by its **shrubby habit**, **doubly serrate round-ovate leaves**, and **small persistent woody cones**. Like all alders, forms nitrogen-fixing root nodules with Frankia bacteria, enriching poor soils. Distinguished from **A. incana** (speckled alder) by smaller stature and sticky young twigs. Important for slope stabilization.

**Amelanchier canadensis**, commonly known as Canadian serviceberry or shadbush, is a **large shrub or small tree** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet thickets, swamp edges, and low woods**, often in acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
A multi-stemmed shrub or small tree, 3–8 meters tall, often forming colonies via root suckers. Bark is smooth, gray, with shallow fissures on older stems. Growth is upright and somewhat narrow.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to oblong**, 3–7 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**. Young leaves are **densely white-woolly** beneath when flowers open (key identifier), becoming nearly smooth later. Fall color is yellow to orange-red.

**Flowers**  
Flowers appear **before or with emerging leaves**, in **drooping to spreading racemes** of 5–12 flowers. Individual flowers have **5 white petals**, 10–15 mm long, narrow and strap-like. Blooms early spring (April–May), coinciding with shad fish runs—hence "shadbush."

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **berry-like pome**, 6–10 mm across, dark purple-black when ripe, sweet and edible. Ripens June–July.

**Seeds**  
Pomes contain several small seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**A. canadensis** is identified by its **white-woolly young leaves**, **wet habitat preference**, and **early white flowers**. Distinguished from **A. arborea** (downy serviceberry) which is more often tree-form with leaves nearly full-sized at flowering. Taxonomy of serviceberries is notoriously complex—hybridization is common. Fruits are delicious fresh or in pies.

**Ampelopsis cordata**, commonly known as heartleaf peppervine, is a **deciduous woody vine** in the **Vitaceae** family. Native to the southeastern and central United States, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, thickets, and fence rows**.

**Growth habit**  
A high-climbing vine reaching 10+ meters, climbing by **forked tendrils** opposite the leaves. Bark is tight, not shreddy like true grapes. Pith is white, continuous (not chambered).

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly heart-shaped (cordate)**, 5–12 cm long and nearly as wide, with **coarsely serrate margins** and a pointed tip. Leaves are NOT lobed (unlike most grapes). Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are small, **greenish**, borne in **branched cymes** opposite the leaves. Petals fall early. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **berry**, 6–10 mm across, ripening through a striking color sequence: **green → white → turquoise → blue → purple**. Multiple colors often present in one cluster. NOT palatable.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains 2–4 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**A. cordata** is identified by its **simple, unlobed heart-shaped leaves** and **multicolored berries**. Distinguished from grapes (Vitis) by unlobed leaves, white continuous pith (grapes have brown chambered pith), and inedible fruit. The colorful berry display is ornamentally attractive. Can become weedy in disturbed areas.

**Andropogon gerardi**, commonly known as big bluestem or turkeyfoot, is a **tall, warm-season perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this species is the dominant grass of the **tallgrass prairie**, also found in old fields, roadsides, and open woods.

**Growth habit**  
A robust bunchgrass, 1–3 meters tall, forming large clumps from short, scaly rhizomes. Stems (culms) are erect, often purplish to bronze at the base. Plants turn distinctive bronze-copper in fall.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 20–60 cm long, 5–10 mm wide, flat, often with a bluish bloom. Leaves are rough on margins. Lower leaves are often folded; upper leaves are spreading.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence consists of **2–6 finger-like racemes** at the culm tip, typically 3, arranged like a turkey's foot—hence "turkeyfoot." Racemes are 5–10 cm long, purplish to bronze. Spikelets are paired, one sessile (fertile), one stalked (sterile or male). Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** (grain) enclosed in the lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed by wind; the awned lemma aids dispersal.

**Morphology**  
**A. gerardi** is identified by its **tall stature**, **finger-like "turkeyfoot" inflorescence**, and **bluish foliage turning bronze in fall**. Distinguished from **Schizachyrium scoparium** (little bluestem) which is shorter with single racemes. The iconic grass of the tallgrass prairie. Deep roots (3+ meters) make big bluestem extremely drought-tolerant and valuable for restoration.

**Anemone quinquefolia**, commonly known as wood anemone or nightcaps, is a **delicate spring ephemeral perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often carpeting the forest floor in early spring.

**Growth habit**  
A low, slender herb, 10–20 cm tall, arising from a thin, horizontal rhizome. Plants form loose colonies, often growing intermixed with other spring wildflowers.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaf is usually **solitary**, **long-petioled**, appearing after flowering. Stem leaves are **3, whorled** below the flower, **palmately 3–5 divided**, with each segment **deeply cut into toothed lobes**. Leaves are delicate, bright green.

**Flowers**  
Flower is **solitary**, borne on a slender stalk above the leaf whorl. The flower has **5 (sometimes 4–9) white petal-like sepals**, 1–2 cm across, sometimes tinged pink beneath. True petals are absent. Stamens are numerous, yellow. Blooms early spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **cluster of hairy achenes** in a rounded head.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed by wind and gravity.

**Morphology**  
**A. quinquefolia** is identified by its **solitary white flower** above a **whorl of 3 deeply cut leaves**. Distinguished from **Thalictrum thalictroides** (rue anemone) which has multiple flowers per stem and more rounded leaflets. The flowers close at night and on cloudy days—hence "nightcaps." A classic harbinger of spring in eastern forests.

**Antennaria neglecta**, commonly known as field pussytoes, is a **low, mat-forming perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **dry fields, open woods, roadsides, and sandy areas**, often in poor soils.

**Growth habit**  
A low herb, 10–30 cm tall when flowering, spreading by **stolons** (runners) to form dense mats. Basal rosettes produce erect flowering stems.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves form a rosette, **spatulate to oblanceolate**, 2–5 cm long, **gray-green with dense white woolly pubescence** beneath, greener and less hairy above, with a single prominent vein. Stem leaves are small, linear, appressed.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **dioecious** (male and female on separate plants). Flower heads are borne in **tight, terminal clusters** of 3–10 heads. Heads are small, 5–8 mm across, with **papery white bracts** surrounding tubular florets. Female heads are larger; male heads are smaller and rounder. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are tiny, topped with a pappus of fine white bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**A. neglecta** is identified by its **stoloniferous mat-forming habit**, **woolly gray-green basal leaves**, and **tight clusters of small white fuzzy heads**. The "pussytoes" name refers to the soft flower clusters resembling cat paws. Distinguished from **A. plantaginifolia** (plantain-leaved pussytoes) which has broader, 3–5 nerved basal leaves. Common in dry, disturbed habitats.

**Anthoxanthum odoratum**, commonly known as sweet vernal grass, is a **tufted perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **meadows, lawns, roadsides, and open woods**, valued for its sweet fragrance.

**Growth habit**  
A loosely tufted grass, 30–60 cm tall, forming small clumps. Plants have a distinctive **sweet vanilla-like fragrance**, especially when dried, due to coumarin content.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 5–20 cm long, 3–8 mm wide, flat, bright green, sparsely hairy. Ligule is membranous, prominent. The fragrance is detectable when leaves are crushed.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **dense, spike-like panicle**, 3–7 cm long, yellowish-green to golden. Spikelets are 3-flowered but only the terminal floret is fertile; lower two florets are reduced to awned lemmas. Blooms early spring—one of the earliest grasses to flower.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the shiny lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed as the spikelet disarticulates.

**Morphology**  
**A. odoratum** is identified by its **sweet coumarin fragrance**, **early flowering**, and **spike-like golden panicle**. The scent of new-mown hay is largely due to this grass. Causes "sweet clover disease" in livestock if moldy (coumarin converts to anticoagulant). Common in cool, moist grasslands. One of the few fragrant grasses.

**Apocynum androsaemifolium**, commonly known as spreading dogbane, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Apocynaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **dry open woods, roadsides, fields, and forest edges**, often in sandy or gravelly soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect to spreading herb, 30–100 cm tall, with branching reddish stems arising from creeping rhizomes. All parts exude **milky latex** when broken. Plants often form colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **simple**, **ovate to elliptic**, 5–10 cm long, with **entire margins** and **drooping habit**. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath. Petioles are short.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal and axillary cymes**. Individual flowers are **bell-shaped**, 6–9 mm long, **pink with darker pink stripes inside**, nodding, fragrant. Corolla lobes recurve at tips. Blooms early to mid summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **paired, slender follicles**, 8–15 cm long, pendant, splitting to release seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds bear a tuft of silky hairs (coma), wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**A. androsaemifolium** is identified by its **pink-striped bell flowers**, **opposite drooping leaves**, **milky sap**, and **paired follicles**. Distinguished from **A. cannabinum** (Indian hemp) which has smaller, greenish-white flowers. Related to milkweeds; host plant for monarch butterflies. ALL PARTS ARE TOXIC—the "dogbane" name reflects historical use as dog poison. Handle with care.

**Aquilegia canadensis**, commonly known as wild columbine or red columbine, is a **graceful perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rocky woods, ledges, cliffs, and woodland edges**, often in dry, well-drained sites.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, with slender, branching stems arising from a woody rootstock. Plants are delicate and airy in appearance.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **long-petioled**, **2–3 times ternately compound**, creating a lacy appearance. Leaflets are **rounded, 3-lobed**, 1–3 cm across, pale bluish-green, resembling meadow-rue foliage. Stem leaves are smaller and less divided.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **nodding**, borne singly or in open clusters at branch tips. Each flower has **5 red sepals**, **5 yellow petals** with long, backward-projecting **red spurs** containing nectar, and numerous yellow stamens extending below the petals. Flowers are 3–5 cm long. Blooms spring to early summer (April–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **5 erect follicles**, 1.5–2.5 cm long, splitting along one side.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are black, shiny; dispersed by gravity.

**Morphology**  
**A. canadensis** is identified by its **red and yellow nodding flowers with long spurs**, **ternately compound leaves**, and **rocky habitat**. The spurs are adapted for hummingbird pollination—one of the few native flowers with this relationship. Distinguished from European columbine cultivars which have various colors. Easy to grow from seed; self-sows readily.

**Aralia elata**, commonly known as Japanese angelica tree, is a **large, spiny, deciduous shrub or small tree** in the **Araliaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is planted as an ornamental and has become **invasive** in parts of eastern North America, spreading into disturbed forests and edges.

**Growth habit**  
A shrub or small tree, 5–10 meters tall, usually with a single trunk or few stems. Bark is gray-brown, covered with **sharp spines**. Spreads aggressively by **root suckers** to form dense colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **very large** (60–120 cm long), **2–3 times pinnately compound**, clustered at the branch tips, giving a tropical appearance. Leaflets are **ovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **serrate margins**. Leaf stalks and rachis are often prickly.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **large, terminal panicles** of many small umbels, 30–60 cm long. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, 5-petaled. Blooms late summer (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small black drupe**, 3–4 mm across, in large clusters. Fruits are eaten by birds, spreading the plant.

**Seeds**  
Each drupe contains 2–5 seeds.

**Morphology**  
**A. elata** is identified by its **massive pinnately compound leaves**, **spiny stems**, and **large white flower panicles**. Distinguished from native **A. spinosa** (devil's walking stick) which is very similar; positive ID requires close examination of leaf and flower details. INVASIVE in many areas—remove seedlings and root suckers. Do not plant.

**Arisaema dracontium**, commonly known as green dragon, is a **tuberous perennial herb** in the **Araceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist bottomlands, floodplains, and wet woods**, often in alluvial soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–90 cm tall, arising from a corm. Typically produces a **single leaf** that overtops the inflorescence—opposite of its relative jack-in-the-pulpit.

**Leaves**  
Leaf is **solitary**, **pedately compound** with **7–15 leaflets** arranged in a fan or horseshoe shape. Leaflets are **elliptic to lanceolate**, 10–25 cm long, with **entire to wavy margins**. The single large leaf on a long petiole is distinctive.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **spadix** (club-shaped spike) partially enclosed by a **green spathe** (modified bract). The spadix extends well beyond the spathe as a **long, tapering "dragon's tongue"** 10–20 cm long—hence "green dragon." Spathe is green, narrow, pointed. Blooms spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **cluster of red-orange berries** on the thickened spadix, showy in late summer.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains 1–3 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**A. dracontium** is identified by its **single pedately compound leaf** and **spadix with an extremely long whip-like extension**. Distinguished from **A. triphyllum** (jack-in-the-pulpit) which has 1–2 trifoliate leaves and a hooded spathe. The long "tongue" projecting from the spathe is unmistakable. All parts contain calcium oxalate crystals—causes intense burning if chewed.

**Aronia arbutifolia**, commonly known as red chokeberry, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet thickets, bogs, swamp edges, and moist open woods**, often in acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
An upright, multi-stemmed shrub, 1–3 meters tall, often forming colonies via root suckers. Branches are slender, smooth, gray.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to obovate**, 4–8 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**. Upper surface is dark green with **red glands along the midrib**; lower surface is **densely gray-tomentose (felted)**—a key identifier. Fall color is brilliant **red to purple**.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal corymbs** of 10–25 flowers. Individual flowers are **white to pinkish**, 1–1.5 cm across, with **5 petals** and numerous stamens with pink anthers. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **bright red pome**, 6–10 mm across, in drooping clusters, persisting into winter. Fruits are edible but extremely **astringent** ("chokeberry")—better after frost or cooking.

**Seeds**  
Pomes contain several small seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**A. arbutifolia** is identified by its **red fruits**, **gray-felted leaf undersides**, and **red midrib glands**. Distinguished from **A. melanocarpa** (black chokeberry) which has black fruits and nearly smooth leaf undersides. The persistent red fruits and red fall color provide excellent ornamental value. Increasingly popular for landscaping and fruit production.

**Asclepias amplexicaulis**, commonly known as clasping milkweed or blunt-leaved milkweed, is a **perennial herb** in the **Apocynaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry prairies, open woods, roadsides, and sandy fields**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, unbranched herb, 40–100 cm tall, arising from a deep taproot. Stems are stout, smooth, waxy-pale, exuding **milky latex** when broken. Unlike most milkweeds, stems are typically solitary, not clustered.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **simple**, **broadly oblong to ovate**, 7–13 cm long, with **wavy, entire margins** and **rounded to cordate bases that clasp the stem** ("amplexicaulis" = stem-clasping). Leaves are pale blue-green with a waxy bloom, smooth.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **1–4 terminal and upper axillary umbels**. Individual flowers have the characteristic milkweed structure: **reflexed corolla lobes** (pale pink to greenish) and a **corona** of 5 hoods (pink to lavender). Umbels are loose, with long pedicels. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **spindle-shaped follicle**, 10–15 cm long, smooth, erect.

**Seeds**  
Seeds bear a tuft of silky white hairs (coma), wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**A. amplexicaulis** is identified by its **waxy, clasping leaves**, **solitary unbranched stem**, and **loose umbels of pinkish flowers**. Distinguished from **A. syriaca** (common milkweed) by the clasping leaves and single-stemmed habit. Important monarch butterfly host plant. All milkweeds are toxic due to cardiac glycosides.

**Aster novae-angliae** (syn. **Symphyotrichum novae-angliae**), commonly known as New England aster, is a **tall, showy perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to eastern and central North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, prairies, stream banks, and roadsides**, one of the showiest fall wildflowers.

**Growth habit**  
A tall, clump-forming herb, 60–180 cm tall, with stout, hairy stems arising from a short, thick rhizome. Stems are unbranched below the inflorescence, densely glandular-hairy above.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate**, 5–12 cm long, with **entire margins** and **sessile, auricle-clasping bases** that wrap around the stem. Leaves are hairy and glandular-sticky.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in **showy terminal corymbs**. Each head is 3–5 cm across, with **40–100 ray florets** that are **deep violet-purple** (occasionally pink or white) surrounding a **yellow disk** that turns reddish with age. Involucral bracts are glandular-sticky. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are hairy with a **tawny pappus** of bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**A. novae-angliae** is identified by its **tall stature**, **clasping glandular leaves**, and **large purple flower heads** with numerous rays. Distinguished from **A. novi-belgii** (New York aster) by sticky bracts and hairier leaves. Among the showiest native asters; many cultivars exist. Note: Now placed in genus Symphyotrichum by most authorities.

**Barbarea verna**, commonly known as early yellowrocket or land cress, is a **biennial or perennial herb** in the **Brassicaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America in **moist fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**, often cultivated as a salad green.

**Growth habit**  
A biennial or short-lived perennial, 30–80 cm tall when flowering, with erect, grooved, smooth stems arising from a basal rosette.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **lyrate-pinnatifid** (deeply lobed with a large terminal lobe and smaller lateral lobes), 5–20 cm long, with **8–16 lateral lobes**—more lobes than common yellowrocket. Stem leaves are **alternate**, smaller, toothed to lobed, clasping with auriculate bases.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal racemes** that elongate in fruit. Individual flowers are **4-petaled**, bright **yellow**, 7–10 mm across. Petals are arranged in a cross (cruciform). Blooms early spring—earlier than most mustards.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **silique** (elongate pod), 4–7 cm long, erect to ascending, beakless.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are small, in a single row within each silique half.

**Morphology**  
**B. verna** is identified by its **numerous lateral leaf lobes** (8–16), **early flowering**, and **basal rosette of edible leaves**. Distinguished from **B. vulgaris** (common yellowrocket) which has fewer lateral lobes (1–4). Leaves are edible, peppery, used as winter salad green—hence "land cress." A useful cool-season potherb.

**Berberis julianae**, commonly known as wintergreen barberry or Julian's barberry, is an **evergreen shrub** in the **Berberidaceae** family. Native to China, this species is planted as an ornamental hedge and has escaped cultivation in parts of eastern North America.

**Growth habit**  
A dense, rounded evergreen shrub, 2–3 meters tall, with rigid, arching branches. Stems bear **3-pronged spines** at the nodes. Bark is gray-brown.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, clustered at nodes, **narrowly elliptic to lanceolate**, 5–10 cm long, **leathery and evergreen**, with **spiny-toothed margins**. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense, axillary clusters** of 15–25 flowers. Individual flowers are small, **yellow**, with 6 petals and 6 sepals. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **oblong berry**, 7–10 mm long, **blue-black** with a waxy bloom, in clusters.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains 1–3 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**B. julianae** is identified by its **evergreen, spiny-margined leaves**, **3-pronged stem spines**, and **blue-black berries**. Distinguished from **B. thunbergii** (Japanese barberry) which is deciduous with smaller, entire leaves. Less invasive than Japanese barberry but still a concern in some areas. Creates impenetrable hedges.

**Betula alleghaniensis**, commonly known as yellow birch, is a **large deciduous tree** in the **Betulaceae** family. Native to northeastern North America, this species inhabits **cool, moist forests, especially in mountainous areas and northern hardwoods**, often on rocky slopes.

**Growth habit**  
A large tree, typically 20–25 meters tall (occasionally taller), with an irregular crown. Bark is distinctive: **yellowish-bronze, peeling in thin, papery, horizontal curls**. Twigs have a **wintergreen fragrance** when scratched—diagnostic.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **ovate to elliptic**, 7–12 cm long, with **doubly serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are dull green above, paler beneath with tufts of hair in vein axils. Fall color is yellow.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male catkins are **pendant**, 7–10 cm long, yellowish, appearing before leaves. Female catkins are **erect**, small, greenish. Blooms early spring.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **upright, ovoid cone-like catkin**, 2–4 cm long, containing small, 2-winged nutlets. Catkins break apart to release seeds.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are tiny with papery wings; wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**B. alleghaniensis** is identified by its **yellowish, curly-peeling bark**, **wintergreen-scented twigs**, and **doubly serrate leaves**. Distinguished from **B. lenta** (black/sweet birch) which has darker, non-peeling bark but similar wintergreen scent. Important timber tree; wood is used for furniture and flooring. Declining in some areas due to climate change.

**Bidens aristosa**, commonly known as bearded beggarticks or tickseed sunflower, is an **annual or biennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to central and eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, prairies, stream banks, and disturbed wetlands**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching herb, 30–120 cm tall, with smooth to sparsely hairy stems. Plants are often bushy with numerous flower heads.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **pinnately dissected** into **5–7 lanceolate, serrate segments**, creating a lacy appearance. Upper leaves may be less divided. Leaves are bright green, smooth to sparsely hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **solitary** or in open clusters at branch tips, **showy**, 3–5 cm across. **Ray florets are 6–8, bright golden yellow**, 1–2 cm long. Disk florets are yellow. Involucral bracts are in 2 distinct series. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are flat, wedge-shaped, with **2–4 barbed awns** at the tip that catch on fur and clothing—"beggarticks."

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed by clinging to animals and people.

**Morphology**  
**B. aristosa** is identified by its **showy yellow rays** (unusual in Bidens, which often lacks rays), **dissected leaves**, and **barbed achenes**. Distinguished from **B. cernua** (nodding beggarticks) which has simple leaves. The bright yellow flowers are more ornamental than most beggarticks. Common in wet meadows.

**Boehmeria cylindrica**, commonly known as false nettle or smallspike false nettle, is a **perennial herb** in the **Urticaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, floodplains, and swamp edges**, often in shade.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 50–120 cm tall, with unbranched or sparingly branched stems. Unlike true nettles, false nettle **lacks stinging hairs** and is safe to handle.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to lanceolate**, 5–15 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins**, **3 prominent veins** from the base, and long petioles. Leaves are thin-textured, dark green, resembling nettle but without stinging hairs.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious** or **dioecious**. Flowers are tiny, **greenish**, borne in **elongate, cylindrical, axillary spikes** 1–5 cm long, interrupted or continuous. The cylindrical spikes are diagnostic. Blooms summer (July–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a tiny **achene** enclosed in the persistent perianth.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are minute; dispersed by gravity and water.

**Morphology**  
**B. cylindrica** is identified by its **opposite, nettle-like leaves WITHOUT stinging hairs** and **elongate cylindrical flower spikes**. Distinguished from **Urtica** (true nettles) by lack of stinging hairs. Distinguished from **Pilea** (clearweed) by opposite (not alternate) leaf arrangement and cylindrical (not panicled) spikes. Larval host for red admiral butterfly.

**Bromus arvensis**, commonly known as field brome or Japanese brome, is an **annual grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America in **fields, roadsides, waste places, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted annual grass, 30–80 cm tall, with erect to spreading culms. Plants may be solitary or in small clusters. Often turns purplish at maturity.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 5–20 cm long, 3–8 mm wide, flat, softly hairy on both surfaces. Sheaths are also hairy. Ligule is membranous, short.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is an **open, nodding panicle**, 10–20 cm long, with spreading to drooping branches. Spikelets are **oblong**, 15–25 mm long, usually purplish-tinged, containing 5–10 florets. Lemmas are awned, awns 5–10 mm long. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** (grain) enclosed in the lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed with the floret.

**Morphology**  
**B. arvensis** is identified by its **open, drooping panicle**, **softly hairy leaves and sheaths**, and **awned, often purplish spikelets**. Distinguished from **B. tectorum** (cheatgrass) which has a more one-sided panicle. Part of a complex of weedy annual bromes. Can reduce forage quality in pastures.

**Calamagrostis epigejos**, commonly known as wood small-reed or bushgrass, is a **tall, rhizomatous perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Eurasia, this species is naturalized in North America in **disturbed areas, roadsides, and waste places**, sometimes forming dense stands.

**Growth habit**  
A robust, clump-forming grass, 100–200 cm tall, spreading aggressively by stout **rhizomes** to form large colonies. Culms are erect, stiff.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 20–60 cm long, 5–15 mm wide, flat or inrolled when dry, rough on margins. Leaves are grayish-green. Ligule is membranous, prominent, often torn.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **large, dense, plume-like panicle**, 15–30 cm long, erect to somewhat nodding, purplish to straw-colored, feathery. Spikelets are one-flowered, 5–7 mm long, with silky hairs at the base. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed with silky hairs by wind.

**Morphology**  
**C. epigejos** is identified by its **tall stature**, **large feathery panicle**, and **aggressive rhizomatous spread**. Distinguished from native Calamagrostis species by larger size and denser panicle. Can become invasive in disturbed areas, outcompeting native vegetation. Difficult to eradicate once established.

**Caltha palustris**, commonly known as marsh marigold or cowslip, is a **succulent perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to North America and Eurasia, this species inhabits **marshes, wet meadows, stream banks, and swamp edges**, one of the showiest early spring wetland wildflowers.

**Growth habit**  
A low, clumping herb, 30–60 cm tall, with hollow, fleshy, branching stems arising from a stout rootstock. Plants form dense clumps in favorable sites.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **long-petioled**, **kidney-shaped to heart-shaped (reniform to cordate)**, 5–15 cm wide, **glossy dark green**, with **crenate to dentate margins**. Stem leaves are smaller, short-petioled to sessile. Leaves are thick, succulent.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **few-flowered cymes** at branch tips. Individual flowers are **showy**, 2–4 cm across, with **5–9 bright yellow, petal-like sepals** (true petals are absent). Stamens are numerous, golden. Blooms early spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **cluster of follicles**, each follicle 10–15 mm long, spreading at maturity.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**C. palustris** is identified by its **glossy kidney-shaped leaves**, **bright yellow flowers**, and **wet habitat**. The buttercup-like flowers appearing in early spring are unmistakable in wetland settings. CAUTION: Contains protoanemonin—toxic raw, but reportedly edible after cooking (not recommended). A classic harbinger of spring in northern wetlands.

**Cardamine bulbosa**, commonly known as bulbous bittercress or spring cress, is a **perennial herb** in the **Brassicaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, stream banks, springs, and floodplain forests**, often in calcareous soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 15–50 cm tall, arising from a **small, tuberous base** (corm-like). Stems are simple, smooth, often hollow.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **long-petioled**, **simple**, **rounded to kidney-shaped**, 2–5 cm wide, with **entire to wavy margins**. Stem leaves are **alternate**, **oblong to lanceolate**, sessile, with **toothed margins**, not clasping. The contrast between round basal leaves and narrow stem leaves is notable.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal racemes** that elongate in fruit. Individual flowers are **4-petaled**, **white** (occasionally pink-tinged), 10–15 mm across. Petals are broadly spatulate. Blooms spring (March–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **silique** (elongate pod), 2–3 cm long, erect, narrow.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are in a single row in each silique half.

**Morphology**  
**C. bulbosa** is identified by its **tuberous base**, **rounded basal leaves vs. narrow stem leaves**, and **white spring flowers**. Distinguished from **C. concatenata** (cutleaf toothwort) which has whorled, dissected stem leaves. The young leaves have a peppery, cress-like flavor—edible in moderation. A cheerful spring wildflower of wet areas.

**Carex blanda**, commonly known as eastern woodland sedge or common wood sedge, is a **perennial sedge** in the **Cyperaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **mesic deciduous forests, woodland edges, and shaded stream banks**, one of the most common woodland sedges.

**Growth habit**  
A loosely tufted sedge, 20–60 cm tall, forming clumps from short rhizomes. Stems (culms) are triangular in cross-section—"sedges have edges."

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal and cauline**, **linear**, 3–8 mm wide, bright green, soft-textured. Leaves are shorter than or equal to the flowering stems. Sheaths are smooth.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence consists of **3–5 spikes** in a terminal cluster, the terminal spike **staminate** (male) above, **pistillate** (female) below; lateral spikes entirely pistillate. Spikes are oblong, 8–15 mm long, on nodding peduncles. Perigynia (sac enclosing achene) are green, finely nerved, with a short beak. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **achene** enclosed in the perigynium.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed with the perigynium.

**Morphology**  
**C. blanda** is identified by its **loosely tufted habit**, **bright green soft leaves**, and **terminal spike with male flowers above, female below**. Distinguished from **C. laxiflora** and similar woodland sedges by technical perigynium characters. Extremely common but often overlooked. Valuable groundcover for shaded gardens.

**Carpinus betulus**, commonly known as European hornbeam, is a **medium-sized deciduous tree** in the **Betulaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is widely planted as an ornamental and hedge tree in North America.

**Growth habit**  
A medium tree, typically 15–25 meters tall, with a **dense, rounded to oval crown**. Bark is smooth, gray, often with a fluted or muscled appearance. The trunk is characteristically **fluted (wavy, sinewy)**.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **ovate to elliptic**, 5–12 cm long, with **doubly serrate margins** and **prominent parallel veins** (10–15 pairs), giving a pleated or corrugated appearance. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath. Fall color is yellow.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male catkins are **pendant**, 3–5 cm long, yellowish. Female catkins are **erect**, becoming pendant in fruit. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **nutlet** attached to a **3-lobed, leafy bract**, 3–4 cm long. Fruits hang in **pendant clusters**. The 3-lobed bract is distinctive.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are ribbed; dispersed by wind with the aid of the bract.

**Morphology**  
**C. betulus** is identified by its **fluted gray bark**, **corrugated leaves with parallel veins**, and **3-lobed fruiting bracts**. Distinguished from **C. caroliniana** (American hornbeam) by larger size and slightly different bract shape. Excellent for hedging—responds well to shearing. "Hornbeam" refers to the hard wood.

**Carya glabra**, commonly known as pignut hickory, is a **large deciduous tree** in the **Juglandaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry to mesic upland forests and ridges**, often on well-drained slopes.

**Growth habit**  
A large tree, typically 20–30 meters tall, with a tall, straight trunk and **narrow, oblong crown**. Bark is gray, tight, becoming shallowly furrowed with **interlacing ridges** forming a diamond pattern on older trees.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **5 (sometimes 7) leaflets**. Leaflets are **lanceolate to obovate**, 8–15 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**, the terminal leaflet largest. Leaves are dark green above, paler and smooth beneath (glabrous—hence "glabra"). Fall color is yellow.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers in **pendant catkins** in clusters of 3. Female flowers are tiny, at twig tips. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **pear-shaped to obovoid nut** enclosed in a thin husk, 2–4 cm long. Husk splits only partway to the base, often remaining attached. Nut is thick-shelled, not sweet—"pignut."

**Seeds**  
Kernel is small, bitter to slightly sweet; eaten by wildlife.

**Morphology**  
**C. glabra** is identified by its **5-leaflet compound leaves**, **tight bark with diamond pattern**, and **pear-shaped nuts with thin, tardily splitting husks**. Distinguished from **C. ovata** (shagbark hickory) by tight (not shaggy) bark and smaller, less palatable nuts. Important wildlife food tree.

**Castanea dentata**, commonly known as American chestnut, is a **large deciduous tree** in the **Fagaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this once-dominant species was nearly eliminated by chestnut blight (Cryphonectria parasitica) in the early 1900s. Today, **root sprouts persist** in forests but rarely reach reproductive maturity before succumbing to blight.

**Growth habit**  
Historically a massive tree reaching 30–35 meters with trunk diameters of 1–2 meters. Today, typically seen as **multi-stemmed sprouts** 3–10 meters tall from old root systems, eventually killed back by blight.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **oblong-lanceolate**, 15–25 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** bearing **large, bristle-tipped teeth** (incurved, not spreading). Leaves are smooth, dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers in **long, erect, pale yellow catkins**, 15–20 cm long, conspicuous and fragrant. Female flowers are at the base of some male catkins or separate, inconspicuous. Blooms early summer (June–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **spiny bur**, 5–7 cm across, containing **2–3 shiny, brown nuts**. Nuts are sweet and edible—historically a major food source for wildlife and humans.

**Seeds**  
Nuts are large, flattened on one side, with a pointed tip.

**Morphology**  
**C. dentata** is identified by its **long serrate leaves with bristle-tipped teeth** and **spiny burs** (when fruiting). Distinguished from **C. mollissima** (Chinese chestnut) by leaf pubescence and tree form. Restoration efforts using blight-resistant hybrids are ongoing. One of the great ecological tragedies of North America.

**Ceanothus americanus**, commonly known as New Jersey tea or redroot, is a **small deciduous shrub** in the **Rhamnaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry open woods, prairies, roadsides, and forest edges**, often on sandy or rocky soils.

**Growth habit**  
A low, multi-stemmed shrub, 0.5–1 meter tall, with slender, flexible branches. The root system produces **deep red roots** (hence "redroot"), and plants are **nitrogen-fixing** through root nodule bacteria.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **ovate to elliptic**, 5–10 cm long, with **serrate margins** and **3 prominent veins** from the base. Leaves are dull green above, paler and softly pubescent beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense, rounded to cylindrical clusters** 2–5 cm long, on long peduncles from upper leaf axils. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, fragrant, with 5 hooded petals. Blooms late spring to summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **3-lobed capsule**, 4–5 mm across, splitting into 3 nutlets.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are hard, dispersed when capsule dehisces explosively.

**Morphology**  
**C. americanus** is identified by its **low shrubby habit**, **3-veined leaves**, and **dense white flower clusters**. Leaves were used as a tea substitute during the American Revolution—hence "New Jersey tea." The red roots contain a dye. Important for pollinators, especially native bees. Nitrogen-fixing ability makes Ceanothus valuable for restoration.

**Celastrus orbiculatus**, commonly known as oriental bittersweet, is an **aggressive, invasive woody vine** in the **Celastraceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is **highly invasive** in eastern North America, smothering and killing native trees.

**Growth habit**  
A twining, woody vine climbing 10–20+ meters into the canopy, with stems reaching 10+ cm diameter. Vines twine around and strangle host trees. Spreads by seed and root sprouts.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly elliptic to nearly round**, 5–12 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are glossy green, turning yellow in fall.

**Flowers**  
Plants are typically **dioecious** (some plants polygamo-dioecious). Flowers are small, **greenish-yellow**, borne in **axillary clusters** along the stem. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **yellow-orange capsule**, 8–10 mm across, splitting to reveal **bright red, fleshy-coated seeds (arils)**. The yellow capsule + red aril combination is showy. Fruits are produced **along the stems** at leaf axils.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are bird-dispersed; each berry produces multiple seeds.

**Morphology**  
**C. orbiculatus** is identified by its **twining habit**, **axillary fruit clusters** (vs. terminal in native bittersweet), and **yellow-orange capsules with red arils**. Distinguished from **C. scandens** (American bittersweet) which has fruit only at branch tips. HIGHLY INVASIVE—do not plant. Remove and destroy plants where found. A severe threat to native forests.

**Centaurea cyanus**, commonly known as cornflower or bachelor's button, is an **annual herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely cultivated as an ornamental and occasionally escapes to **roadsides, fields, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching annual, 30–90 cm tall, with slender, grooved stems covered with loose, cottony pubescence. Plants are gray-green in appearance.

**Leaves**  
Lower leaves are **lance-shaped**, sometimes with a few lobes near the base, 5–15 cm long. Upper leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, entire, sessile. All leaves are covered with cottony hairs, giving a grayish appearance.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **solitary** at branch tips, 2–4 cm across. **Ray florets are bright blue** (also pink, white, or purple in cultivars), tubular, with deeply lobed tips, spreading outward. Disk florets are violet-blue. Involucral bracts have **fringed, papery margins**. Blooms summer.

**Fruit**  
Achenes are 4–5 mm long with a short pappus of bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**C. cyanus** is identified by its **brilliant blue flower heads**, **cottony gray-green foliage**, and **fringed involucral bracts**. The intense blue is distinctive—historically used as a dye. Once a common weed in European grain fields (hence "cornflower") but now rare there due to herbicides. Popular garden annual.

**Cephalanthus occidentalis**, commonly known as buttonbush, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Rubiaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **swamps, pond margins, stream banks, and wet ditches**, often growing in standing water.

**Growth habit**  
A multi-stemmed shrub or small tree, 2–5 meters tall, with spreading, irregular branches. Bark is gray-brown, deeply furrowed on older stems. Often grows leaning over water.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite or whorled** (in 3s), **simple**, **elliptic to ovate**, 8–15 cm long, with **entire margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are glossy dark green above, paler beneath. Stipules are small, triangular, between the petioles.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense, spherical heads** 2–4 cm across, on long peduncles from upper leaf axils. Individual flowers are tiny, tubular, **white**, with **long-exserted styles** giving the heads a pin-cushion appearance. Fragrant and highly attractive to butterflies. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a cluster of **reddish-brown nutlets** in a spherical head, persisting into winter.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets contain 2 seeds each; dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**C. occidentalis** is identified by its **spherical white flower heads** resembling ping-pong balls, **opposite to whorled leaves**, and **wet habitat**. The pin-cushion flower heads are unique among native shrubs. Important nectar source for butterflies and bees. All parts are **toxic** to livestock and humans.

**Cercis canadensis**, commonly known as eastern redbud, is a **small deciduous tree** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist forests, woodland edges, and stream banks**, one of the showiest spring-flowering native trees.

**Growth habit**  
A small tree or large shrub, 6–12 meters tall, with a **short trunk** and **broad, rounded crown**. Bark is dark gray to black, becoming scaly with age. Often multi-stemmed.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **heart-shaped (cordate)**, 7–12 cm long and wide, with **entire margins** and a pointed tip. Leaves emerge after flowering. Color is dark green above, paler beneath. Fall color is yellow.

**Flowers**  
Flowers appear **before leaves** in early spring, borne in **clusters directly on branches and even the trunk** (cauliflory). Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 1–1.5 cm long, **bright pink to magenta** (rarely white). Blooms March–May, creating spectacular spring display.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a flat, **papery legume** (pod), 6–10 cm long, pink when young, maturing brown, persisting into winter.

**Seeds**  
Each pod contains 4–10 flat, hard seeds.

**Morphology**  
**C. canadensis** is identified by its **heart-shaped leaves**, **pink flowers appearing before leaves on bare branches**, and **flat pods**. The cauliflorous flowering (flowers on old wood) is unusual among temperate trees. State tree of Oklahoma. Popular ornamental with many cultivars including white and weeping forms.

**Chelone glabra**, commonly known as white turtlehead, is a **perennial herb** in the **Plantaginaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, stream banks, marshes, and moist woods**, often in partial shade.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, unbranched or sparingly branched herb, 60–120 cm tall, with smooth, square-angled stems arising from a rhizome. Plants often form clumps.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **lanceolate to narrowly elliptic**, 8–15 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins** and short petioles. Leaves are dark green, smooth, prominently veined.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **dense, terminal spike** 5–10 cm long. Individual flowers are **strongly 2-lipped**, 2.5–3.5 cm long, **white** (sometimes pink-tinged), resembling a turtle's head with the mouth slightly open—hence the common name. Upper lip arches over lower lip. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **ovoid capsule** containing numerous winged seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are flat, winged; wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**C. glabra** is identified by its **white, turtle-head-shaped flowers**, **opposite serrate leaves**, and **wet habitat**. Distinguished from **C. lyonii** (pink turtlehead) and **C. obliqua** (red turtlehead) by white (not pink/red) flowers. Important late-season nectar source. Larval host for Baltimore checkerspot butterfly. Valuable for rain gardens.

**Chimaphila maculata**, commonly known as striped wintergreen or spotted wintergreen, is a **low, evergreen perennial herb** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry to mesic oak and pine forests**, often in acidic, sandy soils.

**Growth habit**  
A low subshrub, 10–25 cm tall, with creeping rhizomes and erect, unbranched stems. Plants are semi-woody at the base and form loose colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **whorled or nearly opposite**, **lanceolate to ovate**, 2–6 cm long, **leathery and evergreen**, with **toothed margins**. Leaves are dark green with **conspicuous white stripes along the veins**—the "striped" or "spotted" appearance is diagnostic.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **terminal cluster of 1–5 nodding flowers** on a leafless stalk. Individual flowers are **waxy white to pinkish**, 1–1.5 cm across, with **5 rounded petals** and a prominent green ovary. Fragrant. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **erect, rounded capsule**, 5–8 mm across, brown, persisting through winter.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are tiny, dust-like; dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**  
**C. maculata** is identified by its **white-striped evergreen leaves** and **nodding waxy flowers**. Distinguished from **C. umbellata** (pipsissewa) which has uniformly green leaves without stripes. Like other Ericaceae, requires mycorrhizal fungi for germination. A charming woodland wildflower.

**Cichorium intybus**, commonly known as chicory or blue sailors, is a **perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America along **roadsides, fields, waste places, and disturbed areas**, often in compacted or poor soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching herb, 30–150 cm tall, with a stout taproot. Stems are stiff, grooved, sparingly hairy, with a milky sap.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves form a rosette, **oblanceolate**, **deeply lobed** (dandelion-like), 10–25 cm long. Stem leaves are **alternate**, much smaller, **lanceolate**, clasping, with entire to toothed margins. Upper leaves are often reduced to bracts.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **sessile or short-stalked** in upper leaf axils, 2.5–4 cm across. All florets are **ray florets**, **bright sky-blue** (rarely pink or white), strap-shaped with 5 teeth at the tip. Flowers open in morning and close by midday. Blooms summer to fall (July–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are 2–3 mm long, angled, with a short pappus of scales.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**C. intybus** is identified by its **bright blue flower heads**, **stiff branching habit**, and **roadside habitat**. The vivid blue color is distinctive—few other plants match the hue. The root is roasted as a coffee substitute or additive. Cultivated forms include radicchio and Belgian endive.

**Cicuta maculata**, commonly known as spotted water hemlock, is a **tall perennial herb** in the **Apiaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, stream banks, marshes, and ditches**. **EXTREMELY TOXIC—one of North America's most poisonous plants.**

**Growth habit**  
An erect, stout herb, 100–200 cm tall, with hollow, branching stems that are **streaked or mottled with purple** ("spotted"). Arising from a cluster of thick, chambered tuberous roots.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times pinnately compound**, 20–40 cm long. Leaflets are **lanceolate**, 5–12 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and veins running to the sinuses (notches) between teeth—a key identifier.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **compound umbels** 8–12 cm across, with 15–25 rays. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, 5-petaled. Involucral bracts are few or absent. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **schizocarp** splitting into 2 rounded, ribbed mericarps, 2–4 mm long.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**C. maculata** is identified by its **purple-streaked stems**, **wet habitat**, **veins running to leaf sinuses**, and **chambered tuberous roots**. Distinguished from **Daucus carota** (wild carrot) by habitat and smooth (not hairy) stems. **ALL PARTS ARE DEADLY TOXIC**—especially the roots, which smell like parsnip. Even small amounts can kill. Never consume any part of any wild carrot-family plant without expert identification.

**Circaea alpina**, commonly known as small enchanter's nightshade or alpine enchanter's nightshade, is a **delicate perennial herb** in the **Onagraceae** family. Native to northern North America, Europe, and Asia, this species inhabits **cool, moist forests, mossy stream banks, and shaded ravines**, often in montane or boreal regions.

**Growth habit**  
A delicate, low herb, 5–25 cm tall, with slender stems arising from **small tubers** on thread-like rhizomes. Plants form loose colonies in favorable sites.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **heart-shaped to ovate**, 2–6 cm long, with **coarsely toothed margins**, thin texture, and pointed tips. Leaves are bright green, somewhat shiny.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **slender terminal racemes**, becoming elongate in fruit. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, with **2 deeply notched petals**, 2 sepals, and 2 stamens. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small, **club-shaped capsule**, 1.5–3 mm long, covered with **soft hooked bristles** that catch on fur and clothing.

**Seeds**  
Each capsule contains 1 seed; dispersed by clinging to animals.

**Morphology**  
**C. alpina** is identified by its **delicate habit**, **heart-shaped opposite leaves**, **tiny 2-parted white flowers**, and **bristly fruits**. Distinguished from **C. canadensis** (broad-leaved enchanter's nightshade) which is larger with more prominent teeth. The "enchanter's nightshade" name is fanciful—no relationship to nightshades (Solanaceae).

**Cirsium altissimum**, commonly known as tall thistle, is a **biennial or perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to central and eastern North America, this species inhabits **prairies, open woods, roadsides, and field edges**, often in rich soils.

**Growth habit**  
A tall, erect herb, 100–300 cm tall, with stout, branching stems. Stems are densely white-woolly, especially above. First-year plants form a basal rosette; second-year plants bolt and flower.

**Leaves**  
Basal and lower stem leaves are **elliptic to oblanceolate**, 15–40 cm long, with **shallow lobes or coarse teeth** tipped with weak spines. Upper leaves are smaller, less lobed, **white-tomentose beneath**. Leaves are not as deeply lobed as many thistles. **Leaf bases do not run down the stem** (not decurrent).

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **solitary or few** at branch tips, 4–6 cm across (including florets). All florets are **disk florets**, **pink to purple** (rarely white), tubular, fragrant. Involucral bracts are **appressed**, with **weak spine tips**. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are 4–5 mm long, brown, with a **feathery white pappus**.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**C. altissimum** is identified by its **tall stature**, **white-woolly stems**, **shallowly lobed leaves with white-felted undersides**, and **non-decurrent leaf bases**. Distinguished from **C. discolor** (field thistle) which has more deeply lobed leaves. Native thistle—important for pollinators, especially bumblebees and butterflies.

**Clematis terniflora**, commonly known as sweet autumn clematis or Japanese clematis, is a **vigorous, semi-evergreen to deciduous vine** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is widely planted as an ornamental and has become **invasive** in parts of eastern North America.

**Growth habit**  
A climbing vine reaching 5–10+ meters, climbing by **twining leaf petioles**. Stems are woody at the base, herbaceous above. Spreads aggressively by seed and can smother vegetation.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **pinnately compound** with **3–5 leaflets**. Leaflets are **ovate to lanceolate**, 4–10 cm long, with **entire margins** (sometimes with a few coarse teeth), glossy dark green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **profuse axillary and terminal panicles**, creating a mass of bloom. Individual flowers are 2–3 cm across, with **4 white, petal-like sepals** (true petals absent), **fragrant** with a sweet vanilla scent. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **achenes** with **long, feathery, persistent styles** forming silky, plume-like clusters.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the feathery styles.

**Morphology**  
**C. terniflora** is identified by its **masses of fragrant white flowers in fall**, **pinnately compound leaves with entire leaflets**, and **feathery seed heads**. Distinguished from native **C. virginiana** (virgin's bower) which has coarsely toothed leaflets. **INVASIVE** in many areas—escapes cultivation and smothers native vegetation. Consider native alternatives.

**Convallaria majalis**, commonly known as lily-of-the-valley, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asparagaceae** family. Native to Europe and eastern Asia (some populations in Appalachians may be native), this species is widely cultivated and escapes to **moist, shaded woodlands and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A low, colony-forming herb, 15–25 cm tall, spreading aggressively by creeping rhizomes. Plants form dense groundcover patches.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, usually **2–3 per shoot**, **elliptic to broadly lanceolate**, 10–20 cm long, with **entire margins**, **parallel venation**, and a sheathing base. Leaves are dark green, smooth, somewhat leathery.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne on a **leafless, arching raceme** (scape) with **5–15 nodding, bell-shaped flowers**. Individual flowers are 6–10 mm long, **waxy white**, powerfully **sweet-fragrant**. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round, red-orange berry**, 6–10 mm across, in a cluster.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains several seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**C. majalis** is identified by its **fragrant, nodding white bell flowers**, **broad parallel-veined leaves**, and **colony-forming habit**. **ALL PARTS ARE HIGHLY TOXIC**—contains cardiac glycosides. Even water from cut flowers can be dangerous. The sweetly scented flowers belie the plant's deadly nature. Do not consume any part.

**Coreopsis auriculata**, commonly known as lobed tickseed or eared coreopsis, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to southeastern North America, this species inhabits **open woods, rocky slopes, and forest edges**, often in dry to mesic conditions.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading herb, 20–60 cm tall, forming clumps and colonies from creeping rhizomes. Stems are erect to ascending, often with stolons.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **simple to 3–5 lobed**, **ovate to elliptic**, 5–10 cm long, with a prominent **pair of small basal lobes ("ears")** at the petiole junction—hence "auriculata" (eared). Stem leaves are smaller, sometimes entire. Leaves are bright green.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne on long peduncles, **solitary or in loose clusters**, 3–5 cm across. **Ray florets are 6–10, bright golden yellow**, often with a darker base, broad with toothed tips. Disk florets are yellow to orange. Blooms spring to early summer (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are small, flattened, wingless or narrowly winged.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**C. auriculata** is identified by its **basal leaves with small "ears" at the petiole base**, **bright yellow flower heads**, and **spreading habit**. Distinguished from **C. lanceolata** (lanceleaf coreopsis) by lobed vs. entire basal leaves. Popular native garden plant. 'Nana' is a common dwarf cultivar.

**Cornus alternifolia**, commonly known as pagoda dogwood or alternate-leaved dogwood, is a **small deciduous tree or large shrub** in the **Cornaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist forests, woodland edges, and stream banks**, often in understory.

**Growth habit**  
A small tree or large shrub, 5–10 meters tall, with a distinctive **horizontally layered branching pattern** resembling a pagoda. Branches grow in tiers, creating a striking architectural form.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate** (unique among native dogwoods), **elliptic to ovate**, 6–12 cm long, with **entire to slightly wavy margins** and **arcuate venation** (veins curving toward tip). Leaves are clustered at branch tips. Fall color is reddish-purple.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **flat-topped cymes** 4–8 cm across, without showy bracts (unlike flowering dogwood). Individual flowers are small, 4-petaled, **creamy white**. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round drupe**, 6–8 mm across, **blue-black** on **red pedicels**—the color contrast is showy. Fruit clusters appear July–September.

**Seeds**  
Each drupe contains 1–2 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**C. alternifolia** is identified by its **alternate leaves** (all other native Cornus have opposite leaves), **tiered branching**, and **blue-black fruit on red stalks**. The pagoda-like architecture is distinctive in the landscape. Valuable for wildlife. Susceptible to golden canker disease.

**Corylus americana**, commonly known as American hazelnut, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Betulaceae** family. Native to eastern and central North America, this species inhabits **woodland edges, thickets, roadsides, and fencerows**, often forming dense colonies.

**Growth habit**  
A multi-stemmed shrub, 2–4 meters tall, spreading by root suckers to form thickets. Twigs are pubescent and often glandular-bristly.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly ovate to nearly round**, 6–12 cm long, with **doubly serrate margins** and a pointed tip. Leaves are softly hairy on both surfaces, especially on veins beneath. Fall color is yellow to orange-red.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers in **pendant catkins**, 4–8 cm long, appearing before leaves—showy in late winter. Female flowers are tiny, with only **red stigmas** protruding from a scaly bud. Blooms late winter to early spring (February–April).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round nut**, 1–1.5 cm across, enclosed in **2 leafy, ragged-edged bracts (involucre)** that extend well beyond the nut and have bristly-glandular hairs.

**Seeds**  
The nut contains one edible seed—a hazelnut.

**Morphology**  
**C. americana** is identified by its **round, doubly serrate leaves**, **pendant male catkins in late winter**, and **nuts enclosed in ragged, bristly husks**. Distinguished from **C. cornuta** (beaked hazelnut) which has tubular, beak-like husks. Nuts are edible and delicious but often claimed by squirrels before humans can harvest.

**Crataegus coccinea**, commonly known as scarlet hawthorn or red haw, is a **small deciduous tree or large shrub** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to northeastern North America, this species inhabits **woodland edges, thickets, old fields, and fencerows**. Hawthorn taxonomy is notoriously complex.

**Growth habit**  
A small tree or large shrub, 5–10 meters tall, with a rounded, dense crown. Branches bear **sharp thorns** 3–5 cm long. Bark is gray-brown, scaly.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly ovate to triangular**, 4–8 cm long, with **3–5 shallow, serrate lobes** and a **broadly wedge-shaped to truncate base**. Leaves are thick, dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **flat-topped corymbs** of 5–12 flowers. Individual flowers are **white** (sometimes pinkish), 1.5–2 cm across, with **5 petals** and numerous stamens with **pink to red anthers**. Blooms spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **pome**, 1–1.5 cm across, **bright scarlet red**, glossy, with 3–5 nutlets, persisting into winter.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are bony, dispersed by birds and mammals.

**Morphology**  
**Crataegus** identification is difficult—hundreds of species and hybrids exist. **C. coccinea** is characterized by **shallowly lobed leaves**, **pink-anthered flowers**, and **bright red fruit**. The specific epithet "coccinea" means scarlet. Hawthorns are important wildlife food and shelter. Thorns make effective barrier plantings.

**Cuscuta campestris**, commonly known as field dodder or golden dodder, is an **annual parasitic vine** in the **Convolvulaceae** family. Native to North America, this species parasitizes a wide range of herbaceous hosts in **fields, gardens, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A leafless, rootless, **bright orange to yellow twining vine** that wraps around host plants and penetrates their stems with specialized structures (haustoria) to extract water and nutrients. Plants are entirely parasitic.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are reduced to **tiny, vestigial scales**, barely visible. No photosynthesis occurs.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense, rounded clusters** 5–15 mm across along the stems. Individual flowers are tiny, **white to cream**, with **5 fused petals** forming an urn shape. Blooms summer to fall (June–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small capsule**, 2–3 mm across, containing 2–4 seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds germinate in soil; seedlings must find and attach to a host within days or die.

**Morphology**  
**Cuscuta** is unmistakable: the **bright orange, leafless, tangled stems** wrapped around host plants resemble masses of orange spaghetti. Distinguished from other dodders by flower details. Parasitizes many crops and garden plants. Often considered a serious agricultural pest. The appearance of dodder is a sign of underlying host plant presence.

**Cynoglossum amabile**, commonly known as Chinese forget-me-not or Chinese hound's tongue, is a **biennial or short-lived perennial herb** in the **Boraginaceae** family. Native to Asia, this species is cultivated as an ornamental and occasionally escapes to **disturbed areas, roadsides, and gardens**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, with branching stems covered in soft hairs. Basal rosette forms the first year; flowering stalks arise the second year.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **elliptic to spatulate**, 10–20 cm long, petioled. Stem leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate**, sessile, becoming smaller upward. All leaves are softly hairy (pubescent) with a grayish-green appearance.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **coiled, scorpioid cymes** (unfurling like a fiddlehead as flowers open). Individual flowers are **5-lobed**, 8–10 mm across, **bright sky-blue** with a white eye, resembling true forget-me-nots (Myosotis). Blooms spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **4 nutlets** covered with **barbed prickles** (glochids), resembling tiny burs.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are dispersed by clinging to fur and clothing.

**Morphology**
