**C. amabile** is identified by its **bright blue flowers with white eye**, **hairy gray-green foliage**, and **prickly nutlets**. Distinguished from true forget-me-nots (Myosotis) by larger size and prickly fruits. The related **C. officinale** (common hound's tongue) has reddish-purple flowers and is more weedy.

**Cypripedium acaule**, commonly known as pink lady's slipper or moccasin flower, is a **terrestrial orchid** in the **Orchidaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry to moist acidic forests**, especially under pines and oaks, often in nutrient-poor soils.

**Growth habit**  
A perennial herb, 15–40 cm tall, arising from a short rhizome. Plants grow very slowly and may take 10–15 years to flower from seed. Colonies are long-lived but difficult to transplant.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **2, basal**, **broadly elliptic**, 15–25 cm long, with **prominent parallel veins** and a pleated appearance. Leaves are hairy along veins, arising directly from the ground with no stem. The "acaule" means stemless.

**Flowers**  
Flower is **solitary**, borne on a hairy scape 20–40 cm tall arising between the two leaves. The flower has a **large, pink, pouch-shaped lip** (labellum) 4–6 cm long, with a vertical slit down the front, veined with darker pink. Upper sepal is greenish-brown; lateral petals are greenish to brownish, narrow, twisted. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **erect capsule** containing thousands of dust-like seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are microscopic, wind-dispersed; require specific mycorrhizal fungi to germinate.

**Morphology**  
**C. acaule** is identified by its **2 basal leaves**, **stemless habit**, and **pink pouch-like flower with a slit opening**. Distinguished from **C. reginae** (showy lady's slipper) which has leafy stems and white-and-pink flowers. Do NOT dig or transplant—plants rarely survive and populations are declining. One of the most beautiful native wildflowers.

**Dactylis glomerata**, commonly known as orchard grass or cock's-foot, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **meadows, pastures, roadsides, and open woods**, one of the most common introduced grasses.

**Growth habit**  
A coarse, tufted bunchgrass, 60–120 cm tall, forming large clumps. Plants are long-lived and drought-tolerant. Does not spread by rhizomes.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–40 cm long, 5–12 mm wide, flat or folded at the base, with a distinctive **V-shaped cross-section** and a **prominent, sharply pointed keel**. Leaves are blue-green to grayish-green.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **panicle**, 5–20 cm long, with branches bearing **dense, one-sided clusters of spikelets** at their tips. Spikelets are flattened, 5–9 mm long, containing 2–5 florets. The one-sided, clumped arrangement resembles a rooster's foot. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**D. glomerata** is identified by its **large tufted habit**, **blue-green V-shaped leaves**, and **one-sided clumped panicle branches**. One of the first grasses to green up in spring. Important pasture and hay grass but can dominate meadows at the expense of native species. Common allergen.

**Daucus carota**, commonly known as Queen Anne's lace or wild carrot, is a **biennial herb** in the **Apiaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **fields, roadsides, meadows, and disturbed areas**—one of the most common roadside wildflowers.

**Growth habit**  
A biennial forming a basal rosette and taproot the first year; an erect, branching flowering stem 30–150 cm tall the second year. Stems are rough-hairy. The taproot smells like carrot—the plant is the wild ancestor of cultivated carrots.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times pinnately compound** with finely dissected, fern-like segments. Leaves are hairy, carrot-scented when crushed.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **compound umbels** 7–15 cm across, flat-topped to slightly convex. Individual flowers are tiny, **white** (rarely pink), 5-petaled. Often a single **dark purple floret** at the center of the umbel. As fruits develop, the umbel curls inward like a bird's nest.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **schizocarp** splitting into 2 mericarps, each 3–4 mm long, with **rows of bristly spines**.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are dispersed by clinging to animals.

**Morphology**  
**D. carota** is identified by its **lacy white umbels** (often with a purple center flower), **hairy stems**, **fern-like leaves**, and **carrot-scented root**. **CAUTION:** Can be confused with deadly **Cicuta** (water hemlock) and **Conium** (poison hemlock). Always confirm ID before consuming any wild carrot-family plant—mistakes are fatal.

**Desmodium canadense**, commonly known as showy tick-trefoil or Canadian tick-trefoil, is a **perennial herb** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **prairies, meadows, woodland edges, and roadsides**, often in moist to dry soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching herb, 60–150 cm tall, with stems that are densely hairy with hooked hairs. Plants often form loose colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **lanceolate to oblong**, 5–10 cm long, with pointed tips. Leaves are hairy beneath. Stipules are persistent, slender.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal and axillary racemes** forming a showy panicle. Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 10–15 mm long, **pink to purplish-rose**, fading to blue. Upper petal (banner) often has a green-yellow center. Blooms summer (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **loment**—a legume constricted into **3–5 segments**, each segment 7–10 mm long, covered with **hooked hairs** that stick to fur and clothing ("tick-trefoil," "beggar's ticks").

**Seeds**  
Each segment contains one seed; dispersed by clinging to animals.

**Morphology**  
**D. canadense** is identified by its **showy pink-purple flowers** (largest of the tick-trefoils), **trifoliate leaves**, and **segmented, sticky fruits**. Distinguished from other Desmodium species by the large, showy flower clusters. Important native pollinator plant. The clinging seeds are highly effective at hitchhiking.

**Dicentra canadensis**, commonly known as squirrel corn, is a **spring ephemeral perennial herb** in the **Papaveraceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often in association with other spring ephemerals.

**Growth habit**  
A delicate herb, 15–30 cm tall, arising from a cluster of **small, yellow, grain-like bulblets** resembling kernels of corn—hence "squirrel corn" (a favorite food of squirrels). Plants go dormant by summer.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **finely dissected** into narrow segments, creating a lacy, fern-like appearance, pale blue-green. Leaves are nearly identical to Dutchman's breeches (D. cucullaria).

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **nodding raceme** of 4–8 flowers on a leafless scape. Individual flowers are **heart-shaped**, 12–15 mm long, **white** (often tinted pink or greenish), with **2 rounded spurs** (not elongated like D. cucullaria), fragrant. Blooms early spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **elongate capsule** containing several seeds with fleshy appendages.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by ants (myrmecochory).

**Morphology**  
**D. canadensis** is identified by its **white, rounded-spurred heart-shaped flowers** and **finely dissected blue-green leaves**. Distinguished from **D. cucullaria** (Dutchman's breeches) by rounded spurs (not pantaloon-shaped) and yellow grain-like bulblets (not white scaly bulbs). The two often grow together. All parts contain toxic alkaloids.

**Dichanthelium acuminatum**, commonly known as tapered rosette grass or hairy panicgrass, is a **perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this highly variable species complex inhabits **dry to moist open woods, fields, and sandy areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted grass, 20–80 cm tall, with 2 distinct growth phases: spring plants have erect culms with terminal panicles; later, plants become bushy with many branches bearing smaller, cleistogamous (self-fertilizing) panicles from the axils.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate**, 5–15 cm long, 5–15 mm wide, often hairy (pubescence varies greatly by variety). Basal winter rosettes may persist. Ligule is a ring of hairs.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is an **open panicle**, 4–12 cm long, with spreading branches. Spikelets are small, 1.5–3 mm long, ellipsoid, 2-flowered (lower floret sterile, upper fertile). Blooms spring and again in fall (autumnal phase).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in a shiny, hardened lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed when spikelets fall.

**Morphology**  
**D. acuminatum** is part of a complex of similar species. Identified by its **dimorphic growth habit** (vernal and autumnal phases), **hairy leaves and sheaths** (variable), and **small ellipsoid spikelets**. Extremely variable; many segregate species have been described. Common in sandy, open habitats.

**Digitaria sanguinalis**, commonly known as hairy crabgrass or large crabgrass, is an **annual grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, gardens, fields, and disturbed areas**—one of the most familiar lawn weeds.

**Growth habit**  
A spreading annual, 20–80 cm tall, with stems (culms) that often root at the lower nodes, forming mats. Plants radiate from a central point, giving the "crab" appearance.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 5–15 cm long, 5–10 mm wide, flat, hairy on both surfaces. Sheaths are hairy. Ligule is membranous.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence consists of **3–10 finger-like spikes** (racemes) radiating from near the culm tip, each spike 5–15 cm long. Spikelets are small, 2.5–3.5 mm long, arranged in pairs along one side of the rachis, greenish to purplish. Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are prolific; a single plant produces thousands of seeds that persist in the soil.

**Morphology**  
**D. sanguinalis** is identified by its **mat-forming habit**, **hairy leaves and sheaths**, and **finger-like spikes radiating from the stem tip**. Distinguished from **D. ischaemum** (smooth crabgrass) which is smaller and hairless. The bane of lawn enthusiasts—thrives in summer heat when cool-season lawns are stressed. Annual; dies with frost but seeds persist.

**Echinochloa crus-galli**, commonly known as barnyard grass or cockspur grass, is an **annual grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe or Asia, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **moist fields, gardens, ditches, and disturbed areas**—a common weed of cultivated land.

**Growth habit**  
A coarse, tufted annual, 30–150 cm tall, with thick, often reddish stems that may root at lower nodes. Plants are robust and fast-growing.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 10–40 cm long, 10–25 mm wide, flat, smooth, without hairs. Sheaths are smooth. **Ligule is absent**—a key diagnostic feature distinguishing Echinochloa from most other grasses.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **panicle** of dense, spike-like racemes, 10–25 cm long, often purplish. Racemes are crowded, ascending to spreading. Spikelets are 3–4 mm long, often with a **short to long awn** (variable). Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the hardened lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are prolific; plants produce thousands of seeds.

**Morphology**  
**E. crus-galli** is identified by its **coarse habit**, **absent ligule**, and **dense, often purplish panicle with awned spikelets**. Highly variable species. A troublesome weed in rice paddies and corn fields. The name "cockspur" refers to the awned spikelets resembling a rooster's spur.

**Echinocystis lobata**, commonly known as wild cucumber or balsam apple, is an **annual vine** in the **Cucurbitaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist thickets, stream banks, floodplains, and fence rows**, often climbing over shrubs and small trees.

**Growth habit**  
A vigorous, fast-growing annual vine reaching 5–8 meters, climbing by **branched tendrils**. Stems are angular, smooth, succulent. Plants can blanket vegetation with their growth.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately 5-lobed**, 5–15 cm across, resembling maple leaves, with pointed lobes and a heart-shaped base. Leaves are thin-textured, bright green.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers are borne in **long, erect racemes** from leaf axils, with 6 white petals, showy and fragrant. Female flowers are **solitary or in small clusters** at the same nodes, greenish, inconspicuous. Blooms summer (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **spiny, inflated capsule**, 3–5 cm long, oval, covered with weak prickles, resembling a small spiny cucumber. Capsule dries and splits at the apex to release seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are large, flat, dark brown, 4 per fruit; forcibly expelled when capsule dries.

**Morphology**  
**E. lobata** is identified by its **maple-like lobed leaves**, **white flowers in showy racemes**, **branched tendrils**, and **spiny inflated fruits**. Despite the common name, the fruit is NOT edible. Native and generally not considered invasive, though vigorous. Adds textural interest to moist woodland edges.

**Eleocharis obtusa**, commonly known as blunt spikerush or ovate spikerush, is a **perennial or annual sedge** in the **Cyperaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, pond margins, marshes, and mudflats**, often in shallow water or saturated soils.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted sedge, 10–50 cm tall, forming dense clumps. Stems (culms) are round in cross-section, spongy, leafless, arising from fibrous roots or short rhizomes.

**Leaves**  
True leaves are **reduced to basal sheaths** with no blade—the photosynthetic stems function as leaves. Sheaths are reddish to brownish at the base.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **single terminal spikelet** per stem, 4–12 mm long, **ovoid to broadly ellipsoid**, with many spirally arranged scales. Scales are brown with lighter margins. Flowers are tiny, with 3 stigmas. Blooms summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **achene**, 1–1.5 mm long, lens-shaped (biconvex), yellowish-brown, capped with a **tubercle** (persistent style base) that is much narrower than the achene body.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**E. obtusa** is identified by its **leafless round stems**, **single terminal ovoid spikelet**, and **achene with a narrow tubercle**. Distinguished from similar spikerushes by the blunt (obtuse) spikelet shape and tubercle form. Common in ephemeral wetlands.

**Elymus canadensis**, commonly known as Canada wild rye, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **prairies, open woods, stream banks, and roadsides**, adaptable to various soil types.

**Growth habit**  
A robust bunchgrass, 80–150 cm tall, forming clumps from a fibrous root system. Culms are stout, often nodding at the top due to the heavy seed head.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–30 cm long, 8–18 mm wide, flat, rough on both surfaces, often with a bluish-green color. Auricles (ear-like appendages at the leaf base) are well-developed, clasping the stem.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **dense, bristly spike**, 10–25 cm long, often nodding or arching. Spikelets are in pairs (sometimes 3s) at each node, 2–4 flowered, with **long, spreading to recurved awns** 2–4 cm long, giving a bushy, bottle-brush appearance. Blooms summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma, with the awn attached.

**Seeds**  
Grains with awns are dispersed by wind and by catching on fur.

**Morphology**  
**E. canadensis** is identified by its **tall stature**, **nodding spike with long curving awns**, and **well-developed auricles**. Distinguished from **E. virginicus** (Virginia wild rye) which has shorter, straighter awns. Important native grass for restoration and erosion control. Provides winter food for birds.

**Epilobium ciliatum**, commonly known as fringed willowherb or American willowherb, is a **perennial herb** in the **Onagraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, stream banks, disturbed areas, and wetland edges**, one of the most common willowherbs.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–150 cm tall, with stems that are often branched above and may have lines of hairs running down from the leaf bases (decurrent pubescence).

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite below**, becoming **alternate above**, **lanceolate to narrowly elliptic**, 3–10 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**. Leaves are sessile or short-petioled, often with prominent veins.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are small, borne in **leafy, terminal racemes**. Individual flowers have **4 pink to white petals**, 3–8 mm long, **notched at the tip**. Stigma is club-shaped, not 4-lobed (unlike Oenothera). Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **long, narrow capsule**, 4–8 cm long, splitting to release seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds bear a tuft of white hairs (coma) at one end, wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**E. ciliatum** is identified by its **small notched pink or white petals**, **club-shaped stigma**, and **cottony-seeded capsules**. Distinguished from other willowherbs by leaf shape and pubescence patterns. A weedy but native species. The genus name Epilobium means "upon the pod," referring to the flower position.

**Eragrostis spectabilis**, commonly known as purple lovegrass, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry, sandy fields, roadsides, open woods, and prairies**, often in poor, well-drained soils.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted bunchgrass, 30–70 cm tall, forming dense clumps. The distinctive purple panicle breaks off at maturity and tumbles in the wind, dispersing seeds—a "tumbleweed" habit.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 10–30 cm long, 3–6 mm wide, flat to inrolled, often with long hairs at the base. Leaves are mostly basal.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **large, diffuse, reddish-purple panicle**, 15–40 cm long and nearly as wide, accounting for most of the plant's height. Spikelets are small, 5–10 mm long, flattened, purplish, containing 6–12 florets. The delicate, airy panicle is highly ornamental. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a tiny **caryopsis**, reddish-brown.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed as the panicle breaks off and tumbles.

**Morphology**  
**E. spectabilis** is identified by its **large, diffuse purple panicle** that comprises most of the plant's visible structure, and its **tumbling dispersal mechanism**. One of the most beautiful native grasses. Excellent for dry meadow gardens. The purple haze of flowering lovegrass is unmistakable in late summer.

**Erigeron annuus**, commonly known as annual fleabane or daisy fleabane, is an **annual or biennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **fields, roadsides, waste places, and disturbed areas**—one of the most common weedy wildflowers.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching herb, 30–150 cm tall, with stems that are hairy with spreading hairs. Plants often become bushy with many flower heads.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **spatulate to oblanceolate**, 5–15 cm long, with **coarsely toothed margins**, often withering by flowering time. Stem leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate to ovate**, becoming smaller upward, with toothed to nearly entire margins.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **numerous**, borne in **open, flat-topped clusters**. Each head is 1–2 cm across, with **80–125 white to pinkish ray florets** (narrow, numerous) surrounding a **yellow disk**. Ray florets are much narrower than those of asters. Blooms late spring to fall (May–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are tiny with a sparse pappus of short bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant or by wind.

**Morphology**  
**E. annuus** is identified by its **numerous narrow white rays** (more than most similar species), **spreading stem hairs**, and **weedy habit**. Distinguished from **E. strigosus** (rough fleabane) which has appressed (not spreading) hairs. Common and weedy but native. The name "fleabane" suggests historical use to repel fleas.

**Erythronium albidum**, commonly known as white trout lily or white fawn lily, is a **spring ephemeral perennial herb** in the **Liliaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests and bottomlands**, often forming extensive colonies.

**Growth habit**  
A delicate herb, 10–25 cm tall, arising from a deep, elongate **corm**. Plants spread by producing offsets (cormels) and stolons, forming large colonies over time. Non-flowering plants produce a single leaf; flowering plants produce two.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, 1–2 per plant, **elliptic to lanceolate**, 8–20 cm long, **mottled with brownish-purple blotches** on a green background—resembling brook trout markings, hence "trout lily." Leaves are smooth, succulent.

**Flowers**  
Flower is **solitary**, nodding, on a leafless scape 10–20 cm tall. The flower has **6 white tepals** (sometimes tinged lavender or pink on the back), 2–3 cm long, **strongly recurved** (bent backward). Stamens have yellow anthers. Blooms early spring (March–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **3-lobed capsule**, held erect as the scape lengthens.

**Seeds**  
Seeds have a fleshy appendage; dispersed by ants (myrmecochory).

**Morphology**  
**E. albidum** is identified by its **white recurved tepals**, **mottled basal leaves**, and **early spring bloom**. Distinguished from **E. americanum** (yellow trout lily) by white (not yellow) flowers. Colonies may be decades old. Plants may take 7+ years to flower from seed. A classic spring ephemeral.

**Eupatorium cannabinum**, commonly known as hemp agrimony, is a **perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is occasionally cultivated and may escape to **moist areas, stream banks, and disturbed wetlands** in parts of North America.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, robust herb, 60–150 cm tall, with reddish, hairy stems arising from a woody rootstock. Plants often form clumps.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **palmately divided into 3–5 lanceolate segments** (resembling hemp/cannabis leaves—hence the name), or sometimes undivided. Segments are 5–12 cm long with **coarsely serrate margins**. Leaves are downy beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in **dense, flat-topped terminal clusters** (corymbs). Individual heads are small, 2–5 mm across, containing only **tubular disk florets** (no rays), **pale pink to mauve**. Heads are grouped 5–6 florets each. Blooms late summer (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are 2–3 mm long with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**E. cannabinum** is identified by its **opposite, hemp-like divided leaves** and **clusters of small pink-mauve flower heads**. Distinguished from native Joe-Pye weeds (now Eutrochium) by the divided leaves. Not currently widespread in North America but may be encountered in gardens or as an escape. Important nectar source for butterflies in Europe.

**Euphorbia corollata**, commonly known as flowering spurge, is a **perennial herb** in the **Euphorbiaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry prairies, open woods, roadsides, and fields**, often in sandy or rocky soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–100 cm tall, with smooth, unbranched stems below and branched above, arising from a deep taproot. All parts exude **milky latex** when broken.

**Leaves**  
Lower leaves are **alternate**, **oblong to spatulate**, 2–5 cm long, with **entire margins**, sessile. Upper leaves are smaller and whorled at branch points. Leaves are smooth, pale green.

**Flowers**  
The "flowers" are actually **cyathia**—specialized Euphorbia structures with **5 showy white, petal-like appendages** surrounding tiny true flowers. Cyathia are borne in **open, branched clusters**, creating an airy, baby's-breath-like effect. Blooms summer (May–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **3-lobed capsule**, 3–4 mm across, smooth.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are expelled forcibly when capsules dehisce.

**Morphology**  
**E. corollata** is identified by its **white petal-like bracts** giving a flowering effect, **milky sap**, and **dry habitat**. One of the showiest native spurges. The white "petals" are actually gland appendages of the cyathium, not true petals. CAUTION: The milky latex is a skin and eye irritant.

**Euthamia graminifolia**, commonly known as grass-leaved goldenrod or flat-topped goldenrod, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, prairies, stream banks, and roadsides**, often forming large colonies.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 60–120 cm tall, with smooth stems that branch near the top. Spreads aggressively by creeping rhizomes to form dense stands.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear** (grass-like), 5–12 cm long, 3–10 mm wide, with **3–5 parallel veins** and **entire margins**. Leaves are numerous, sessile, with resinous dots (visible with a hand lens).

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in **flat-topped clusters** (corymbs), giving a different appearance from the plume-like goldenrods. Heads are small, 4–5 mm across, with **15–25 yellow ray florets** and yellow disk florets. Blooms late summer to fall (July–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are small with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**E. graminifolia** is identified by its **grass-like leaves with parallel veins**, **flat-topped yellow flower clusters**, and **colonial habit**. Distinguished from true goldenrods (Solidago) by the flat-topped inflorescence and linear leaves. Sometimes still listed as Solidago graminifolia. Important late-season pollinator plant.

**Fragaria ananassa**, commonly known as garden strawberry or cultivated strawberry, is a **stoloniferous perennial herb** in the **Rosaceae** family. This **hybrid species** originated in France (~1750) from crosses between F. virginiana (North America) and F. chiloensis (Chile). Widely cultivated and occasionally persists or escapes near gardens.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading herb, 15–30 cm tall, spreading by **stolons** (runners) that root at nodes to form new plants. Plants form mats in favorable conditions.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **broadly ovate**, 4–8 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins**, dark green above, paler and silky beneath. Petioles are long, hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **clusters on erect scapes**. Individual flowers are 2–3 cm across, with **5 white petals**, numerous stamens, and many pistils on a central receptacle. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
The "fruit" is an **enlarged, fleshy red receptacle** (the edible portion) studded with **achenes** (the true fruits—the "seeds" on the surface). Fruit is large, 2–5 cm across, aromatic, sweet.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are on the fruit surface; dispersed by animals eating the fruit.

**Morphology**  
**F. ananassa** is identified by its **large fruit** (much larger than wild strawberries), **trifoliate leaves**, and **stoloniferous habit**. Distinguished from native **F. virginiana** (wild strawberry) by larger fruit and leaves. The familiar supermarket strawberry. Technically not a berry but an accessory fruit.

**Gaylussacia baccata**, commonly known as black huckleberry, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry, acidic woods, rocky slopes, and barrens**, often under oaks and pines.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading shrub, 30–100 cm tall, forming colonies via underground rhizomes. Branches are slender, spreading. Young twigs are covered with resinous dots.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to obovate**, 3–5 cm long, with **entire margins** and **resinous dots** on both surfaces (visible with a hand lens—key identifier). Leaves are bright green above, paler beneath. Fall color is red to maroon.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **short, drooping racemes** of 5–10 flowers from leaf axils. Individual flowers are **urn-shaped** (urceolate), 5–7 mm long, **dull red to pinkish**, constricted at the mouth. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round, black drupe** (not a true berry), 6–10 mm across, sweet, edible, with 10 hard nutlets. Ripens July–August.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are dispersed by animals eating the fruit.

**Morphology**  
**G. baccata** is identified by its **resinous-dotted leaves**, **urn-shaped reddish flowers**, and **black fruit with 10 hard seeds**. Distinguished from blueberries (Vaccinium) by resinous leaf dots and hard-seeded fruit. Huckleberries have crunchy seeds; blueberries have soft, unnoticeable seeds. Fruit is delicious but hard to gather in quantity.

**Gentiana andrewsii**, commonly known as bottle gentian or closed gentian, is a **perennial herb** in the **Gentianaceae** family. Native to northeastern North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, prairies, stream banks, and open wetlands**, one of the showiest late-season wildflowers.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, unbranched herb, 30–60 cm tall, with stout, smooth stems arising from a thick rootstock. Plants often grow in clumps.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **lanceolate to ovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **entire margins** and **3–7 prominent parallel veins**. Leaves are sessile, smooth, dark green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense terminal and upper axillary clusters**. Individual flowers are **bottle-shaped**, 3–4 cm long, **deep blue to violet**, with petals that remain **closed or nearly closed** at the tip—the flower never opens fully. The closed form requires strong pollinators like bumblebees to force entry. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **capsule** containing winged seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**G. andrewsii** is identified by its **deep blue, closed bottle-shaped flowers** and **opposite leaves with prominent veins**. Distinguished from **G. clausa** (closed gentian) by minor technical features. One of the latest-blooming native wildflowers. The intense blue is remarkable in the autumn landscape. Increasingly rare due to habitat loss.

**Geranium carolinianum**, commonly known as Carolina cranesbill or Carolina geranium, is an **annual or biennial herb** in the **Geraniaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **dry fields, roadsides, waste places, and disturbed areas**, a common weedy species.

**Growth habit**  
A spreading to erect herb, 15–50 cm tall, with branching stems covered in spreading hairs. Plants often form bushy mounds.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite to alternate**, **palmately 5–7 lobed**, 3–7 cm across, with each lobe further divided into narrow segments, creating a finely dissected appearance. Leaves are hairy on both surfaces. Basal leaves are long-petioled; stem leaves are short-petioled.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **compact, terminal clusters** of 2–several. Individual flowers are small, 8–12 mm across, with **5 pale pink to whitish petals** (sometimes with darker veins), notched at the tip. Blooms spring to early summer (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is the characteristic "cranesbill"—a **long-beaked schizocarp** 2–2.5 cm long that splits into 5 segments, each coiling upward and flinging the seed.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by the coiling mericarp mechanism.

**Morphology**  
**G. carolinianum** is identified by its **finely divided palmate leaves**, **small pale pink flowers in clusters**, and **cranesbill fruit**. Distinguished from **G. maculatum** (wild geranium) by smaller flowers and more finely divided leaves. A common weedy species—the first to bloom of the cranesbills.

**Geum aleppicum**, commonly known as yellow avens, is a **perennial herb** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to northern North America and Eurasia, this species inhabits **moist meadows, thickets, stream banks, and open woods**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 50–120 cm tall, with branching, hairy stems arising from a stout rhizome. Plants are coarse-textured.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **pinnately compound** with a **large terminal leaflet** and several smaller lateral leaflets, 10–30 cm long. The terminal leaflet is **broadly kidney-shaped to round**, 5–15 cm wide, coarsely toothed and often shallowly lobed. Stem leaves are **alternate**, smaller, often trifoliate or simple. Leaves are hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **open, terminal clusters**. Individual flowers are 10–15 mm across, with **5 yellow petals** that are broadly spreading. Sepals are reflexed. Blooms late spring to summer (May–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a cluster of **achenes**, each tipped with a **hooked style** that forms a bur, clinging to fur and clothing.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed by clinging to animals.

**Morphology**  
**G. aleppicum** is identified by its **yellow flowers**, **pinnate basal leaves with large terminal leaflet**, and **bur-like fruit cluster**. Distinguished from **G. canadense** (white avens) by yellow (not white) flowers. The hooked fruits are effective hitchhikers. Common in disturbed, moist habitats.

**Glyceria canadensis**, commonly known as rattlesnake mannagrass, is a **perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **swamps, marshes, wet meadows, and stream margins**, often standing in shallow water.

**Growth habit**  
A loosely tufted grass, 60–150 cm tall, with erect to arching culms arising from short rhizomes. Plants are graceful in appearance.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–30 cm long, 6–12 mm wide, flat, rough on margins. Sheaths are smooth, often closed most of their length. Ligule is membranous, prominent.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is an **open, drooping panicle**, 15–30 cm long, with spreading to reflexed branches bearing spikelets at the tips. Spikelets are distinctive: **ovate, inflated**, 5–8 mm long, resembling rattlesnake rattles, containing 5–12 florets. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis**.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**G. canadensis** is identified by its **open, nodding panicle** and **distinctive ovate, inflated spikelets** that suggest rattles. The "rattlesnake" name refers to the spikelet shape. An attractive native wetland grass. Provides food for waterfowl. The genus name means "sweet grass"—the grains are palatable.

**Helianthus angustifolius**, commonly known as swamp sunflower or narrowleaf sunflower, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, swamp edges, ditches, and moist pinelands**, often in acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
A tall, erect herb, 100–200 cm tall, with slender stems that are rough-hairy. Spreads by rhizomes to form colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear to narrowly lanceolate**, 10–20 cm long, only 0.5–2 cm wide—very narrow for a sunflower (hence "angustifolius"). Leaves are **stiff, rough**, with entire to slightly wavy margins, often with revolute (rolled-under) edges.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in **loose, open clusters** at stem tips. Heads are 5–8 cm across, with **10–20 bright yellow ray florets** and a **dark purple to brown disk**. The dark disk is distinctive. Blooms fall (September–November)—later than most sunflowers.

**Fruit**  
Achenes are 3–4 mm long with a pappus of 2 scales.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed by wind and gravity.

**Morphology**  
**H. angustifolius** is identified by its **very narrow leaves**, **dark-centered flower heads**, **late fall bloom**, and **wet habitat preference**. One of the showiest fall wildflowers for wet sites. Excellent for rain gardens and wet meadow restorations. Spreads readily by rhizomes.

**Hepatica acutiloba**, commonly known as sharp-lobed hepatica or acute-lobed liverleaf, is a **spring ephemeral perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often in calcareous soils.

**Growth habit**  
A low herb, 10–20 cm tall, with basal leaves and flowers on separate hairy stalks arising from a short rhizome. Plants are long-lived and form small clumps.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **3-lobed**, 4–8 cm wide, with **pointed (acute) lobe tips**—the key distinguishing feature. Leaves are leathery, overwintering (new leaves emerge after flowering), often mottled with purple beneath. The liver-like leaf shape gives the plant the name.

**Flowers**  
Flowers appear **before new leaves** in early spring, each solitary on a hairy scape. Flowers are 1.5–2.5 cm across, with **5–12 petal-like sepals** (true petals absent) in **white, pink, lavender, or blue**. Three green bracts sit just below the flower. Blooms very early spring (March–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a cluster of **hairy achenes**.

**Seeds**  
Achenes may be dispersed by ants.

**Morphology**  
**H. acutiloba** is identified by its **3-lobed leaves with pointed tips**, **early flowering before new leaves**, and **variable flower color**. Distinguished from **H. americana** (round-lobed hepatica) by pointed vs. rounded lobe tips. One of the earliest spring wildflowers. Note: Some authorities merge both into H. nobilis var. acuta.

**Heuchera americana**, commonly known as American alumroot, is a **perennial herb** in the **Saxifragaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rocky woods, shaded cliffs, and forest slopes**, often in well-drained, acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
A clump-forming herb, 30–90 cm tall when in flower, with basal leaves and tall, slender flowering stalks. Plants arise from a scaly rhizome.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **long-petioled**, **broadly heart-shaped to rounded**, 5–12 cm wide, with **5–7 shallow, rounded lobes** and **crenate margins**. Leaves are often **mottled or veined with purple or silver**—ornamentally variable. Leaves are semi-evergreen.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne on **tall, slender panicles** 30–60 cm tall, with tiny, inconspicuous flowers. Individual flowers are 3–5 mm long, with **5 greenish to purplish sepals** and **5 minute petals** (petals often absent). Stamens protrude. Blooms spring to early summer (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **2-beaked capsule** containing many tiny seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are minute; dispersed by gravity and water.

**Morphology**  
**H. americana** is identified by its **rounded, lobed basal leaves** (often mottled), **tall, airy flower panicles**, and **tiny greenish flowers**. The genus Heuchera is the source of the popular "coral bells" garden plants—most cultivars are hybrids involving this and related species. Native plants are less showy but valuable for woodland gardens.

**Hibiscus coccineus**, commonly known as scarlet rosemallow or Texas star, is a **tall perennial herb** in the **Malvaceae** family. Native to the southeastern United States, this species inhabits **swamps, marshes, and wet ditches**, often standing in shallow water.

**Growth habit**  
A robust, upright herb, 100–300 cm tall, with stout, smooth stems arising from a woody rootstock. Plants die back to the ground in winter and resprout vigorously in spring.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately divided into 5–7 narrow, lanceolate lobes**, 10–20 cm across, resembling cannabis leaves superficially. Lobes are **coarsely serrate**. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary** in upper leaf axils, spectacular: 15–20 cm across, with **5 deep crimson-red petals** spreading flat. Petals are broad, overlapping. The central **staminal column** is long, prominent, bearing numerous stamens and a 5-branched stigma. Blooms summer to fall (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **5-celled capsule**, 2–3 cm long, containing several seeds per cell.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are kidney-shaped, hairy; dispersed when capsule dehisces.

**Morphology**  
**H. coccineus** is identified by its **deeply palmately lobed leaves** and **large, brilliant red flowers**. Distinguished from **H. moscheutos** (swamp rosemallow) by the deeply divided (not merely lobed) leaves. One of the showiest native wetland plants. Excellent for rain gardens and pond edges. Hardy to Zone 6.

**Hieracium murorum**, commonly known as wall hawkweed, is a **perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in parts of North America in **rocky woods, walls, cliffs, and shaded banks**.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted herb, 20–60 cm tall, with a basal rosette of leaves and one or few erect, hairy flowering stems. Plants exude milky sap when cut.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **elliptic to ovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **coarsely toothed to shallowly lobed margins**, often **purplish-blotched** at the base, hairy on both surfaces. Stem leaves are **absent or 1–2**, much reduced.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne in a **loose, open cluster** (cyme) of 2–12 heads at the stem apex. Each head is 2–3 cm across, with **all ray florets** (no disk florets), **yellow**, strap-shaped with 5 teeth at the tip. Involucral bracts are dark green to blackish, glandular-hairy. Blooms late spring to summer (May–August).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are cylindrical, ribbed, 2–3 mm long, with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**H. murorum** is identified by its **basal rosette of hairy, often purple-blotched leaves**, **few or no stem leaves**, and **yellow dandelion-like flower heads**. Hieracium is a notoriously complex genus with hundreds of microspecies due to apomixis (asexual seed production). Distinguished from other hawkweeds by leaf and bract characters.

**Hydrocotyle americana**, commonly known as American marshpennywort, is a **low, creeping perennial herb** in the **Araliaceae** family (formerly Apiaceae). Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, stream banks, marshes, and moist woods**, often in shallow water.

**Growth habit**  
A low, mat-forming herb, 5–15 cm tall, spreading by slender, creeping stems that root at the nodes. Plants form loose patches in wet areas.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, on long petioles attached to the center of the blade (**peltate**), **round to kidney-shaped**, 2–5 cm across, with **shallowly crenate margins**. Leaves are thin, bright green, often glossy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **small, inconspicuous umbels** at the nodes, often hidden below the leaves. Individual flowers are tiny, **greenish-white**, 5-petaled. Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, flattened schizocarp**, 1–2 mm across, splitting into 2 mericarps.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**H. americana** is identified by its **round, peltate leaves** (petiole attached at center), **creeping habit**, and **wet habitat**. Distinguished from **H. umbellata** (many-flowered marshpennywort) which has larger umbels and more southern distribution. The peltate leaves are distinctive—like tiny lily pads. An easily overlooked but charming wetland plant.

**Hypericum androsaemum**, commonly known as tutsan or sweet-amber, is a **semi-evergreen shrub** in the **Hypericaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is cultivated as an ornamental and occasionally escapes to **moist, shaded areas and woodland edges** in parts of North America.

**Growth habit**  
A small, rounded shrub, 60–100 cm tall, with arching branches. Stems are 2-edged when young. Plants are semi-evergreen, retaining some leaves through mild winters.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **sessile**, **broadly ovate**, 5–10 cm long, with **entire margins** and a **heart-shaped, clasping base**. Leaves are aromatic when crushed, dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **few-flowered terminal cymes**. Individual flowers are 1.5–2.5 cm across, with **5 yellow petals** and numerous **prominent stamens** in bundles. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a distinctive **fleshy berry-like capsule**, 8–10 mm across, changing from **red to purplish-black** as the capsule matures—unusual for Hypericum, which typically has dry capsules.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are small; dispersed by birds eating the fleshy fruit.

**Morphology**  
**H. androsaemum** is identified by its **shrubby habit**, **large clasping leaves**, **yellow flowers**, and **berry-like fruit** that turns dark. Distinguished from **H. perforatum** (common St. Johns wort) by shrubby form and fleshy fruit. The fruit is ornamentally attractive. Considered invasive in some Pacific coastal areas.

**Ipomoea cordatotriloba**, commonly known as tievine or cotton morning glory, is an **annual or perennial vine** in the **Convolvulaceae** family. Native to the southeastern United States and tropical Americas, this species inhabits **fields, roadsides, disturbed areas, and agricultural land**, often as a weed.

**Growth habit**  
A twining vine reaching 1–3 meters, with slender, hairy stems. Plants climb on vegetation or trail along the ground. In mild climates, perennial from the root.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **variable in shape**: **heart-shaped (cordate)** to **deeply 3-lobed**, 3–8 cm long and wide, hence cordatotriloba. Leaves are hairy, dark green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne **singly or in few-flowered clusters** from leaf axils. Individual flowers are **funnel-shaped**, 1.5–2.5 cm long, **pink to rose-purple** with a darker center. Blooms late summer to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round capsule**, 6–8 mm across, containing 4 seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dark, hairy; dispersed when capsule opens.

**Morphology**  
**I. cordatotriloba** is identified by its **variable leaf shape** (heart-shaped to 3-lobed, often on the same plant), **small pink-purple funnel flowers**, and **hairy stems**. A common agricultural weed in cotton fields—hence cotton morning glory. Distinguished from **I. hederacea** (ivy-leaved morning glory) by smaller flowers and leaf shape variation.

**Jeffersonia diphylla**, commonly known as twinleaf, is a **spring-blooming perennial herb** in the **Berberidaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often in calcareous soils.

**Growth habit**  
A clump-forming herb, 15–45 cm tall, with basal leaves and leafless flowering stalks arising from a short, thick rhizome. Plants are slow-growing but long-lived.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **long-petioled**, with a blade **divided into 2 symmetrical halves** (appearing like butterfly wings)—the twinleaf feature is unique and unmistakable. Each half is 5–10 cm long, kidney-shaped, with **wavy to slightly lobed margins**. Leaves emerge reddish, maturing to blue-green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary**, on leafless scapes 15–25 cm tall, appearing **before or with emerging leaves**. Flowers are 2.5–3 cm across, with **8 white petals** (delicate, falling quickly), numerous stamens. Blooms very early spring (April–May)—flowers last only 1–2 days.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a distinctive **leathery, pear-shaped capsule** with a **hinged lid** that opens horizontally near the top, like a covered cup.

**Seeds**  
Seeds have a fleshy appendage (aril); dispersed by ants (myrmecochory).

**Morphology**  
**J. diphylla** is identified by its **uniquely twin-lobed leaves** and **hinged-lid fruit capsule**. Named for Thomas Jefferson. The ephemeral white flowers are beautiful but brief. A treasured native wildflower for woodland gardens. Slow to establish but worth the wait.

**Juncus articulatus**, commonly known as jointed rush, is a **perennial rush** in the **Juncaceae** family. Native to North America and Eurasia, this species inhabits **wet meadows, stream margins, pond edges, and ditches**, often in shallow standing water.

**Growth habit**  
A clump-forming rush, 20–60 cm tall, with erect, cylindrical stems arising from creeping rhizomes. Plants form loose to dense colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal and cauline**, **cylindrical** (terete), **conspicuously septate** (cross-partitioned internally, visible as nodes when held to light)—the jointed appearance. Leaves are dark green, hollow between septa.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **branched, terminal clusters** (cymes) with spreading branches. Individual flowers are small, 2–3 mm long, with **6 tepals** that are **dark brown to blackish**, lance-shaped, acute. Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **dark brown capsule**, about as long as the tepals, 3-celled, containing many seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are tiny, dispersed by water and wind.

**Morphology**  
**J. articulatus** is identified by its **cylindrical, septate (jointed) leaves**, **dark brown flowers in branched clusters**, and **wet habitat**. Distinguished from **J. effusus** (soft rush) which has continuous (not septate) stems. The visible cross-partitions in the leaves are diagnostic. Common in wetlands across temperate regions.

**Juniperus communis**, commonly known as common juniper, is an **evergreen shrub or small tree** in the **Cupressaceae** family. Native across the Northern Hemisphere (North America, Europe, Asia), this species inhabits **dry, rocky areas, open woods, and barrens**, often in poor, acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
Highly variable: a low, spreading shrub 0.5–2 m tall in exposed sites, or an upright shrub to small tree up to 10 m in sheltered locations. Bark is reddish-brown, shreddy.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **needle-like**, **sharp-pointed**, 8–15 mm long, arranged in **whorls of 3**, spreading at right angles to the stem. Needles have a **single white stomatal band** on the upper surface (appearing as a white stripe). Needles are prickly to the touch.

**Flowers**  
Plants are **dioecious**. Male cones are small, yellow, shedding pollen in spring. Female cones are tiny, green.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **fleshy, berry-like cone**, 6–10 mm across, **blue-black** with a waxy bloom, taking **2–3 years to mature**. The juniper berry is actually a modified cone with fused, fleshy scales.

**Seeds**  
Cones contain 1–3 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**J. communis** is identified by its **needle-like leaves in whorls of 3 with white stripe above**, and **blue-black berry-like cones**. Distinguished from **J. virginiana** (eastern red cedar) which has scale-like adult leaves. The berries flavor gin. The most widespread conifer species in the world.

**Kalmia angustifolia**, commonly known as sheep laurel or lambkill, is an **evergreen shrub** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **bogs, acidic barrens, wet meadows, and pine-oak forests**, often in poor, acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading shrub, 30–100 cm tall, with slender stems arising from a spreading root system. Plants often form dense colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite or whorled in 3s**, **elliptic to oblong**, 2–6 cm long, with **entire margins** that are often **rolled under (revolute)**. Leaves are **leathery, evergreen**, dark green above, paler beneath. New leaves appear at stem tips; flowers appear below them on older growth.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **clusters around the stem** (lateral, not terminal), below the current years leaves. Individual flowers are **saucer-shaped**, 8–12 mm across, **pink to rose-purple** with darker spots, with 10 stamens tucked into pouches in the petals. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, dry capsule**, 3–5 mm across, persisting through winter.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are minute, dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**  
**K. angustifolia** is identified by its **narrow, whorled or opposite evergreen leaves**, **lateral flower clusters** (below the new leaves), and **pink spotted flowers**. Distinguished from **K. latifolia** (mountain laurel) by smaller size, narrower leaves, and lateral (not terminal) flower position. **ALL PARTS ARE HIGHLY TOXIC** to livestock and humans—hence lambkill. Beautiful but deadly.

**Lactuca biennis**, commonly known as tall blue lettuce, is a **biennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, thickets, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A tall, erect biennial, 100–300 cm tall, with stout, smooth, often glaucous stems. First-year plants form a basal rosette; second-year plants bolt and flower. All parts exude milky sap when cut.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **large, deeply pinnately lobed**, 15–40 cm long, with a large terminal lobe. Stem leaves are **alternate**, becoming smaller and less lobed upward, often **clasping with auriculate bases**. Leaves are blue-green.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are **numerous**, borne in a large, branched **panicle**. Each head is small, 1–1.5 cm across, with **15–30 ray florets only** (no disk), **pale blue to whitish** (occasionally yellowish). Blooms summer to fall (July–October).

**Fruit**  
Achenes are flattened, beaked, 4–5 mm long, with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**  
**L. biennis** is identified by its **tall stature**, **milky sap**, **pinnately lobed lower leaves**, and **pale blue flower heads in large panicles**. Distinguished from **L. canadensis** (wild lettuce) which has yellow flowers. The genus Lactuca includes cultivated lettuce (L. sativa). A stately native plant often overlooked.

**Lamium amplexicaule**, commonly known as henbit or henbit deadnettle, is a **winter annual herb** in the **Lamiaceae** family. Native to Europe and Asia, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, gardens, fields, and disturbed areas**—one of the earliest spring-flowering weeds.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading to ascending herb, 10–40 cm tall, with square stems that are often branched at the base. Plants germinate in fall, overwinter as rosettes, and flower early spring.

**Leaves**  
Lower leaves are **opposite**, **long-petioled**, **rounded to kidney-shaped**, 1–3 cm across, with **crenate margins**. Upper leaves are **sessile, clasping the stem** (amplexicaule = stem-clasping), often appearing to surround the stem in tiers.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **whorls in the axils of upper leaves**. Individual flowers are **2-lipped**, 12–18 mm long, **pink to purple** with darker spots on the lower lip. The tube is long and slender. Blooms late winter to spring (February–May), and again in fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **4 nutlets** at the base of the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**L. amplexicaule** is identified by its **sessile, clasping upper leaves**, **square stems**, and **pink tubular flowers**. Distinguished from **L. purpureum** (purple deadnettle) which has all leaves petioled, not clasping. One of the first flowers to bloom in late winter—important early nectar source. Edible but not flavorful.

**Leersia oryzoides**, commonly known as rice cutgrass, is a **perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America and Eurasia, this species inhabits **marshes, stream margins, wet meadows, and ditches**, often in standing water.

**Growth habit**  
A spreading grass, 60–150 cm tall, with weak, often sprawling culms that root at the nodes. Spreads by scaly rhizomes to form dense colonies. Plants lean on other vegetation for support.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 10–25 cm long, 8–15 mm wide, flat, rough on margins and surfaces—**sharply cutting** to the touch (hence cutgrass). Sheaths are also rough. Ligule is membranous, short.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is an **open panicle**, 10–20 cm long, with spreading branches. Spikelets are **strongly flattened**, 4–6 mm long, **single-flowered**, arranged along one side of the branches, resembling rice spikelets. Lemmas are **fringed with stiff hairs**. Blooms late summer to fall. Often produces **cleistogamous** (self-fertilizing, never-opening) spikelets within the sheath.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed by water and by clinging to fur via the rough hairs.

**Morphology**  
**L. oryzoides** is identified by its **rice-like flattened spikelets**, **rough, cutting leaves**, and **wet habitat**. Related to cultivated rice (Oryza). The leaves can cause cuts—handle carefully. Important waterfowl food. Valuable for wetland restoration.

**Lespedeza bicolor**, commonly known as shrub lespedeza or bicolor lespedeza, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species was introduced for erosion control and wildlife food, and has become **invasive** in parts of eastern North America.

**Growth habit**  
A multi-stemmed shrub, 1–3 meters tall, with arching branches. Plants spread by seed and root sprouts to form dense thickets.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **elliptic to obovate**, 2–5 cm long, with **entire margins** and blunt to notched tips. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **loose, drooping racemes** 5–15 cm long from leaf axils. Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 10–12 mm long, **rose-purple to magenta** with darker veins. Blooms summer to fall (July–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, flat pod** (legume), 6–8 mm long, containing one seed.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are hard-coated, long-lived in soil; dispersed by birds and gravity.

**Morphology**  
**L. bicolor** is identified by its **shrubby habit**, **trifoliate leaves**, and **drooping racemes of rose-purple flowers**. Distinguished from native bush clovers by larger size and showier flowers. **INVASIVE** in many areas—forms dense stands that exclude native plants. Avoid planting; control existing populations.

**Leucothoe fontanesiana**, commonly known as highland doghobble or drooping leucothoe, is an **evergreen shrub** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to the southern Appalachian Mountains, this species inhabits **moist, acidic forests, stream banks, and mountain slopes**.

**Growth habit**  
An arching, evergreen shrub, 1–2 meters tall, with gracefully drooping branches. Spreads by underground stems to form colonies.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate**, 7–15 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and a pointed tip. Leaves are **leathery, glossy, evergreen**, dark green above, paler beneath. New growth is often **bronze to reddish**. Winter foliage may turn purplish.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **drooping axillary racemes** 5–10 cm long along the arching stems. Individual flowers are **urn-shaped** (urceolate), 6–8 mm long, **white**, waxy. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, dry capsule**, 5-lobed, brown, persisting through winter.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are tiny, numerous; dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**  
**L. fontanesiana** is identified by its **gracefully arching branches**, **glossy evergreen lanceolate leaves**, and **drooping racemes of white urn-shaped flowers**. A popular ornamental shrub for shaded, acidic sites. Doghobble refers to the dense thickets that could impede dogs (and people). Related to and sometimes confused with Agarista (formerly Leucothoe) populifolia.

**Lilium canadense**, commonly known as Canada lily or meadow lily, is a **bulbous perennial herb** in the **Liliaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, wet prairies, and stream banks**, one of the most elegant native lilies.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 60–150 cm tall, with a single, unbranched stem arising from a scaly bulb with rhizome-like stolons. Plants may form loose colonies over time.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **whorled** (3–12 per whorl), occasionally some alternate above, **lanceolate**, 7–15 cm long, with **parallel veins** and **smooth margins**. Leaves are bright green, smooth beneath.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **terminal cluster** of 1–16 (usually 3–8) **nodding flowers**. Individual flowers are **bell-shaped**, 5–8 cm long, with **6 tepals** curving outward but not strongly reflexed. Color ranges from **yellow to orange to red**, typically spotted with dark purplish-brown inside. Blooms early to mid summer (June–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **erect, oblong capsule**, 3–5 cm long, containing stacked, flat seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are flat, papery; wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**L. canadense** is identified by its **whorled leaves** and **nodding, bell-shaped flowers** (not strongly recurved like Turks cap lily). Distinguished from **L. superbum** (Turks cap lily) by less reflexed tepals and generally shorter stature. A graceful meadow lily, increasingly rare due to habitat loss. Deer frequently browse the foliage.

**Liparis liliifolia**, commonly known as large twayblade or lily-leaved twayblade, is a **terrestrial orchid** in the **Orchidaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist, rich deciduous forests and wooded slopes**, often in humus-rich soil.

**Growth habit**  
A perennial herb, 10–25 cm tall, arising from a small **pseudobulb** (corm-like structure). Plants are inconspicuous and easily overlooked.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **2, basal**, **broadly elliptic to ovate**, 5–15 cm long, **glossy, pale green**, with prominent parallel veins and a somewhat keeled appearance. The two leaves arise from the pseudobulb base.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **loose terminal raceme** of 5–31 flowers on a smooth stalk exceeding the leaves. Individual flowers are 1.5–2 cm across, with **narrow, thread-like lateral petals** (greenish to purplish) and a **broad, wedge-shaped lip** that is **translucent mauve to purple**, often with darker veins. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is an **ellipsoid capsule**, erect, containing thousands of dust-like seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are microscopic; require mycorrhizal fungi for germination.

**Morphology**  
**L. liliifolia** is identified by its **2 broad, glossy basal leaves** and **raceme of flowers with a broad mauve lip and thread-like petals**. Distinguished from **L. loeselii** (yellow twayblade) which has yellow-green flowers. An understated but intriguing native orchid. Populations are declining in many areas.

**Lolium arundinaceum** (syn. **Festuca arundinacea**, **Schedonorus arundinaceus**), commonly known as tall fescue, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized and cultivated in North America for **pastures, lawns, roadsides, and erosion control**.

**Growth habit**  
A robust bunchgrass, 60–120 cm tall, forming dense clumps from a fibrous root system. Plants are deep-rooted and drought-tolerant. Does not spread by rhizomes.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–40 cm long, 5–10 mm wide, flat, with **rough margins** and **prominent ribs** on the upper surface. Leaves are dark green, tough. Auricles are small, claw-like.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **narrow, erect panicle**, 10–25 cm long, with short, appressed branches bearing spikelets. Spikelets are 10–15 mm long, containing 4–8 florets. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **caryopsis** adhering to the lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**L. arundinaceum** is identified by its **coarse, bunchgrass habit**, **rough-margined leaves**, and **narrow panicle**. Most pasture tall fescue is infected with an endophytic fungus (Epichloe coenophiala) that confers stress tolerance but can cause fescue toxicosis in livestock. Important turf grass for tough sites but can dominate at the expense of natives.

**Ludwigia palustris**, commonly known as marsh seedbox or water purslane, is a **creeping to floating perennial herb** in the **Onagraceae** family. Native to North America and other continents, this species inhabits **shallow water, muddy shores, marshes, and ditches**.

**Growth habit**  
A low, mat-forming herb, with stems 10–50 cm long, creeping on mud or floating in shallow water, rooting at the nodes. Stems often reddish, smooth to slightly hairy.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **elliptic to spatulate**, 1–4 cm long, with **entire margins** and tapered bases forming a short petiole. Leaves are bright green to reddish, smooth.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary in leaf axils**, small, inconspicuous, **sessile**. Flowers have **4 sepals** but **no petals** (apetalous)—unusual in the genus. Stamens are 4. Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, 4-angled capsule**, 3–5 mm long, green to brownish.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are tiny, dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**L. palustris** is identified by its **creeping habit**, **opposite elliptic leaves**, and **small, petalless flowers in leaf axils**. Distinguished from other Ludwigia species by the lack of petals. Often overlooked as the plant lacks showy flowers. Common in muddy areas that dry out seasonally. Taxonomically, one of the most widespread Ludwigia species.

**Lupinus perennis**, commonly known as wild lupine or sundial lupine, is a **perennial herb** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry, sandy prairies, open woods, and roadsides**, often in acidic, nutrient-poor soils.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, with stems arising from a deep taproot and woody crown. Plants are often short-lived perennials.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately compound** with **7–11 leaflets** radiating from a central point like spokes. Leaflets are **oblanceolate**, 2–5 cm long, with entire margins, softly hairy beneath. Leaves fold upward at night and on cloudy days (sundial lupine).

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **showy, terminal raceme** 10–25 cm long. Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 12–16 mm long, **blue to violet** (rarely pink or white), with an erect banner petal. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **hairy, flat pod** (legume), 3–5 cm long, containing 4–6 seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are hard, mottled; dispersed when pods split explosively.

**Morphology**  
**L. perennis** is identified by its **palmately compound leaves** (7–11 leaflets) and **tall racemes of blue pea-like flowers**. The **only lupine native to eastern North America**. Critically important as the **sole host plant for the endangered Karner blue butterfly** (Lycaeides melissa samuelis). Restoration of wild lupine is essential for butterfly conservation.

**Luzula campestris**, commonly known as field woodrush or sweeps brush, is a **perennial rush-like plant** in the **Juncaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, meadows, roadsides, and open woods**, often in acidic soils.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted, grass-like herb, 10–30 cm tall, forming small clumps. Plants spread slowly by short stolons.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal and cauline**, **linear**, grass-like, 3–10 mm wide, flat, with **long, white, silky hairs along the margins** (ciliate)—a key identifier distinguishing woodrushes from true rushes and grasses. Leaves are bright green.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **cluster of rounded heads** (spikes) on unequal branches, with 1 sessile central head and several stalked lateral heads. Individual flowers are small, 3–4 mm long, with **6 brownish tepals**. Blooms early spring (March–May)—one of the earliest spring bloomers.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **3-celled capsule**, about as long as the tepals.

**Seeds**  
Seeds have a fleshy appendage (caruncle); dispersed by ants.

**Morphology**  
**L. campestris** is identified by its **grass-like leaves with long marginal hairs**, **clustered rounded flower heads**, and **early spring bloom**. Distinguished from true rushes (Juncus) by hairy leaves and from grasses by 6-parted flowers. Often overlooked in lawns. The genus name Luzula comes from Italian lucciola (glow-worm), possibly referring to dew-covered plants.

**Lysimachia arvensis** (syn. **Anagallis arvensis**), commonly known as scarlet pimpernel or poor mans weatherglass, is an **annual herb** in the **Primulaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **gardens, fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading annual, 10–30 cm tall, with weak, square, branching stems that often trail along the ground. Plants are delicate in appearance.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **sessile**, **ovate to elliptic**, 1–2 cm long, with **entire margins** and **black dots** on the underside (visible with a hand lens). Leaves are bright green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary** in leaf axils on slender stalks. Individual flowers are 8–12 mm across, with **5 petals** that are **salmon-orange to brick-red** (rarely blue), fringed with tiny glandular hairs. Flowers open only in sunshine and close by early afternoon or in cloudy weather—hence weatherglass. Blooms late spring to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **globose capsule** (pyxis), 4–5 mm across, with a cap that pops off to release seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are numerous, tiny, angular; dispersed when capsule opens.

**Morphology**  
**L. arvensis** is identified by its **salmon-red flowers** that close in cloudy weather, **opposite sessile leaves with black dots beneath**, and **trailing habit**. The blue-flowered form was once considered a separate species. Mildly toxic—not edible. A charming but weedy little plant.

**Malus baccata**, commonly known as Siberian crabapple, is a **small deciduous tree** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is widely cultivated as an ornamental and occasionally escapes to **roadsides, thickets, and woodland edges**.

**Growth habit**  
A small tree or large shrub, 5–15 meters tall, with a rounded, spreading crown. Branches may bear thorns on vigorous shoots. Bark is gray-brown, scaly on older trunks.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to ovate**, 3–8 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath, smooth on both surfaces.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **clusters of 4–8** on short spurs. Individual flowers are 3–4 cm across, with **5 white petals** (pink in bud), fragrant, appearing before or with leaves. Stamens are numerous with yellow anthers. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small pome** (crabapple), 8–12 mm across, **red to yellow**, on a long, slender stalk. Fruit persists into winter, providing wildlife food.

**Seeds**  
Each pome contains several small seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**M. baccata** is identified by its **small red or yellow fruit** on long stalks, **white fragrant flowers**, and **thornless or nearly thornless branches**. One of the hardiest crabapples, used extensively in breeding ornamental cultivars. Distinguished from **M. coronaria** (native crabapple) by smaller fruit and Asian origin. Fruit is edible but tart—good for preserves.

**Malva alcea**, commonly known as hollyhock mallow or vervain mallow, is a **perennial herb** in the **Malvaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is cultivated as an ornamental and occasionally escapes to **roadsides, fields, and disturbed areas** in North America.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, bushy herb, 60–120 cm tall, with branching stems covered in star-shaped (stellate) hairs. Plants may be short-lived perennials.

**Leaves**  
Lower leaves are **alternate**, **palmately 5–7 lobed**, 5–10 cm across, with rounded lobes and **crenate margins**. Upper leaves are more deeply divided into narrow segments. Leaves are softly hairy, pale green.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne **singly or in small clusters** in upper leaf axils. Individual flowers are 3–5 cm across, with **5 notched petals** that are **pink to rose-purple** with darker veins. The central staminal column is typical of mallows. Blooms summer to fall (June–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **schizocarp** of 15–20 mericarps arranged in a ring, each containing one seed.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are kidney-shaped; dispersed when the schizocarp breaks apart.

**Morphology**  
**M. alcea** is identified by its **deeply lobed upper leaves**, **large pink flowers**, and **stellate pubescence**. Distinguished from **M. sylvestris** (common mallow) by more deeply divided leaves and stellate (not simple) hairs. A showy plant resembling small hollyhocks. Attractive to pollinators.

**Matricaria chamomilla** (syn. **M. recutita**), commonly known as German chamomile or wild chamomile, is an **annual herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is cultivated for herbal tea and escapes to **fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect, branching annual, 15–60 cm tall, with smooth, hairless stems. Plants are aromatic with a pleasant apple-like scent.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times pinnately dissected** into fine, thread-like segments, 2–8 cm long, giving a feathery appearance. Leaves are bright green, smooth.

**Flowers**  
Flower heads are borne on long stalks at branch tips. Each head is 1.5–2.5 cm across, with **10–20 white ray florets** (often reflexed downward at maturity) surrounding a **yellow, conical disk** that becomes hollow with age—the hollow receptacle distinguishes German from Roman chamomile. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**  
Achenes are tiny, curved, without pappus.

**Seeds**  
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**M. chamomilla** is identified by its **finely dissected, feathery leaves**, **daisy-like heads with reflexed white rays**, and **hollow, conical disk**. Distinguished from **Anthemis** species and Roman chamomile by the hollow receptacle. The dried flower heads make the familiar chamomile tea. Sweet apple fragrance when crushed.

**Medicago lupulina**, commonly known as black medick or hop clover, is an **annual or short-lived perennial herb** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to Eurasia, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
A low, spreading herb, 10–60 cm long, with trailing to ascending stems. Plants often grow prostrate in lawns.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **obovate**, 5–15 mm long, with **finely toothed margins** near the tip and often a tiny point (mucro) at the apex. Center leaflet is on a longer stalk than lateral leaflets. Stipules are small, pointed.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **dense, rounded heads** 3–8 mm across, containing 10–50 tiny flowers. Individual flowers are **bright yellow**, 2–3 mm long, pea-like. Blooms spring to fall (April–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **kidney-shaped pod**, 2–3 mm long, **black when mature** (hence black medick), coiled in a single spiral, containing one seed.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are small, hard; dispersed with the pod.

**Morphology**  
**M. lupulina** is identified by its **trifoliate leaves with toothed leaflet tips**, **small yellow flower heads**, and **black, kidney-shaped pods**. Distinguished from true clovers (Trifolium) by the coiled pod (not enclosed in calyx). Common lawn weed. Related to alfalfa (M. sativa). Fixes nitrogen.

**Melilotus albus**, commonly known as white sweet clover, is a **biennial herb** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to Eurasia, this species is widely naturalized in North America along **roadsides, fields, and disturbed areas**, often forming dense stands.

**Growth habit**  
A tall, erect biennial, 100–250 cm tall, with branching stems. First-year plants form a rosette; second-year plants bolt and flower. Plants have a distinctive sweet fragrance (coumarin) when dried.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **oblong to oblanceolate**, 1.5–2.5 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**. Stipules are bristle-like.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **elongate, spike-like racemes** 5–15 cm long. Individual flowers are small, 4–5 mm long, **white**, pea-like, fragrant. Blooms summer (June–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **small, ovoid pod**, 3–4 mm long, wrinkled, containing 1–2 seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are small, hard; dispersed when pod disintegrates.

**Morphology**  
**M. albus** is identified by its **tall stature**, **trifoliate leaves with serrate leaflets**, and **long racemes of small white flowers**. Distinguished from **M. officinalis** (yellow sweet clover) by white (not yellow) flowers. The coumarin content makes sweet clover valuable as a fragrant plant but dangerous as spoiled fodder—can convert to the anticoagulant dicoumarol. Fixes nitrogen.

**Monarda clinopodia**, commonly known as white bergamot or basil bee balm, is a **perennial herb** in the **Lamiaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist woods, thickets, and stream banks**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 50–100 cm tall, with square stems arising from a spreading rhizome. Plants are aromatic when crushed.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to lance-ovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **serrate margins**, pointed tips, and rounded to truncate bases. Leaves are thin-textured, light green, sparsely hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **terminal heads** 3–5 cm across, subtended by **whitish to pinkish bracts**. Individual flowers are **2-lipped**, 2–3 cm long, **whitish to pale pink** with purple spots on the lower lip. Upper lip is arched; lower lip is 3-lobed. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **4 nutlets** at the base of the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are small, smooth; dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**M. clinopodia** is identified by its **whitish to pale pink flowers** (not red or purple like most Monarda), **whitish bracts**, and **woodland habitat**.
