Distinguished from **M. fistulosa** (wild bergamot) by paler flowers and preference for shadier sites. Less commonly cultivated than red bee balms but equally attractive to pollinators.

**Morus alba**, commonly known as white mulberry, is a **medium-sized deciduous tree** in the **Moraceae** family. Native to China, this species was introduced for silk production and is now widely naturalized in North America in **disturbed areas, woodland edges, and urban lots**. Considered **invasive** in many regions.

**Growth habit**  
A medium tree, 10–20 meters tall, with a rounded, spreading crown. Bark is gray-brown, becoming furrowed with orange inner bark visible. Growth is rapid; trees produce abundant fruit and seedlings.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **highly variable in shape**: **ovate to deeply lobed** (often on the same tree), 5–15 cm long, with **serrate margins**. Leaves are glossy bright green above, smooth or slightly hairy beneath. Petioles exude milky sap when cut.

**Flowers**  
Plants are usually **dioecious** (sometimes monoecious). Male flowers in **drooping catkins** 2–4 cm long. Female flowers in shorter, denser spikes. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **multiple fruit** (like a blackberry), 1–2.5 cm long, **white, pink, or purplish-black** depending on variety, sweet when ripe. Fruit is edible.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by birds eating the fruit—this drives invasiveness.

**Morphology**  
**M. alba** is identified by its **variable leaf shape** (unlobed to deeply lobed), **glossy leaves**, and **white to purple multiple fruit**. Distinguished from **M. rubra** (native red mulberry) by glossy (not rough) leaf upper surface and often lighter-colored fruit. **INVASIVE**—spreads readily and hybridizes with native red mulberry, threatening the native species.

**Muhlenbergia capillaris**, commonly known as pink muhly grass or hairawn muhly, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to eastern and southern North America, this species inhabits **dry, sandy pinelands, prairies, and open woods**.

**Growth habit**  
A densely tufted bunchgrass, 60–100 cm tall, forming rounded clumps. Plants are long-lived and increase slowly in size.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **linear**, 30–60 cm long, very narrow (1–3 mm wide), wiry, often inrolled. Leaves are gray-green, turning tan in winter. The leaf mass forms a fountain-like mound.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **large, diffuse panicle**, 25–50 cm long, **spectacular pink to purplish-pink**, airy and cloud-like. Spikelets are tiny, 3–4 mm long, on hair-like (capillary) pedicels. Blooms fall (September–November)—one of the showiest native grass displays.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a tiny **caryopsis** enclosed in the lemma.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**  
**M. capillaris** is identified by its **spectacular pink, cloud-like panicle** in fall and **fine-textured, arching foliage**. One of the most ornamental native grasses. Increasingly popular in landscaping. The pink haze of flowering pink muhly in autumn is unmistakable. Drought-tolerant once established.

**Myosotis arvensis**, commonly known as field forget-me-not, is an **annual or biennial herb** in the **Boraginaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America in **fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect to spreading herb, 15–50 cm tall, with branching stems covered in spreading hairs. Plants are softly hairy throughout.

**Leaves**  
Basal leaves are **spatulate**, 2–5 cm long, forming a rosette. Stem leaves are **alternate**, **oblong to lanceolate**, sessile, smaller upward. All leaves are softly hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **scorpioid cymes** (coiled, unfurling as flowers open) at branch tips. Individual flowers are small, 3–5 mm across, with **5 sky-blue petals** (rarely white) and a **yellow eye** formed by scales in the throat. Blooms spring to summer (April–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit consists of **4 shiny, dark nutlets**, each 1.5–2 mm long, enclosed in the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**  
Nutlets are dispersed when calyx dries and opens.

**Morphology**  
**M. arvensis** is identified by its **small sky-blue flowers with yellow eye**, **coiled cymes**, and **hairy stems and leaves**. Distinguished from **M. scorpioides** (true forget-me-not) which is perennial and prefers wet habitats. The classic forget-me-not flowers. Weedy but charming.

**Nasturtium officinale**, commonly known as watercress, is a **perennial aquatic herb** in the **Brassicaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **springs, streams, and other cool, flowing waters**, also cultivated as a salad green.

**Growth habit**  
A succulent, semi-aquatic herb, with creeping stems 10–60 cm long, rooting at nodes, forming dense mats in shallow water. Stems are hollow, floating or emergent.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **3–9 rounded leaflets**, 1–3 cm long. The terminal leaflet is largest. Leaflets are entire to slightly wavy, dark green, succulent. Leaves have a peppery taste.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **short racemes** at stem tips. Individual flowers are small, 4–6 mm across, with **4 white petals** arranged in a cross. Blooms spring to fall (April–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **silique** (elongate pod), 1–2 cm long, curved, containing seeds in 2 rows.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are small, in 2 rows per silique half; dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**N. officinale** is identified by its **aquatic habitat**, **pinnate leaves with rounded leaflets**, **white cruciform flowers**, and **peppery taste**. A popular edible plant—leaves are used in salads and sandwiches. CAUTION: Only harvest from clean, flowing water; can harbor liver flukes if water is contaminated by livestock.

**Nuphar advena**, commonly known as spatterdock or yellow pond lily, is an **aquatic perennial herb** in the **Nymphaeaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **ponds, lakes, slow streams, and marshes**, rooted in muddy bottoms with leaves floating or emergent.

**Growth habit**  
An aquatic herb with thick, creeping rhizomes buried in the substrate. Leaves arise on long petioles from the rhizome, floating on or standing above the water surface.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **long-petioled**, **heart-shaped to oval**, 15–40 cm long, with a **deep, narrow sinus** (notch) at the base. Leaves are leathery, bright green above, often emergent above the water surface (distinguishing from Nymphaea).

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary**, on stout stalks held above the water, 3–5 cm across. Flowers are **cup-shaped**, with **5–6 thick, leathery, yellow sepals** (petals are reduced to small scales hidden within). The flower center is green, disc-like. Blooms late spring to summer (May–September).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **leathery, urn-shaped capsule**, green, 3–5 cm long, containing numerous seeds in a gelatinous matrix.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by water as the fruit disintegrates.

**Morphology**  
**N. advena** is identified by its **heart-shaped emergent leaves** and **cup-shaped yellow flowers** with thick sepals. Distinguished from **Nymphaea** (water lily) by emergent (not floating) leaves and cup-shaped (not flat-opened) flowers. Rhizomes and seeds were eaten by Indigenous peoples. Important wildlife habitat.

**Nymphaea mexicana**, commonly known as yellow water lily or banana water lily, is an **aquatic perennial herb** in the **Nymphaeaceae** family. Native to the southern United States and Mexico, this species inhabits **ponds, lakes, and slow streams**, often planted ornamentally and naturalized northward.

**Growth habit**  
An aquatic herb with rhizomes producing **banana-shaped tubers** at stolon tips. Leaves and flowers arise on long, flexible petioles from the rhizome.

**Leaves**  
Floating leaves are **nearly round**, 10–20 cm across, with a **narrow sinus** (notch) from the edge to the center where the petiole attaches. Leaves are green above, often **purplish-mottled beneath**, margins entire. Some submerged leaves may be present.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are **solitary**, floating or slightly elevated, 8–12 cm across, with **numerous yellow petals** (15–25) spreading flat, and **yellow stamens**. Flowers open during the day and close at night. Blooms spring to fall (April–October).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **spongy, berry-like capsule** ripening underwater and releasing seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed by water and by birds eating the fruit.

**Morphology**  
**N. mexicana** is identified by its **floating, round leaves** (often purple-mottled beneath), **bright yellow, many-petaled flowers**, and **banana-like tubers**. Distinguished from **Nuphar** (spatterdock) by flat-opening flowers with many petals (not cup-shaped with thick sepals). Popular water garden plant. Can become invasive in mild climates.

**Ornithogalum nutans**, commonly known as nodding star-of-Bethlehem, is a **bulbous perennial herb** in the **Asparagaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is cultivated as an ornamental and escapes to **lawns, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 30–50 cm tall, arising from a tunicate bulb. Plants form clumps and spread by bulb offsets.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **linear**, 20–40 cm long, 8–15 mm wide, with a **whitish midvein stripe** on the upper surface. Leaves are channeled, gray-green, often flopping over.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in a **one-sided raceme** of 5–15 flowers. Individual flowers are **nodding to horizontal**, 3–4 cm across, with **6 tepals** that are **silvery-white inside** with a **broad green stripe** down the back. Stamens have broad, flattened filaments. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **3-angled capsule** containing black seeds.

**Seeds**  
Seeds are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**  
**O. nutans** is identified by its **nodding flowers** with **green-striped backs**, **one-sided raceme**, and **white-striped leaves**. Distinguished from **O. umbellatum** (star-of-Bethlehem) which has upward-facing flowers in a corymb. Mildly toxic—all parts contain alkaloids. An elegant spring bulb.

**Osmorhiza longistylis**, commonly known as aniseroot or long-styled sweet cicely, is a **perennial herb** in the **Apiaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests and shaded slopes**.

**Growth habit**  
An erect herb, 40–100 cm tall, with branching stems arising from a thick, aromatic taproot. The root has a strong anise (licorice) fragrance.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times ternately compound**, 10–25 cm long, creating a lacy appearance. Leaflets are **ovate**, 3–8 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are bright green, sparsely hairy.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **compound umbels** with 3–6 rays. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, 5-petaled. Styles are **long, prominent**, exceeding the petals—hence longistylis. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **linear schizocarp**, 15–22 mm long, splitting into 2 bristly, club-shaped mericarps with a long, persistent style beak.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are dispersed by clinging to fur via the bristles.

**Morphology**  
**O. longistylis** is identified by its **anise-scented root**, **long styles visible in flower**, and **elongate, bristly fruit**. Distinguished from **O. claytonii** (bland sweet cicely) which lacks the anise scent and has shorter styles. The aromatic root was used as a flavoring. A characteristic plant of rich forests.

**Panicum capillare**, commonly known as witchgrass or old witch grass, is an **annual grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **fields, roadsides, gardens, and disturbed areas**—a common agricultural weed.

**Growth habit**  
A tufted annual, 20–80 cm tall, with branching stems that are often spreading at the base. Plants may be single or form bushy clumps.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 10–25 cm long, 8–15 mm wide, flat, conspicuously **hairy on both surfaces**. Sheaths are also densely hairy with spreading hairs. Ligule is a ring of hairs.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **large, diffuse panicle**, 15–40 cm long, comprising up to half the plant height, with spreading, hair-like branches. At maturity, the panicle breaks off and tumbles as a tumbleweed. Spikelets are tiny, 2–3 mm long, pointed, single-flowered. Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small, shiny **caryopsis** enclosed in the hardened lemma and palea.

**Seeds**  
Grains are dispersed as the panicle tumbles.

**Morphology**  
**P. capillare** is identified by its **large, diffuse, tumbling panicle**, **densely hairy leaves and sheaths**, and **weedy annual habit**. The panicle can be spectacular in size relative to the plant. A common weed of summer crops. The witchgrass name may refer to the tumbling habit or the hair-like panicle branches.

**Parthenocissus inserta**, commonly known as thicket creeper or woodbine, is a **deciduous woody vine** in the **Vitaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **thickets, woodland edges, and disturbed areas**, climbing trees and fences or trailing on the ground.

**Growth habit**  
A climbing or trailing vine reaching 5–20 meters, with tendrils that **lack adhesive disks** (or have very weak disks)—unlike Virginia creeper. Bark is tight, not shreddy.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately compound** with **(3–)5 leaflets**. Leaflets are **elliptic to obovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are dull green above, paler beneath. Fall color is red to purple.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are small, **greenish**, borne in **branched cymes** opposite the leaves. Blooms early summer (June–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **round berry**, 6–8 mm across, **dark blue** with a waxy bloom, in clusters on red stalks. Fruit ripens late summer to fall.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains 2–4 seeds; dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**  
**P. inserta** is identified by its **5-foliate leaves** and **tendrils without adhesive disks**. Distinguished from **P. quinquefolia** (Virginia creeper) which has tendrils with well-developed adhesive disks that cling firmly to surfaces. Thicket creeper relies more on twining and support than adhesion. Both have similar leaves and fruit. Often lumped with Virginia creeper but ecologically distinct.

**Paspalum dilatatum**, commonly known as dallisgrass, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to South America, this species is widely naturalized in warm regions of North America in **lawns, pastures, roadsides, and disturbed areas**—often considered a weed in turf.

**Growth habit**  
A coarse, clumping perennial, 50–150 cm tall, forming dense tufts from a knotty base. Plants spread slowly by short rhizomes.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 10–30 cm long, 6–12 mm wide, flat, with sparse hairs at the base. Sheaths are flattened, often purplish. Ligule is membranous.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence consists of **3–6 spreading racemes** arranged along the upper part of the culm, each raceme 5–12 cm long. Spikelets are **broadly elliptic**, 3–4 mm long, arranged in 4 rows along one side of the rachis, softly hairy, often with a fringe of silky hairs. Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the spikelet.

**Seeds**  
Spikelets are often infected with ergot fungus, appearing as black masses replacing the grain.

**Morphology**  
**P. dilatatum** is identified by its **spreading racemes** with **4 rows of silky, hairy spikelets**, and **coarse, clumping habit**. A problematic weed in warm-season lawns—difficult to control and unsightly. Ergot-infected seed heads are toxic to livestock. Provides forage in pastures where ergot is controlled.

**Pastinaca sativa**, commonly known as wild parsnip, is a **biennial herb** in the **Apiaceae** family. Native to Eurasia, this species is widely naturalized in North America along **roadsides, fields, and disturbed areas**. **CAUTION: Contact with sap causes severe burns in sunlight (phytophotodermatitis).**

**Growth habit**  
A biennial forming a basal rosette and taproot the first year; an erect, branching flowering stem 50–150 cm tall the second year. The taproot is the cultivated parsnip vegetable.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **5–15 leaflets**. Leaflets are **ovate to oblong**, 5–10 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins**, sometimes lobed. Leaves are yellowish-green, smooth.

**Flowers**  
Flowers are borne in **compound umbels** 10–20 cm across, with 15–25 rays. Individual flowers are tiny, **yellow**, 5-petaled. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a **flattened schizocarp**, oval, 5–8 mm long, splitting into 2 winged mericarps.

**Seeds**  
Mericarps are wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**  
**P. sativa** is identified by its **yellow flowers** (unusual in Apiaceae), **pinnate leaves with serrate leaflets**, and **grooved stem**. Distinguished from golden Alexanders (Zizia) by larger size and habitat. **SEVERE SKIN HAZARD**: The sap contains furanocoumarins that cause blistering burns when skin is exposed to sunlight. Wear protective clothing when handling. Invasive and spreading rapidly.

**Peltandra virginica**, commonly known as arrow arum or tuckahoe, is a **perennial aquatic herb** in the **Araceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **marshes, swamps, stream margins, and pond edges**, often growing in shallow water.

**Growth habit**  
A clump-forming herb, 30–90 cm tall, arising from a thick, starchy rhizome. Plants form dense colonies in favorable sites.

**Leaves**  
Leaves are **basal**, **long-petioled**, **sagittate (arrow-shaped)**, 15–45 cm long, with **pointed basal lobes** directed downward. Leaves are bright green, somewhat fleshy, with prominent parallel veins following the arrow shape.

**Flowers**  
Inflorescence is a **spadix** partially enclosed by a **green spathe**. Spathe is narrow, 10–20 cm long, green throughout (not white or colorful), with margins rolled inward. Spadix bears tiny male flowers above and female flowers below. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**  
Fruit is a cluster of **green to brownish berries** enclosed in the persistent spathe base, forming an elongate mass.

**Seeds**  
Each berry contains 1 large seed surrounded by gelatinous pulp; dispersed by water.

**Morphology**  
**P. virginica** is identified by its **arrow-shaped leaves** with downward-pointing basal lobes and **narrow green spathe**. Distinguished from **Arisaema** (jack-in-the-pulpit) by habitat (aquatic vs. woodland) and spathe shape. The starchy rhizome was historically eaten after extensive cooking to remove calcium oxalate crystals. Important wetland plant.

**Persicaria amphibia** (syn. **Polygonum amphibium**), commonly known as water smartweed or water knotweed, is a **perennial aquatic or terrestrial herb** in the **Polygonaceae** family. Native to North America and Eurasia, this species inhabits **ponds, lakes, marshes, and wet meadows**, displaying remarkable variation between aquatic and terrestrial forms.

**Growth habit**
Highly variable depending on habitat. Aquatic form: stems float on water surface, rooting at nodes, 30–100 cm long. Terrestrial form: erect stems 30–100 cm tall from creeping rhizomes. Plants can transition between forms as water levels change.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate to elliptic**, 5–15 cm long. Aquatic leaves are **floating, glossy, smooth, elliptic** with rounded bases. Terrestrial leaves are **narrower, hairy**, with pointed bases. Ocrea (sheath around stem) is present at each node.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, terminal, spike-like racemes** 2–5 cm long, held above water or foliage. Individual flowers are small, with **5 pink tepals**, showy in aggregate. Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **lens-shaped achene**, 2–3 mm long, dark brown, shiny.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed by water and waterfowl.

**Morphology**
**P. amphibia** is identified by its **pink flower spikes**, **dimorphic growth forms**, and **aquatic to wetland habitat**. The dramatic difference between floating and erect forms led early botanists to describe them as separate species. Important waterfowl food. One of the few truly amphibious flowering plants.

**Phalaris arundinacea**, commonly known as reed canary grass, is a **tall, rhizomatous perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Eurasia and possibly parts of North America (debated), this species inhabits **wetlands, stream banks, and moist meadows**. **Highly invasive** in many regions.

**Growth habit**
A robust grass, 60–200 cm tall, spreading aggressively by thick, scaly rhizomes to form dense, monotypic stands. Culms are stout, erect.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–35 cm long, 10–20 mm wide, flat, with **rough margins**. Leaves are blue-green, often with a whitish bloom. Ligule is membranous, prominent, 3–8 mm long.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence is a **dense, spike-like panicle**, 10–20 cm long, contracted but lobed, green to purplish, becoming straw-colored at maturity. Spikelets are single-flowered, 4–6 mm long. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** enclosed in the shiny lemma and palea.

**Seeds**
Grains are dispersed by water, contaminated soil, and machinery.

**Morphology**
**P. arundinacea** is identified by its **dense spike-like panicle**, **blue-green leaves**, and **aggressive rhizomatous spread**. **HIGHLY INVASIVE**—displaces native wetland vegetation, degrades wildlife habitat, and is extremely difficult to control. Variegated cultivars (ribbon grass) also escape and spread. Avoid planting any form.

**Physocarpus opulifolius**, commonly known as ninebark, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **stream banks, rocky slopes, and woodland edges**, often in moist to dry sites.

**Growth habit**
A multi-stemmed shrub, 1.5–3 meters tall, with arching branches. Bark is distinctive: **peeling in thin, papery layers** revealing multiple colors (tan, brown, orange)—the "nine barks" of the common name.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **palmately 3–5 lobed**, 4–8 cm long and wide, resembling maple or currant leaves. Lobes are **doubly serrate**. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath. Fall color is yellow to bronze.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, rounded corymbs** 3–5 cm across at branch tips. Individual flowers are small, 8–12 mm across, with **5 white to pinkish petals** and numerous stamens with pink to red anthers. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **3–5 inflated, reddish follicles** in a cluster, bladder-like, persistent and ornamental. Follicles split to release seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, shiny; dispersed when follicles open.

**Morphology**
**P. opulifolius** is identified by its **peeling, multi-layered bark**, **maple-like lobed leaves**, and **clusters of inflated reddish fruits**. Excellent native shrub for landscaping. Many cultivars exist, including purple-leaved forms like Diablo and Coppertina. Attracts pollinators.

**Picea abies**, commonly known as Norway spruce, is a **large evergreen conifer** in the **Pinaceae** family. Native to northern and central Europe, this species is widely planted in North America for **timber, windbreaks, and ornament**, occasionally naturalizing.

**Growth habit**
A large tree, 30–50 meters tall, with a **narrow, conical crown** and **drooping (pendulous) branchlets**—the classic "weeping" spruce silhouette. Bark is grayish-brown, scaly on older trees.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **needle-like**, 12–25 mm long, **4-sided** (quadrangular in cross-section), dark green, sharp-pointed, spirally arranged on the twigs. Needles persist 4–7 years.

**Flowers**
Plants are **monoecious**. Male cones are small, reddish, clustered, shedding pollen in spring. Female cones are initially erect, reddish-purple.

**Fruit**
Mature cones are **pendant**, **cylindrical**, **10–18 cm long**—the longest cones of any spruce. Cones are brown at maturity with thin, wavy-edged scales.

**Seeds**
Seeds are winged, 4–5 mm long; wind-dispersed when cones open.

**Morphology**
**P. abies** is identified by its **drooping branchlets**, **4-sided needles**, and **very long pendant cones**. Distinguished from native spruces by the pendulous branch habit and longer cones. The traditional Christmas tree of Europe. Susceptible to spruce budworm and other pests outside native range.

**Pilea pumila**, commonly known as clearweed or richweed, is an **annual herb** in the **Urticaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist, shaded woodlands, stream banks, and shaded disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An erect, succulent herb, 20–70 cm tall, with translucent, watery stems that are smooth and often branched. Plants are delicate in appearance. **Lacks stinging hairs** (unlike true nettles).

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to elliptic**, 5–15 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and **3 prominent veins** from the base. Leaves are thin, bright green, smooth, often somewhat translucent ("clearweed").

**Flowers**
Plants are **monoecious** (sometimes dioecious). Flowers are tiny, **greenish**, borne in **loose, axillary panicles** shorter than or equaling the leaves. Blooms summer to fall (July–October).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a tiny **achene**, 1–2 mm long, flattened, enclosed in the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**
**P. pumila** is identified by its **translucent, watery stems**, **opposite coarsely toothed leaves**, and **lack of stinging hairs**. Distinguished from **Boehmeria** (false nettle) by alternate vs. opposite leaf arrangement patterns and panicled vs. spike-like inflorescence. A common but often overlooked plant of shaded, moist sites.

**Pinus banksiana**, commonly known as jack pine, is a **small to medium evergreen conifer** in the **Pinaceae** family. Native to northern North America, this species inhabits **sandy, dry, nutrient-poor soils**, often forming pure stands after fire.

**Growth habit**
A small to medium tree, 10–25 meters tall, often with a **scraggly, irregular crown** and crooked trunk in harsh sites. Can be more symmetrical in favorable conditions. Bark is thin, reddish-brown to gray, scaly.

**Leaves**
Needles are in **bundles of 2**, **short** (2–5 cm), **twisted and spreading**, yellowish-green. Needles are the shortest of eastern pines.

**Flowers**
Plants are **monoecious**. Male cones are small, yellow, clustered at branch tips. Female cones are small, purplish when young.

**Fruit**
Cones are distinctive: **small (3–6 cm), curved, often asymmetrical**, pointing toward the branch tip, frequently **serotinous** (remaining closed for years until opened by fire heat). Cones may persist on the tree for many years.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, winged; released after fire or extreme heat.

**Morphology**
**P. banksiana** is identified by its **short, twisted needles in pairs**, **small, curved, serotinous cones**, and **scraggly growth habit**. A fire-adapted species—serotinous cones ensure regeneration after fire. Important for paper pulp. The Kirtland's warbler depends almost exclusively on young jack pine stands for nesting.

**Poa annua**, commonly known as annual bluegrass, is an **annual or short-lived perennial grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is now cosmopolitan in **lawns, paths, fields, and disturbed areas**—one of the most widespread plants on Earth.

**Growth habit**
A low, tufted annual, 5–30 cm tall, with weak, often spreading stems that may root at lower nodes. Plants are pale green, forming patches in lawns.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 2–10 cm long, 2–4 mm wide, flat, with **distinctly boat-shaped (prow-like) tips**. Leaves are bright green to yellowish-green. Ligule is membranous, prominent.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence is a **small, open, pyramidal panicle**, 2–8 cm long, with spreading branches. Spikelets are 3–6 mm long, containing 3–6 florets. Lemmas often have **cottony hairs at the base**. Blooms nearly year-round in mild climates.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a tiny **caryopsis**.

**Seeds**
Prolific seed producer; seeds germinate rapidly in cool, moist conditions.

**Morphology**
**P. annua** is identified by its **boat-shaped leaf tips**, **small open panicle**, **pale green color**, and **weedy habit**. The bane of turf managers—produces seed heads even at mowing height, disrupts lawn uniformity. Thrives in compacted, moist soil. Nearly impossible to eliminate from turf. Adapts to virtually any disturbed habitat.

**Podophyllum peltatum**, commonly known as mayapple or American mandrake, is a **colonial perennial herb** in the **Berberidaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests**, often forming extensive colonies.

**Growth habit**
A distinctive herb, 30–50 cm tall, arising from a long, creeping rhizome. Non-flowering stems produce **1 large umbrella-like leaf**; flowering stems produce **2 leaves** with a flower in the fork.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **peltate** (stalk attached to the center), **palmately 5–9 lobed**, 20–40 cm across, umbrella-like. Lobes are further divided at tips. Leaves are bright green, smooth above.

**Flowers**
Flower is **solitary**, nodding, in the axil between the 2 leaves, often hidden beneath them. Flowers are 4–6 cm across, **waxy white**, with **6–9 petals** and numerous yellow stamens. Fragrant with a sweet, somewhat unpleasant scent. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **fleshy, lemon-shaped berry**, 3–5 cm long, yellow when ripe (July–August), with a sweet, tropical fragrance.

**Seeds**
Seeds are embedded in pulpy flesh; dispersed by box turtles and other animals.

**Morphology**
**P. peltatum** is identified by its **large, umbrella-like peltate leaves** and **single white flower** (on 2-leaved plants). Colonies of mayapple are a distinctive feature of spring forests. Ripe fruit is edible in small quantities, though the seeds, roots, and leaves are **TOXIC** (contain podophyllotoxin, used in cancer drugs). Never eat unripe fruit.

**Polygonum arenastrum**, commonly known as oval-leaf knotweed or dooryard knotweed, is an **annual herb** in the **Polygonaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **sidewalk cracks, driveways, paths, and compacted soils**—one of the toughest weeds.

**Growth habit**
A prostrate, mat-forming annual, with wiry stems 10–100 cm long, spreading along the ground from a central taproot. Plants are extremely tolerant of foot traffic and compaction.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **elliptic to oval**, 5–20 mm long, with **entire margins**, becoming progressively smaller toward stem tips. Leaves are blue-green. Ocrea (sheath) at each node is silvery, eventually torn and tattered.

**Flowers**
Flowers are tiny, borne in **clusters of 2–5 in leaf axils** along the stems. Individual flowers have **5 greenish tepals** with white or pink margins. Blooms summer to fall (June–October).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **3-angled achene**, 2–3 mm long, dull brown to black, enclosed in the persistent perianth.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant; seeds persist in soil for years.

**Morphology**
**P. arenastrum** is identified by its **prostrate, mat-forming habit**, **oval leaves decreasing in size toward stem tips**, and **tolerance of compacted soil**. Distinguished from **P. aviculare** (with which often lumped) by technical achene and flower characters. The classic sidewalk-crack weed. Nearly indestructible in disturbed, trampled sites.

**Populus balsamifera**, commonly known as balsam poplar, is a **large deciduous tree** in the **Salicaceae** family. Native to northern North America, this species inhabits **moist bottomlands, stream banks, and boreal forests**, one of the northernmost hardwoods.

**Growth habit**
A large tree, 20–30 meters tall, with a narrow, open crown. Bark is gray-green and smooth when young, becoming dark gray and deeply furrowed with age. Buds are large, sticky, and highly aromatic (balsamic).

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **ovate to ovate-lanceolate**, 7–12 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**, pointed tips, and rounded to slightly heart-shaped bases. Leaves are dark green and shiny above, **whitish with rusty resin stains beneath**. Petioles are round (not flattened).

**Flowers**
Plants are **dioecious**. Male and female flowers in **drooping catkins** 8–12 cm long, appearing before leaves. Blooms early spring (March–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **2-valved capsule**, 6–8 mm long, in drooping chains.

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny, attached to cottony hairs; wind-dispersed in late spring, creating "cotton" drifts.

**Morphology**
**P. balsamifera** is identified by its **sticky, aromatic buds**, **leaves whitish beneath with rusty staining**, and **round (not flattened) petioles**. Distinguished from **P. deltoides** (cottonwood) by leaf shape and bud aroma. The resinous buds yield Balm of Gilead, used traditionally for medicinal salves. The balsamic fragrance on spring breezes is distinctive.

**Potentilla argentea**, commonly known as silvery cinquefoil or silver cinquefoil, is a **perennial herb** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America in **dry fields, roadsides, and sandy or rocky areas**.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading to ascending herb, 15–50 cm tall, with branching stems covered in dense white, woolly hairs. Plants arise from a woody rootstock.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately compound** with **5 leaflets** (occasionally 3 or 7). Leaflets are **wedge-shaped (cuneate)**, 1–3 cm long, with **deeply incised or lobed margins** rolled under, **dark green above**, and **densely white-woolly beneath** (the "silvery" feature).

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **open, branched clusters** at stem tips. Individual flowers are 8–12 mm across, with **5 pale yellow petals** that are notched at the tip and slightly shorter than or equal to the sepals. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of many small **achenes** on a dry receptacle.

**Seeds**
Achenes are tiny, smooth; dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**
**P. argentea** is identified by its **palmately 5-foliate leaves**, **white-woolly leaf undersides**, and **small pale yellow flowers**. Distinguished from other cinquefoils by the strongly contrasting leaf surfaces—dark green above, silvery-white beneath. A plant of dry, disturbed habitats.

**Prunus americana**, commonly known as American plum or wild plum, is a **large shrub or small tree** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **thickets, fencerows, stream banks, and woodland edges**, often forming dense colonies.

**Growth habit**
A large shrub or small tree, 3–8 meters tall, with spreading branches often forming **thorny thickets** via root suckers. Bark is dark gray-brown, breaking into thin, curling plates. Twigs may bear **sharp thorns**.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to obovate**, 5–10 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins** (teeth not gland-tipped) and pointed tips. Leaves are dark green above, paler and smooth to slightly hairy beneath.

**Flowers**
Flowers appear **before or with leaves**, in **clusters of 2–5**. Individual flowers are 2–2.5 cm across, with **5 white petals** (sometimes pink-tinged), fragrant. Blooms early spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **drupe** (plum), 2–3 cm across, **red to yellow** when ripe, with a **whitish bloom**. Flesh is sweet to tart; edible. Stone is flattened.

**Seeds**
Stones contain a single seed; dispersed by mammals and birds.

**Morphology**
**P. americana** is identified by its **white spring flowers before leaves**, **thorny thickets**, and **red to yellow edible plums**. Distinguished from **P. serotina** (black cherry) by flower and fruit cluster size and thorny habit. Fruit makes excellent jams and jellies. Wildlife value is high—thickets provide cover and food.

**Pycnanthemum incanum**, commonly known as hoary mountain mint, is a **perennial herb** in the **Lamiaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry open woods, prairies, roadsides, and meadows**.

**Growth habit**
An erect herb, 60–120 cm tall, with square, branching stems arising from a rhizome. Plants often form colonies. Strongly aromatic (minty) when crushed.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to lanceolate**, 3–8 cm long, with **serrate margins**. Upper leaves and bracts are distinctive: **densely white-hairy (canescent)**, giving a hoary or frosted appearance to the upper plant.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, terminal and axillary clusters** subtended by whitish bracts. Individual flowers are small, **2-lipped**, **white to pale lavender** with purple spots. Blooms summer (July–September).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **4 small nutlets** at the base of the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**
Nutlets are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**
**P. incanum** is identified by its **white-frosted upper leaves and bracts** (hoary appearance), **minty fragrance**, and **dense white flower clusters**. One of the best native plants for pollinators—attracts an exceptional diversity of bees, wasps, butterflies, and other insects. Distinguished from other Pycnanthemum species by the densely white-hairy upper leaves.

**Pyrus calleryana**, commonly known as Callery pear or Bradford pear, is a **medium deciduous tree** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to China and Vietnam, this species was widely planted as an ornamental street tree but is now recognized as **highly invasive** across eastern North America.

**Growth habit**
A medium tree, 10–20 meters tall, with a dense, pyramidal to rounded crown. Early cultivars (Bradford) had weak branch structure; newer selections vary. Bark is gray-brown, becoming furrowed. Thorny in wild and seedling forms.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **broadly ovate to nearly round**, 4–8 cm long, with **finely crenate margins** and a glossy surface. Fall color is red to purple, often showy but variable.

**Flowers**
Flowers appear **before or with leaves**, in **dense clusters** covering the tree. Individual flowers are 2–3 cm across, **white**, 5-petaled, with an **unpleasant odor** (often compared to rotting fish). Blooms early spring (March–April).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **small, hard pome**, 1–1.5 cm across, brown, bitter, inedible to humans but eaten by birds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by birds, leading to escape from cultivation.

**Morphology**
**P. calleryana** is identified by its **dense white spring bloom**, **glossy rounded leaves**, and **small, hard fruit**. Originally thought sterile as a cultivar, cross-pollination between different cultivars produces viable seed. **HIGHLY INVASIVE**—seedlings revert to thorny, aggressive form. Many states now restrict sale. Remove and replace with native alternatives.

**Quercus acutissima**, commonly known as sawtooth oak, is a **medium to large deciduous tree** in the **Fagaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is planted for wildlife food and timber, and is naturalizing in parts of eastern North America. Considered **potentially invasive**.

**Growth habit**
A medium to large tree, 15–25 meters tall, with a broad, rounded crown. Bark is gray to dark brown, deeply furrowed with corky ridges. Growth is rapid.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **oblong-lanceolate**, 10–20 cm long, with **bristle-tipped serrations** along the entire margin (like a saw blade—hence sawtooth). Leaves are glossy dark green above, paler beneath. Some leaves persist through winter.

**Flowers**
Plants are **monoecious**. Male flowers in **pendant catkins**. Female flowers are tiny, in leaf axils. Blooms spring.

**Fruit**
Fruit is an **acorn**, 1.5–2 cm long, with a distinctive **cup covered in long, spreading, fringed scales** resembling a shaggy cap. Acorns mature in 2 years.

**Seeds**
Acorns are dispersed by squirrels and other wildlife.

**Morphology**
**Q. acutissima** is identified by its **chestnut-like leaves with bristle-tipped teeth** and **acorns with shaggy, fringed cups**. Produces heavy acorn crops attractive to deer and turkey—hence wildlife plantings. However, naturalizing and displacing native oaks in some areas. Monitor spread; consider native alternatives.

**Ratibida pinnata**, commonly known as gray-headed coneflower or pinnate prairie coneflower, is a **perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to central and eastern North America, this species inhabits **prairies, meadows, roadsides, and open woods**, often in dry to mesic conditions.

**Growth habit**
An erect herb, 60–150 cm tall, with branching stems arising from a woody rootstock. Plants are rough-hairy throughout.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately divided** into 3–7 narrow, lanceolate segments, 10–20 cm long overall. Segments are entire to sparingly toothed. Leaves are gray-green, rough-hairy.

**Flowers**
Flower heads are borne singly on long stalks. Heads have **6–10 drooping yellow ray florets**, 3–6 cm long, and a **cylindrical gray to brown disk** 1–2 cm long (columnar, not spherical). Rays hang downward like a skirt around the disk. Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**
Achenes are small, flattened, without pappus.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**
**R. pinnata** is identified by its **drooping yellow rays** and **cylindrical gray-brown disk**. Distinguished from black-eyed Susan (Rudbeckia) by the taller, narrower disk and drooping (not spreading) rays. A graceful prairie flower. Excellent for meadow gardens. Attracts pollinators.

**Rhododendron arborescens**, commonly known as smooth azalea or sweet azalea, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to the Appalachian region of eastern North America, this species inhabits **stream banks, moist slopes, and mountain woods**, often at higher elevations.

**Growth habit**
A large shrub, 2–5 meters tall, with multiple stems and an open, spreading form. Bark is smooth, gray-brown. Plants are late-flowering compared to other native azaleas.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **obovate to elliptic**, 4–10 cm long, with **entire, ciliate margins** and smooth surfaces (hence "smooth" azalea). Leaves are bright green above, **smooth and glaucous (whitish-waxy) beneath**. Fall color is red.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **clusters of 3–7** at branch tips after leaves are fully expanded (late bloom). Individual flowers are **funnel-shaped**, 4–5 cm across, **white to pale pink** with a **pink style** and **red stamens**. Flowers are **intensely fragrant** (heliotrope-like). Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **dry capsule**, 1–2 cm long, persisting through winter.

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny, dust-like; wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**R. arborescens** is identified by its **late white fragrant flowers**, **smooth leaves glaucous beneath**, and **red stamens**. One of the most fragrant native azaleas. Distinguished from **R. viscosum** (swamp azalea) by smooth (not hairy) branchlets and leaf undersides. Excellent for naturalistic gardens.

**Rhus aromatica**, commonly known as fragrant sumac or aromatic sumac, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Anacardiaceae** family. Native to eastern and central North America, this species inhabits **dry, rocky woods, barrens, and slopes**, often in poor soils.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading shrub, 1–2 meters tall, often wider than tall, with branches that may root where they touch the ground. Bark is brown, smooth. Plants are aromatic when leaves or twigs are crushed.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets)—distinguishing the plant from poison ivy, which has similar leaves. Terminal leaflet is **3-lobed**, 4–8 cm long; lateral leaflets are smaller, unlobed. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath, with a pungent (not unpleasant) scent when crushed. Fall color is brilliant orange to red.

**Flowers**  
Flowers appear **before leaves** in early spring, in **dense, yellowish catkin-like clusters** at branch tips. Individual flowers are tiny, yellow. Plants are usually dioecious. Blooms March–May.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **small, round drupe**, 6–8 mm across, **red**, covered with sticky hairs, in dense clusters. Ripens summer.

**Seeds**
Drupes are dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**
**R. aromatica** is identified by its **trifoliate aromatic leaves** (terminal leaflet 3-lobed), **flowers appearing before leaves**, and **red hairy fruit**. **NOT POISONOUS**—despite resemblance to poison ivy, fragrant sumac is harmless. Excellent native groundcover for difficult dry sites. Cultivar Gro-Low is widely used in landscaping.

**Ribes americanum**, commonly known as American black currant or wild black currant, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Grossulariaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, and thickets**, often in rich soils.

**Growth habit**
An upright to spreading shrub, 1–1.5 meters tall, without thorns or prickles. Bark is gray-brown, smooth. Young stems have resinous dots.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately 3–5 lobed**, 4–8 cm wide, resembling maple leaves. Lobes are doubly serrate. Leaves are dark green above with **yellow resinous dots beneath** (key identifier). Fall color is yellow to reddish.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **drooping racemes** of 6–15 flowers. Individual flowers are tubular, 6–10 mm long, **yellowish-white to greenish**, not showy. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **round berry**, 6–10 mm across, **black** when ripe, smooth (not bristly), in drooping clusters. Berries are edible, tart, excellent for preserves. Ripens mid-summer.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by birds eating the fruit.

**Morphology**
**R. americanum** is identified by its **maple-like lobed leaves with yellow resin dots beneath**, **lack of thorns**, and **black fruit**. Distinguished from European black currant (R. nigrum) by minor technical features. Note: Ribes species were historically banned due to serving as alternate hosts for white pine blister rust; restrictions have eased in many areas.

**Robinia hispida**, commonly known as bristly locust or rose acacia, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to the southeastern United States, this species inhabits **dry, rocky slopes and woodland edges**, often planted ornamentally and escaping northward. Can be **invasive** via root suckers.

**Growth habit**
A suckering shrub, 1–3 meters tall, spreading aggressively by root sprouts to form thickets. Young stems and leaf stalks are covered with **distinctive bristly, red-brown hairs** (not true thorns).

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **7–13 leaflets**. Leaflets are **elliptic to oval**, 2–4 cm long, with **entire margins** and rounded tips. Leaves are bright green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **drooping racemes** 5–12 cm long. Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 2–2.5 cm long, **rose-pink to lavender**, showy and attractive. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **flattened, bristly pod**, 5–8 cm long, covered with glandular hairs. Pods often fail to set viable seed.

**Seeds**
Seeds are rarely produced; spread is primarily vegetative via root suckers.

**Morphology**
**R. hispida** is identified by its **bristly (not spiny) stems**, **showy pink pea-like flowers**, and **aggressive suckering habit**. Distinguished from **R. pseudoacacia** (black locust) by pink (not white) flowers and bristles (not thorns). Can be difficult to control once established—suckers prolifically. Beautiful but use with caution.

**Rorippa sylvestris**, commonly known as creeping yellow cress, is a **perennial herb** in the **Brassicaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is naturalized in North America in **moist fields, stream banks, ditches, and disturbed wet areas**.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading perennial, 20–60 cm tall, with stems that are often decumbent (lying along the ground) at the base and rooting at nodes. Plants spread vegetatively to form patches.

**Leaves**
Basal leaves are **pinnately lobed to deeply divided**, 5–15 cm long, with a large terminal lobe and smaller lateral lobes. Stem leaves are **alternate**, smaller, and less divided upward, often clasping the stem. Leaves are dark green.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **elongating racemes** at branch tips. Individual flowers are small, 5–8 mm across, with **4 bright yellow petals** arranged in a cross. Blooms late spring to fall (May–October).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **short, linear silique**, 8–14 mm long, curved upward on spreading pedicels.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, numerous; dispersed by water.

**Morphology**
**R. sylvestris** is identified by its **creeping habit**, **deeply lobed basal leaves**, **small yellow flowers**, and **short curved siliques**. Distinguished from other yellow cresses by silique length and shape. A persistent weed in moist, disturbed sites. The peppery leaves are edible but not commonly used.

**Rosa carolina**, commonly known as Carolina rose or pasture rose, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry open woods, fields, roadsides, and thickets**, often in sandy or rocky soils.

**Growth habit**
A low, suckering shrub, 0.5–1.5 meters tall, forming loose colonies via underground stems. Stems are slender, armed with **straight, slender prickles** (not hooked), often paired at nodes.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **(3–)5–7 leaflets**. Leaflets are **elliptic**, 2–4 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins**. Stipules are narrow, with flared tips. Leaves are dull green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**
Flowers are **solitary or in clusters of 2–3** at branch tips. Individual flowers are 4–6 cm across, with **5 pink petals** (rarely white) and numerous yellow stamens. Fragrant. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **red hip**, 8–12 mm across, round, smooth, persisting into winter. Contains numerous achenes.

**Seeds**
Achenes (within the hip) are dispersed by birds and mammals eating the fruit.

**Morphology**
**R. carolina** is identified by its **low, suckering habit**, **straight paired prickles**, **5–7 leaflets**, and **pink fragrant flowers**. Distinguished from **R. virginiana** by stipule shape and prickle distribution. One of the most common and widespread native roses. Excellent for wildlife—provides cover and winter food.

**Rubus occidentalis**, commonly known as black raspberry or blackcap, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Rosaceae** family. Native to eastern and central North America, this species inhabits **woodland edges, thickets, fencerows, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An arching shrub with **biennial canes** (primocanes the first year, floricanes the second), 1–2 meters tall. Canes are **distinctly glaucous (whitish-waxy)**, armed with **hooked prickles**. Cane tips often root where they touch ground, forming new plants.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **palmately compound** with **3 leaflets** (rarely 5 on vigorous primocanes). Leaflets are **ovate**, 5–10 cm long, with **sharply doubly serrate margins**, dark green above and **white-felted beneath**.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **clusters of 3–7** on short lateral branches of floricanes. Individual flowers are small, 8–12 mm across, with **5 white petals** and numerous stamens. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is an **aggregate of drupelets** (raspberry), 10–15 mm across, **dark purple to black** when ripe, easily separating from the core (receptacle) when picked—leaving a hollow fruit. Delicious, sweet.

**Seeds**
Drupelets each contain one seed; dispersed by birds and mammals.

**Morphology**
**R. occidentalis** is identified by its **glaucous (white-waxy) canes**, **3 leaflets white beneath**, **hooked prickles**, and **black fruit that separates cleanly from core**. Distinguished from blackberries (R. allegheniensis) by the hollow fruit and glaucous canes. The finest wild berry for fresh eating and preserves.

**Rumex obtusifolius**, commonly known as bitter dock or broad-leaved dock, is a **perennial herb** in the **Polygonaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **fields, roadsides, gardens, and disturbed areas**—a common weed.

**Growth habit**
A robust herb, 60–120 cm tall, with stout, grooved stems arising from a thick, yellow taproot. Plants are persistent and difficult to eradicate once established.

**Leaves**
Basal leaves are **large**, **broadly ovate** with a **heart-shaped base**, 15–40 cm long, with **wavy margins**. Leaves are dark green, somewhat leathery, with prominent veins. Stem leaves are smaller, alternate, lanceolate.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, whorled clusters** on tall, branched panicles. Individual flowers are tiny, greenish, with 6 tepals. Inner tepals enlarge and become the fruit valves. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **3-angled achene** enclosed by 3 enlarged **toothed valves** (inner tepals), each valve typically bearing a prominent **warty tubercle** on the back.

**Seeds**
Achenes are wind- and water-dispersed; seeds persist in soil for decades.

**Morphology**
**R. obtusifolius** is identified by its **large, heart-based basal leaves**, **toothed fruit valves with tubercles**, and **robust stature**. Distinguished from **R. crispus** (curly dock) by broader leaves with heart-shaped (not tapering) bases. The yellow taproot makes mechanical removal difficult. Persistent agricultural weed.

**Sagittaria graminea**, commonly known as grassy arrowhead or grass-leaved arrowhead, is a **perennial aquatic herb** in the **Alismataceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **shallow water, pond edges, marshes, and muddy shores**.

**Growth habit**
An aquatic herb, 20–60 cm tall, arising from a fibrous root system (lacking the tubers of some arrowheads). Plants grow emergent or partially submerged.

**Leaves**
Leaves are highly variable: **submerged leaves are linear, grass-like, ribbon-shaped**; **emergent leaves are lanceolate to elliptic**, 5–20 cm long, **lacking the arrow-shaped base** typical of many Sagittaria species (hence "graminea"—grass-like).

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **whorls of 3** on an erect scape above the leaves. Lower whorls have female flowers; upper whorls have male flowers. Individual flowers are 1–2 cm across, with **3 white petals** and numerous yellow stamens (male) or green pistils (female). Blooms summer (June–September).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **cluster of flattened achenes**, 2–3 mm long, in a spherical head.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**
**S. graminea** is identified by its **grass-like or lanceolate leaves** (NOT arrow-shaped), **white 3-petaled flowers in whorls**, and **aquatic habitat**. Distinguished from **S. latifolia** (common arrowhead) by leaf shape. Variable species—submerged and emergent forms can look very different.

**Salix caprea**, commonly known as goat willow or pussy willow, is a **deciduous shrub or small tree** in the **Salicaceae** family. Native to Europe and western Asia, this species is cultivated for ornament (catkins used in floral arrangements) and occasionally naturalizes in North America.

**Growth habit**
A large shrub or small tree, 5–12 meters tall, with a rounded, spreading crown. Bark is gray, smooth when young, becoming fissured. Twigs are stout, reddish-brown, often hairy when young.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **broadly elliptic to obovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **irregularly wavy to crenate margins** and a **rounded to pointed tip**. Leaves are dark green and wrinkled above, **densely gray-woolly beneath**. Stipules are large, ear-shaped.

**Flowers**
Plants are **dioecious**. Catkins appear **before leaves** in early spring. Male catkins are ovoid, 2–4 cm long, densely covered with **silvery-gray silky hairs** (the familiar "pussy willow"), becoming golden with pollen. Female catkins are greenish. Blooms early spring.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a small **capsule** releasing cottony seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny, borne on cottony hairs; wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**S. caprea** is identified by its **large, broadly elliptic leaves gray-woolly beneath** and **silky male catkins** (pussy willows). Distinguished from native willows by the broad leaf shape. The classic "pussy willow" of the florist trade. Can be invasive in wetlands; monitor spread.

**Sambucus racemosa**, commonly known as red elderberry or red-berried elder, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Adoxaceae** family. Native to North America, Europe, and Asia, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, and mountain slopes**, often at higher elevations than common elderberry.

**Growth habit**
A large shrub, 2–4 meters tall, with multiple stems and soft, pithy wood. Bark is gray-brown with prominent lenticels. Plants may form thickets.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **pinnately compound** with **5–7 leaflets**. Leaflets are **lanceolate to elliptic**, 5–15 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are dark green above, paler beneath.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, dome-shaped to pyramidal panicles** (not flat-topped like S. nigra). Individual flowers are small, 4–5 mm across, **creamy white to yellowish**. Blooms spring (April–June)—earlier than common elderberry.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **small, round drupe**, 4–6 mm across, **bright red** (rarely yellow or white), in dense clusters. Ripens early to mid-summer.

**Seeds**
Drupes are dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**
**S. racemosa** is identified by its **pyramidal flower clusters** (not flat-topped), **bright red fruit**, and **earlier bloom time**. Distinguished from **S. nigra** (common elderberry) by flower cluster shape and fruit color. **Fruit and seeds are mildly TOXIC** when raw—must be cooked and strained before use. Birds eat the fruit readily.

**Saururus cernuus**, commonly known as lizards tail, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Saururaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **swamps, stream margins, wet woods, and shallow water**, often forming extensive colonies.

**Growth habit**
An erect, colonial herb, 60–120 cm tall, spreading by thick, aromatic rhizomes. Stems are erect, jointed, somewhat zigzag.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **heart-shaped**, 8–15 cm long, with **entire margins**, pointed tips, and deeply cordate bases. Leaves are bright green, thin-textured, aromatic when crushed.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, nodding, spike-like racemes** 10–20 cm long at stem tips—the arching, tail-like spike gives the plant the common name. Individual flowers are tiny, **white**, lacking petals, with 6–8 stamens and 3–4 carpels. Fragrant. Blooms late spring to summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a cluster of **wrinkled capsules**, becoming brown and warty at maturity.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**
**S. cernuus** is identified by its **nodding, white, tail-like flower spikes**, **heart-shaped leaves**, and **wetland habitat**. The gracefully curved flower spike is distinctive. An attractive native for water gardens and wetland edges. The aromatic rhizome was used medicinally by Indigenous peoples.

**Scheuchzeria palustris**, commonly known as rannoch-rush or pod grass, is a **perennial herb** in the **Scheuchzeriaceae** family. Native to circumboreal regions of North America, Europe, and Asia, this species inhabits **bogs, fens, and acidic wetlands**, often in sphagnum moss.

**Growth habit**
A slender, grass-like herb, 10–40 cm tall, arising from a creeping rhizome. Plants are inconspicuous and often hidden among sphagnum. Forms loose colonies.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **basal and cauline**, **linear**, 10–25 cm long, 2–4 mm wide, with a **prominent pore at the tip** and a **loose, open sheath** at the base. Leaves are yellowish-green, somewhat fleshy.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in a **loose, terminal raceme** of 3–10 flowers. Individual flowers are small, 4–6 mm across, **greenish-yellow**, with 6 tepals and 6 stamens. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **3–6 spreading follicles**, 5–8 mm long, inflated, diverging like a star—distinctive.

**Seeds**
Seeds are 1–2 per follicle, dispersed when follicles open.

**Morphology**
**S. palustris** is identified by its **grass-like leaves with pore at tip**, **small greenish flowers**, and **star-like cluster of spreading follicles**. A relict species from glacial times, now rare and local in much of the range. Indicator of pristine bog habitats. The only species in the genus.

**Schizachyrium scoparium**, commonly known as little bluestem, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **prairies, old fields, dry slopes, and open woods**, one of the most widespread and important native grasses.

**Growth habit**
A densely tufted bunchgrass, 60–120 cm tall, forming tight clumps. Basal portions of stems are often **flattened and keeled**. Plants are long-lived.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–30 cm long, 3–6 mm wide, often folded lengthwise, blue-green in summer. Leaves and stems turn distinctive **bronze to coppery-red in fall**—one of the showiest autumn grasses.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence consists of **numerous slender racemes**, 3–5 cm long, borne singly at the ends of branching stems, often partially enclosed by the sheath. Spikelets are paired, one sessile (fertile) with a twisted awn, one stalked (sterile). Blooms late summer to fall.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a small **caryopsis** attached to the awned lemma.

**Seeds**
Grains with fluffy hairs are wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**S. scoparium** is identified by its **tufted habit**, **blue-green summer foliage turning bronze-red in fall**, and **fluffy, silvery seed heads**. One of the dominant grasses of the tallgrass and mixed-grass prairies. Excellent for native landscaping and restoration. Provides winter interest.

**Scirpus atrovirens**, commonly known as green bulrush or dark-green bulrush, is a **perennial sedge** in the **Cyperaceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **wet meadows, marshes, stream banks, and ditches**, often in standing water.

**Growth habit**
A robust, clump-forming sedge, 60–150 cm tall, with stout, triangular stems arising from short, thick rhizomes. Plants form dense clumps.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **basal and cauline**, **flat**, 6–15 mm wide, with rough margins, light green. Leaves have a distinct midrib.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence is a **compound umbel-like cluster** at the stem tip, with several to many rays of varying lengths, subtended by 2–4 long, leaf-like bracts. Spikelets are small, 3–5 mm long, **dark green to blackish**, in dense clusters at ray tips. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Achenes are small, lens-shaped, pale brown, with 6 bristles at the base.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed by water.

**Morphology**
**S. atrovirens** is identified by its **umbel-like inflorescence** with **dark greenish-black spikelets**, **leaf-like bracts**, and **clumping habit**. Distinguished from woolgrass (S. cyperinus) by darker spikelets and lack of woolly appearance. Common in disturbed wetlands. Important for wetland restoration.

**Scutellaria integrifolia**, commonly known as hyssop skullcap or helmet flower, is a **perennial herb** in the **Lamiaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **open woods, prairies, meadows, and roadsides**, often in dry to mesic conditions.

**Growth habit**
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, with square, hairy stems arising from a rhizome. Stems are usually unbranched or few-branched.

**Leaves**
Lower leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to lanceolate**, 2–5 cm long, with **crenate margins**. Upper leaves are smaller, narrower, often with **entire margins** (hence "integrifolia"). Leaves are grayish-green, finely hairy.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **terminal racemes** 5–15 cm long. Individual flowers are **2-lipped**, 15–25 mm long, **blue to violet** (rarely pink or white). The upper lip is hood-like; the lower lip is spreading with a white patch. Calyx has a distinctive **helmet-shaped crest** on top. Blooms late spring to summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **4 small nutlets** within the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**
Nutlets are dispersed when calyx dries.

**Morphology**
**S. integrifolia** is identified by its **blue hooded flowers**, **calyx with helmet-like crest**, and **often entire upper leaves**. Distinguished from other skullcaps by the crenate lower vs. entire upper leaf margins. The calyx crest is diagnostic for the genus. Attractive native for meadow gardens.

**Sedum spurium**, commonly known as two-row stonecrop or Caucasian stonecrop, is a **mat-forming succulent perennial** in the **Crassulaceae** family. Native to the Caucasus region, this species is widely cultivated as a groundcover and frequently escapes to **rocky areas, walls, and disturbed sites**.

**Growth habit**
A low, creeping succulent, 10–20 cm tall when in flower, forming dense mats. Stems are trailing, rooting at nodes, with ascending flowering shoots.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **broadly spatulate to obovate**, 1–3 cm long, **thick and succulent**, with **crenate margins** on the upper half. Leaves are evergreen to semi-evergreen, green to reddish-bronze depending on cultivar and conditions.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **flat-topped cymes** at stem tips. Individual flowers are small, 10–15 mm across, **star-shaped** with **5 pink to red petals** (sometimes white). Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **5 follicles** radiating from the center.

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny; dispersed by wind and water.

**Morphology**
**S. spurium** is identified by its **mat-forming habit**, **opposite succulent leaves with crenate margins**, and **pink to red starry flowers**. Many cultivars exist with purple or variegated foliage. Can escape cultivation and establish on walls and rocky sites. Drought-tolerant and easy to grow.

**Senecio vulgaris**, commonly known as common groundsel, is an **annual herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is now nearly cosmopolitan as a weed of **gardens, fields, sidewalk cracks, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An erect to ascending annual, 10–40 cm tall, with branching stems that may be smooth or sparsely woolly. Plants can complete multiple generations per year.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately lobed to deeply divided**, 2–10 cm long, with irregular, wavy lobes that are often toothed. Lower leaves are stalked; upper leaves clasp the stem. Leaves are bright green, somewhat fleshy.

**Flowers**
Flower heads are borne in **loose, irregular clusters**. Each head is **cylindrical**, 6–8 mm long, with **black-tipped involucral bracts** (diagnostic) and **yellow disk florets only**—**no ray florets**. Blooms nearly year-round.

**Fruit**
Achenes are small, ribbed, with a fluffy white **pappus** (resembling dandelion).

**Seeds**
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**
**S. vulgaris** is identified by its **small cylindrical heads with black-tipped bracts**, **lack of ray florets**, and **pinnately lobed leaves**. One of the most cosmopolitan weeds. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids—**toxic to livestock and humans if consumed regularly**. Often appears in potted plants from nurseries.

**Setaria faberi**, commonly known as giant foxtail or nodding foxtail, is an **annual grass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to eastern Asia, this species is a serious agricultural weed in North America, found in **cropland, gardens, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
A robust annual, 60–180 cm tall, with erect to spreading culms that may be solitary or tufted. Plants are coarse and vigorous.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 15–35 cm long, 15–30 mm wide, flat, **densely hairy on the upper surface** (key identifier—other foxtails are smooth). Leaf margins are rough. Ligule is a fringe of hairs.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence is a **dense, cylindrical, bristly panicle** (foxtail), 7–20 cm long, **nodding or drooping** at the tip (diagnostic). Bristles beneath each spikelet are greenish to tawny. Spikelets are 2.5–3 mm long. Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **small caryopsis** enclosed in the spikelet scales.

**Seeds**
Grains are dispersed with the spikelet unit.

**Morphology**
**S. faberi** is identified by its **nodding, drooping panicle**, **hairy upper leaf surface**, and **large, coarse stature**. Distinguished from **S. viridis** (green foxtail) by larger size, nodding inflorescence, and hairy leaves. One of the worst annual grass weeds in corn and soybean fields. Introduced around 1925; now dominant.

**Silphium perfoliatum**, commonly known as cup plant, is a **tall perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to central and eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist prairies, stream banks, and open woodlands**.

**Growth habit**
A robust, clump-forming herb, 150–250 cm tall, with stout, square stems arising from a thick rootstock. Stems are smooth.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **large (20–35 cm)**, **coarsely toothed**, and distinctively **connate-perfoliate**: the bases of opposite leaves are fused together around the stem, creating a **cup that holds water** (the "cup plant" feature). Upper leaves may be sessile but not fully perfoliate. Leaves are rough-textured.

**Flowers**
Flower heads are borne in **open, branched clusters** at stem tops. Heads are 5–8 cm across, with **20–30 yellow ray florets** and **yellow disk florets**. Rays are fertile (produce seeds); disk florets are sterile. Blooms summer (July–September).

**Fruit**
Achenes are flat, winged, notched at the apex, 8–12 mm long.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed by wind and water.

**Morphology**
**S. perfoliatum** is identified by its **square stems** and **opposite leaves fused at the base to form a cup**. The cup-shaped leaf junction collects rainwater, used by birds and insects. Tall and architectural. Excellent native for wet meadow gardens. Attracts pollinators and goldfinches (for seeds).

**Sisymbrium officinale**, commonly known as hedge mustard, is an **annual or biennial herb** in the **Brassicaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **roadsides, fields, waste places, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An erect, stiffly branching herb, 30–90 cm tall, with wiry stems covered in stiff, downward-pointing hairs. Plants often have a distinctive stiff, angular appearance.

**Leaves**
Basal leaves are **pinnately lobed** with a large terminal lobe and smaller lateral lobes pointing backward (runcinate), 5–15 cm long. Stem leaves are **alternate**, smaller, often with just 2 narrow lateral lobes and a larger terminal lobe.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **elongating racemes** at branch tips. Individual flowers are tiny, 3–4 mm across, with **4 pale yellow petals** arranged in a cross. Blooms late spring to fall (May–October).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **narrow, cylindrical silique**, 10–15 mm long, **pressed tightly against the stem** (appressed)—a key identifier. Siliques taper to a point.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, numerous; dispersed when siliques split.

**Morphology**
**S. officinale** is identified by its **stiff, angular habit**, **runcinate basal leaves**, **tiny yellow flowers**, and **siliques pressed tightly against the stem**. The appressed siliques are diagnostic—most mustards have spreading fruit. Common urban weed. The name "officinale" indicates historical medicinal use for throat ailments.

**Sisyrinchium angustifolium**, commonly known as narrow-leaved blue-eyed grass or stout blue-eyed grass, is a **perennial herb** in the **Iridaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist meadows, prairies, open woods, and roadsides**.

**Growth habit**
A tufted, grass-like herb, 20–50 cm tall, with flattened, 2-edged (winged) stems arising from fibrous roots. Plants form small clumps.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **basal**, **linear**, grass-like, 2–4 mm wide, similar in appearance to the stems. Leaves and stems are flat, with parallel veins. The entire plant resembles a small grass.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **terminal clusters** (spathe-enclosed) of 1–several. Individual flowers are **6-tepaled**, 10–15 mm across, **violet-blue with a yellow center** (eye). Tepals are delicate, each tipped with a tiny point. Flowers open in morning sunlight, close by afternoon. Blooms late spring to early summer (May–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a small, **round capsule**, 4–6 mm across.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, black; dispersed when capsule opens.

**Morphology**
**S. angustifolium** is identified by its **grass-like form**, **flat, winged stems**, and **blue flowers with yellow eyes**. Despite the common name, this species is in the iris family, not a true grass. Distinguished from other blue-eyed grasses by technical characters of spathe and stem width. A charming native wildflower for meadow gardens.

**Smilax rotundifolia**, commonly known as common greenbrier or roundleaf greenbrier, is a **woody vine** in the **Smilacaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **woodlands, thickets, and forest edges**, climbing on trees and forming impenetrable tangles.

**Growth habit**
A high-climbing or sprawling woody vine, reaching 5–15 meters, with green stems armed with **stout, sharp thorns**. Climbs by paired **tendrils** arising from leaf bases. Forms dense, thorny thickets.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **broadly ovate to nearly round**, 5–12 cm long and wide, with **entire margins**, a heart-shaped to truncate base, and **parallel veins** curving from base to tip (monocot-like venation). Leaves are **leathery, glossy, semi-evergreen**, green on both surfaces.

**Flowers**
Plants are **dioecious**. Flowers are borne in **axillary umbels** on stalks. Individual flowers are small, **greenish-yellow**, 6-tepaled. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a round **berry**, 6–10 mm across, **blue-black** with a waxy bloom, in clusters. Persists into winter.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by birds eating the berries.

**Morphology**
**S. rotundifolia** is identified by its **round, leathery leaves**, **stout thorns**, **tendrils**, and **blue-black berries**. Distinguished from **S. glauca** by leaves green (not glaucous) beneath. Important wildlife food—berries persist into winter. Forms impenetrable thickets—the bane of hikers and land managers. New shoots are edible.

**Solanum ptychanthum** (syn. **S. americanum** in part), commonly known as eastern black nightshade or American black nightshade, is an **annual herb** in the **Solanaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **gardens, fields, roadsides, and disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An erect to spreading annual, 30–100 cm tall, with branching stems that may be smooth or sparsely hairy. Plants are somewhat weedy.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **ovate to lanceolate**, 3–10 cm long, with **entire to wavy or irregularly toothed margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are thin, dark green.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **small umbel-like clusters** (2–8 flowers) on lateral peduncles. Individual flowers are small, 6–10 mm across, **star-shaped**, with **5 white petals** (sometimes tinged purple) reflexed backward and **yellow stamens** forming a prominent cone. Blooms summer to fall.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a round **berry**, 6–10 mm across, **glossy black** when ripe (green when immature), in drooping clusters. Contains numerous seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by birds eating the berries.

**Morphology**
**S. ptychanthum** is identified by its **white star-shaped flowers with yellow stamen cone**, **glossy black berries**, and **annual habit**. Distinguished from the introduced **S. nigrum** by technical characters of fruit and flower. **CAUTION: Unripe berries and all green parts contain solanine and are TOXIC**. Ripe berries are less toxic but best avoided.

**Solidago altissima**, commonly known as tall goldenrod or late goldenrod, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to North America, this species inhabits **old fields, roadsides, meadows, and disturbed areas**, often forming extensive colonies.

**Growth habit**
A tall, erect herb, 100–200 cm tall, with unbranched stems below the inflorescence, arising from long, creeping rhizomes. Plants often form dense, monocultural stands.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **lanceolate**, 8–15 cm long, with **sharply serrate margins** (except near base and tip), **3-nerved** (3 prominent veins from near the base), and **rough-hairy** on both surfaces. Leaves are numerous, crowded along the stem.

**Flowers**
Inflorescence is a **large, pyramidal panicle** with arching, one-sided branches (secund). Heads are small, 4–5 mm across, with **9–15 yellow ray florets** and yellow disk florets. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**
Achenes are small, hairy, with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**
Achenes are wind-dispersed by the pappus.

**Morphology**
**S. altissima** is identified by its **tall stature**, **rough 3-nerved leaves**, **pyramidal inflorescence**, and **colonial habit**. Distinguished from **S. gigantea** by rough (not smooth) stems. One of the most abundant goldenrods in disturbed habitats. Important late-season nectar source. Does NOT cause hay fever—wind-pollinated ragweed (blooming simultaneously) is the culprit.

**Sorghastrum nutans**, commonly known as Indiangrass, is a **perennial bunchgrass** in the **Poaceae** family. Native to central and eastern North America, this species inhabits **prairies, meadows, and open woods**, one of the dominant grasses of the tallgrass prairie.

**Growth habit**
A tall, clump-forming grass, 100–200 cm tall, with erect culms arising from short, scaly rhizomes. Plants form dense bunches but may spread slowly.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, 30–60 cm long, 8–15 mm wide, with a distinctive **rifle-sight ligule** (a prominent, membranous projection). Leaves are blue-green in summer, turning golden to bronze in fall.

**Flowers**
