Inflorescence is a **narrow, plume-like panicle**, 15–30 cm long, **golden to bronze** at maturity, with a shimmering, silky appearance. Spikelets are paired, one sessile (fertile) with a bent, twisted awn 10–15 mm long, one stalked (sterile, reduced). Blooms late summer to fall.

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **caryopsis** attached to the awned lemma.

**Seeds**
Grains with plumose hairs are dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**
**S. nutans** is identified by its **tall stature**, **rifle-sight ligule**, and **golden, plume-like panicle**. Distinguished from big bluestem (Andropogon gerardii) by the single raceme (not 2–6 digitate racemes). One of the most beautiful native grasses—the golden fall color and silky inflorescence are spectacular. Excellent for native meadow gardens.

**Sparganium americanum**, commonly known as American bur-reed, is an **emergent aquatic perennial** in the **Typhaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **shallow water, pond margins, marshes, and slow streams**.

**Growth habit**
An emergent aquatic herb, 50–150 cm tall, with erect stems arising from creeping rhizomes. Plants often grow in colonies in shallow water.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **linear**, grass-like, 50–100 cm long, 6–15 mm wide, with a **triangular cross-section near the base** (keeled). Leaves are bright green, upright or floating.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **spherical heads** along an unbranched or branched stem. **Male heads** are above, smaller, falling after flowering. **Female heads** are below, larger, 15–25 mm across, greenish. Each female head contains many pistillate flowers. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Fruit is an aggregate of **wedge-shaped, beaked achenes** (nutlets), forming a spiny, bur-like sphere—hence "bur-reed."

**Seeds**
Nutlets are dispersed by water and by sticking to waterfowl feathers.

**Morphology**
**S. americanum** is identified by its **grass-like leaves**, **spherical flower/fruit heads** (burs), and **aquatic habitat**. Distinguished from other bur-reeds by technical characters of fruit and inflorescence branching. Important for wetland wildlife—waterfowl eat the nutlets. Provides habitat for fish and invertebrates.

**Spirodela polyrrhiza**, commonly known as greater duckweed or common duckmeat, is a **tiny, floating aquatic perennial** in the **Araceae** family. Native to much of the world, this species inhabits **still or slow-moving fresh water**, including ponds, lakes, marshes, and ditches.

**Growth habit**
A minute, free-floating aquatic, each frond (plant body) is 5–10 mm across—much larger than lesser duckweed (Lemna). Plants float on the water surface, forming mats. Reproduction is primarily vegetative (budding).

**Leaves**
The plant body is a **thallus-like frond** (not differentiated into stem and leaf), **broadly ovate to round**, 5–10 mm across, **dark green above**, often **reddish-purple beneath**. Fronds have **7–12 roots** (nerves visible on surface), unlike Lemna which has 1 root per frond.

**Flowers**
Flowers are minute, rarely produced, borne in pouches on the frond margin. Plants reproduce almost exclusively by vegetative budding—daughter fronds bud from the parent, separate, and float away.

**Fruit**
If produced, fruit is a minute utricle with 1–2 seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds sink to the bottom; rarely produced.

**Morphology**
**S. polyrrhiza** is identified by its **relatively large fronds** (5–10 mm), **multiple roots** (7–12), and **often reddish-purple underside**. Distinguished from **Lemna** species by larger size and multiple roots. Important waterfowl food. Can form dense mats that shade out submerged plants. Studied for wastewater treatment and biofuel potential.

**Staphylea trifolia**, commonly known as American bladdernut, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Staphyleaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **moist woods, stream banks, and woodland borders**, often in rich soils.

**Growth habit**
A multi-stemmed shrub, 3–5 meters tall, with upright, arching branches. Bark is greenish with pale stripes when young, becoming gray-brown and fissured. May form thickets via root suckers.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **elliptic to ovate**, 5–10 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Terminal leaflet is larger, stalked; lateral leaflets are sessile or short-stalked. Leaves are bright green.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **drooping panicles** 5–10 cm long at branch tips. Individual flowers are **bell-shaped**, 8–10 mm long, with **5 white to greenish-white petals**, fragrant. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a distinctive **inflated, papery capsule**, 3–5 cm long, 3-lobed, pale green becoming tan, **bladder-like**—hanging like small lanterns. Capsules rattle when shaken.

**Seeds**
Seeds are 1–4 per capsule, hard, smooth, rattling inside the bladder. Dispersed by wind and water.

**Morphology**
**S. trifolia** is identified by its **opposite trifoliate leaves** and **inflated, bladder-like fruit capsules**. The papery, lantern-like capsules are unique and persist into winter. An attractive but underused native shrub for woodland gardens. Seeds can be eaten roasted like nuts.

**Stellaria media**, commonly known as common chickweed, is an **annual or winter annual herb** in the **Caryophyllaceae** family. Native to Eurasia, this species is now cosmopolitan in **lawns, gardens, fields, and disturbed areas**—one of the most common weeds worldwide.

**Growth habit**
A low, sprawling to ascending annual, 10–40 cm long, with weak, branching stems that often root at nodes. Stems have a characteristic **single line of hairs** running down one side, changing sides at each node.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate**, 1–3 cm long, with **entire margins** and pointed tips. Lower leaves are long-petioled; upper leaves are sessile. Leaves are bright green, smooth.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **loose, leafy cymes** at stem tips. Individual flowers are small, 5–8 mm across, with **5 white petals** so **deeply cleft** that they appear to be 10 petals. Sepals are longer than petals. Stamens 3–5. Blooms nearly year-round in mild climates.

**Fruit**
Fruit is an **ovoid capsule** opening by 6 teeth.

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny, numerous, reddish-brown; dispersed near the parent plant but readily spread by cultivation.

**Morphology**
**S. media** is identified by the **single line of hairs on stems** (changing sides at nodes), **deeply cleft white petals**, and **weak, sprawling habit**. Edible—leaves and stems are eaten raw in salads or cooked as greens. A cool-season weed, thriving when lawns and gardens are dormant. Nearly impossible to eliminate.

**Stewartia ovata**, commonly known as mountain camellia or mountain stewartia, is a **deciduous shrub or small tree** in the **Theaceae** family. Native to the southeastern United States, this species inhabits **rich, moist mountain woods and stream banks** in the Appalachians.

**Growth habit**
A large shrub or small tree, 3–5 meters tall, with upright branches and an open, irregular form. Bark is smooth, gray-brown, sometimes mottled. Slow-growing and long-lived.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **simple**, **elliptic to ovate**, 6–12 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are dark green above, paler and hairy beneath. Fall color is orange to red.

**Flowers**
Flowers are **solitary** in upper leaf axils. Individual flowers are large, 6–10 cm across, **cup-shaped**, with **5 white, crinkled petals** (resembling crepe paper) and a **mass of purple stamens** (orange in some populations). Showy and camellia-like. Blooms summer (June–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **woody, 5-angled capsule**, 1.5–2 cm long, splitting to release seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are winged, wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**S. ovata** is identified by its **large white camellia-like flowers with purple stamens**, **finely serrate leaves**, and **mountain woodland habitat**. Distinguished from **S. malacodendron** by larger flowers and purple (not white) stamens. One of the most beautiful native flowering shrubs. Rare in the wild and slow to establish in gardens but worth the effort.

**Strophostyles helvola**, commonly known as trailing wild bean or amberique bean, is an **annual vine** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **sandy fields, beaches, roadsides, and disturbed areas**, often in dry, sandy soils.

**Growth habit**
A trailing or twining annual vine, 60–180 cm long, with slender, hairy stems. Plants climb on other vegetation or trail along the ground.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **ovate to 3-lobed**, 2–5 cm long, variable in shape (lobed or unlobed on the same plant), with **entire margins**. Leaves are hairy, grayish-green.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **dense, head-like clusters** of 3–15 on long axillary stalks. Individual flowers are **pea-like**, 8–12 mm long, **pink to greenish** (fading yellowish), with a **curved (coiled) keel petal** (distinctive). Blooms summer to fall (July–October).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **linear, cylindrical pod**, 5–10 cm long, curved, hairy, containing several seeds.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, kidney-shaped, hairy; edible when cooked.

**Morphology**
**S. helvola** is identified by its **trifoliate leaves with variable lobing**, **head-like clusters of pink flowers**, and **curved keel petal**. Distinguished from other wild beans by flower color and curved keel. Common in sandy, disturbed habitats. Seeds were eaten by Indigenous peoples. Fixes nitrogen.

**Symphyotrichum pilosum** (syn. **Aster pilosus**), commonly known as frost aster or hairy white oldfield aster, is a **perennial herb** in the **Asteraceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **old fields, roadsides, meadows, and disturbed areas**, often forming extensive populations.

**Growth habit**
An erect, bushy herb, 60–150 cm tall, with much-branched stems arising from a woody crown. Stems are hairy (pilose). Plants become covered with flowers in fall.

**Leaves**
Basal leaves are **oblanceolate to spatulate**, 5–12 cm long, with serrate margins, often withering by flowering time. Stem leaves are **alternate**, **linear to lanceolate**, becoming small and bract-like upward, with **entire margins**, hairy.

**Flowers**
Flower heads are **numerous**, borne on one-sided, arching branches. Heads are small, 1–2 cm across, with **15–35 white ray florets** (occasionally tinged pink or lavender) and **yellow disk florets** that turn **reddish-purple with age**. Blooms late summer to fall (August–October).

**Fruit**
Achenes are small with a pappus of white bristles.

**Seeds**
Achenes are wind-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**S. pilosum** is identified by its **bushy, much-branched habit**, **small white ray heads with yellow-to-purple disks**, and **hairy stems**. One of the most abundant fall asters. The tiny white flowers create a frothy, cloud-like effect. Important late-season pollinator plant.

**Thalictrum dioicum**, commonly known as early meadow rue, is a **perennial herb** in the **Ranunculaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests and wooded slopes**, often in calcareous soils.

**Growth habit**
An erect herb, 30–70 cm tall, with smooth, often purplish stems arising from a fibrous root system. Plants form loose colonies.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **2–3 times ternately compound**, creating a delicate, airy appearance. Leaflets are **round to kidney-shaped**, 1–3 cm across, with **3 rounded lobes** at the apex, resembling columbine foliage. Leaves are thin, pale green to bluish-green.

**Flowers**
Plants are **dioecious** (male and female flowers on separate plants). Flowers are borne in **loose, drooping panicles**. Flowers lack petals; **sepals are small, greenish, falling early**. Male flowers have **numerous dangling yellow stamens** (showy). Female flowers have **purplish pistils**. Blooms early spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit consists of **ribbed achenes**, 4–5 mm long, in drooping clusters.

**Seeds**
Achenes are dispersed near the parent plant.

**Morphology**
**T. dioicum** is identified by its **delicate, ternately compound leaves**, **drooping clusters of petalless flowers**, and **dioecious habit**. Male plants with dangling yellow stamens are showier than females. Distinguished from tall meadow rue (T. pubescens) by earlier bloom and shorter stature. One of the earliest spring woodland flowers.

**Tiarella cordifolia**, commonly known as foamflower or heartleaf foamflower, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Saxifragaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests and shaded slopes**, often forming extensive groundcover colonies.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading herb, 15–30 cm tall when flowering, spreading by slender stolons or rhizomes to form dense mats. Plants are semi-evergreen in mild climates.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **basal**, **long-petioled**, **broadly heart-shaped** (cordate), 5–10 cm across, with **3–5 shallow, pointed lobes** and **serrate margins**. Leaves are bright green, often with **dark reddish veins or central markings**. Leaves are slightly hairy.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **erect, spike-like racemes** 10–20 cm tall above the foliage, giving a "foamy" appearance. Individual flowers are small, 6–8 mm across, with **5 white petals** and **long, protruding stamens**. Blooms spring (April–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **capsule** with 2 unequal valves.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, shiny; dispersed when capsule opens.

**Morphology**
**T. cordifolia** is identified by its **heart-shaped, lobed basal leaves** (often with dark markings), **spikes of white frothy flowers**, and **spreading stoloniferous habit**. A classic woodland groundcover. Many cultivars exist with enhanced leaf markings. Distinguished from **Heuchera** by running habit and flower structure.

**Trifolium arvense**, commonly known as rabbit-foot clover or hares-foot clover, is an **annual herb** in the **Fabaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **dry fields, roadsides, and sandy disturbed areas**.

**Growth habit**
An erect to ascending annual, 10–40 cm tall, with branching stems that are softly hairy throughout. Plants are often grayish-green due to dense pubescence.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **trifoliate** (3 leaflets). Leaflets are **linear to narrowly oblanceolate**, 1–2 cm long, with **entire margins** (not toothed), much narrower than most clovers. Stipules are membranous with bristle-like tips.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **soft, fuzzy, cylindrical heads** 1–2 cm long, resembling a rabbits foot. Individual flowers are tiny, **grayish-pink**, almost hidden by the **long, feathery calyx lobes** that give the head the soft, furry texture. Blooms summer (June–August).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **tiny pod** enclosed in the persistent calyx.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small; dispersed with the fuzzy calyx.

**Morphology**
**T. arvense** is identified by its **soft, fuzzy, elongate flower heads** (like a rabbits foot), **narrow leaflets**, and **grayish appearance**. The tactile, furry heads are distinctive and persist when dried. Common in dry, sandy, disturbed areas. Unlike most clovers, not a valuable forage plant.

**Typha angustifolia**, commonly known as narrow-leaved cattail, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Typhaceae** family. Native to Eurasia and possibly parts of North America (debated), this species inhabits **marshes, pond edges, and wet ditches**, often in slightly brackish conditions.

**Growth habit**
A tall, emergent aquatic, 150–300 cm tall, spreading aggressively by thick, starchy rhizomes to form dense, monocultural stands. Often outcompetes native cattails.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **basal**, **linear**, 100–200 cm long, **3–10 mm wide** (narrower than T. latifolia), erect, flat to slightly convex on the back. Leaves are gray-green.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in the characteristic **cattail spike**: a dense, cylindrical spike of tiny flowers, with **male flowers above** (shedding pollen, then falling) and **female flowers below** (forming the brown "cigar"). In T. angustifolia, there is a **distinct gap** (1–8 cm) between male and female portions—key diagnostic feature. Blooms late spring to summer.

**Fruit**
Female spike becomes a brown, cigar-like mass of tiny fruits with cottony hairs.

**Seeds**
Seeds are minute, attached to cottony hairs; wind- and water-dispersed.

**Morphology**
**T. angustifolia** is identified by its **narrow leaves** (3–10 mm) and **distinct gap between male and female spike portions**. Distinguished from **T. latifolia** (broad-leaved cattail) by narrower leaves and the gap. Hybridizes with T. latifolia to form the aggressive invasive **T. x glauca**. Can dominate wetlands at the expense of native diversity.

**Uvularia grandiflora**, commonly known as large-flowered bellwort or merrybells, is a **rhizomatous perennial herb** in the **Colchicaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **rich, moist deciduous forests and wooded slopes**, a classic spring ephemeral.

**Growth habit**
An erect herb, 30–60 cm tall, with forking stems that appear to pierce through the leaves (perfoliate). Plants arise from a creeping rhizome, forming loose colonies.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **elliptic to ovate**, 5–12 cm long, with **entire margins** and pointed tips. Leaves are distinctive: the stem **appears to pass through the leaf base** (perfoliate). Leaves are bright green above, pale and downy beneath.

**Flowers**
Flowers are **solitary** (occasionally 2), **nodding**, borne at the tips of forked branches. Flowers are **tubular-bell-shaped**, 3–5 cm long, with **6 bright yellow, twisted tepals**. Tepals are narrow, twisting slightly. Blooms spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **3-angled, 3-winged capsule**, 10–15 mm long.

**Seeds**
Seeds have an aril; dispersed by ants (myrmecochory).

**Morphology**
**U. grandiflora** is identified by its **nodding yellow bell-shaped flowers**, **perfoliate leaves** (stem through leaf base), and **leaves downy beneath**. Distinguished from **U. sessilifolia** by larger flowers, perfoliate (not sessile) leaves, and downy leaf undersides. One of the most elegant spring wildflowers.

**Vaccinium angustifolium**, commonly known as lowbush blueberry, is a **low deciduous shrub** in the **Ericaceae** family. Native to northeastern North America, this species inhabits **dry, acidic barrens, rocky slopes, and open woods**, the primary source of commercial "wild" blueberries.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading shrub, 15–60 cm tall, forming extensive colonies via creeping rhizomes. Plants sucker readily after fire or mowing.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **narrowly elliptic**, 2–4 cm long, with **finely serrate margins** and a pointed tip. Leaves are bright green above, paler beneath, smooth (not hairy). Fall color is brilliant red.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **clusters** from lateral buds on previous years wood. Individual flowers are **urn-shaped** (urceolate), 4–6 mm long, **white to pinkish**, constricted at the mouth. Blooms spring (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **round berry**, 5–12 mm across, **blue with a whitish waxy bloom**, sweet, delicious. Ripens mid-summer (July–August).

**Seeds**
Seeds are tiny; dispersed by birds and mammals eating the fruit.

**Morphology**
**V. angustifolium** is identified by its **low stature**, **narrow, finely serrate leaves**, **urn-shaped flowers**, and **blue, bloom-covered berries**. Distinguished from highbush blueberry (V. corymbosum) by shorter stature and narrower leaves. The premier wild blueberry—commercially harvested in Maine and Atlantic Canada. Superior flavor compared to cultivated highbush berries.

**Veronica chamaedrys**, commonly known as germander speedwell or birds-eye speedwell, is a **perennial herb** in the **Plantaginaceae** family. Native to Europe, this species is widely naturalized in North America in **lawns, meadows, roadsides, and woodland edges**.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading perennial, 20–50 cm tall, with creeping stems that root at nodes and ascending flowering shoots. Stems have **2 opposite lines of hairs** (diagnostic).

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **ovate to triangular**, 1.5–3 cm long, with **coarsely serrate margins** and a rounded base. Lower leaves are short-petioled; upper leaves are sessile. Leaves are hairy.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **loose, axillary racemes** of 10–20 flowers. Individual flowers are 10–12 mm across, with **4 petals** (upper petal largest, lower smallest), **bright blue with white centers and dark nectar guides**. Flowers last only one day. Blooms spring to early summer (April–July).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **heart-shaped capsule**, notched at the apex.

**Seeds**
Seeds are small, flat; dispersed when capsule opens.

**Morphology**
**V. chamaedrys** is identified by its **bright blue flowers with white centers**, **2 lines of hairs on stems**, and **heart-shaped fruit**. One of the prettiest lawn weeds. The intense blue flowers are charming but short-lived. Distinguished from other speedwells by stem pubescence and flower size.

**Viburnum acerifolium**, commonly known as mapleleaf viburnum or dockmackie, is a **deciduous shrub** in the **Adoxaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **dry to moist deciduous forests and woodland understories**, often in rocky or acidic soils.

**Growth habit**
A low, spreading shrub, 1–2 meters tall, often forming colonies via root sprouts. Branches are slender, upright to arching. Bark is gray-brown.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **opposite**, **maple-like** (hence "acerifolium"), **3-lobed**, 5–12 cm long and wide, with **coarsely serrate margins**. Lobes are pointed. Leaves are dark green above, paler and **velvety with black-dotted pubescence beneath**. Fall color is striking: **pink to rose-purple to red**.

**Flowers**
Flowers are borne in **flat-topped cymes** 4–8 cm across. All flowers are small, fertile, **creamy white**, 5-lobed. Blooms late spring (May–June).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **round drupe**, 8–10 mm across, changing from red to **bluish-black** at maturity. Fruit persists into winter.

**Seeds**
Drupes are dispersed by birds.

**Morphology**
**V. acerifolium** is identified by its **maple-like 3-lobed leaves**, **black-dotted pubescence beneath**, **flat-topped white flower clusters**, and **exceptional pink-purple fall color**. Distinguished from other viburnums by the maple-shaped leaves. Excellent native shrub for dry shade. Important wildlife food.

**Woodwardia areolata**, commonly known as netted chain fern, is a **deciduous fern** in the **Blechnaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **acidic swamps, bogs, and moist woods**, often in peaty or sandy soils.

**Growth habit**
A colony-forming fern, 30–60 cm tall, spreading by long, slender, creeping rhizomes. Produces two distinct frond types (dimorphic).

**Leaves (Fronds)**
**Sterile fronds** are **pinnate** with **broadly lanceolate pinnae** (leaflets), 5–15 cm long, with **finely serrate margins**. Pinnae have a distinctive **netted (areolate) vein pattern**—veins form a chain-like network along the midrib (diagnostic). **Fertile fronds** are taller, with narrower, contracted pinnae covered beneath with sori.

**Sori**
Sori are **elongate, chain-like**, running parallel to the midrib on the underside of fertile pinnae, covered by a linear indusium. The chain-like sori give the genus name.

**Spores**
Spores are dispersed by wind.

**Morphology**
**W. areolata** is identified by its **dimorphic fronds**, **netted venation** (chain-like pattern along midrib), and **elongate sori on contracted fertile fronds**. Distinguished from **W. virginica** (Virginia chain fern) by non-leathery texture and more deeply cut fertile pinnae. An attractive native fern for wet, acidic gardens.

**Zanthoxylum americanum**, commonly known as prickly ash or toothache tree, is a **deciduous shrub or small tree** in the **Rutaceae** family. Native to eastern North America, this species inhabits **woodland edges, thickets, and stream banks**, often forming colonies.

**Growth habit**
A thicket-forming shrub or small tree, 3–8 meters tall, with multiple stems arising from spreading roots. Bark is gray, smooth, with **corky-based prickles** on branches and sometimes trunk.

**Leaves**
Leaves are **alternate**, **pinnately compound** with **5–11 leaflets**. Leaflets are **ovate to lanceolate**, 3–6 cm long, with **crenate margins** and **aromatic glands** (visible as translucent dots when held to light). Crushed leaves have a strong citrus scent. Petioles often have prickles.

**Flowers**
Plants are **dioecious**. Flowers are borne in **axillary clusters** on the previous years wood before leaves emerge. Flowers are small, **greenish-yellow**, with 4–5 petals. Blooms early spring (April–May).

**Fruit**
Fruit is a **cluster of follicles**, each 4–5 mm across, **reddish-brown** when ripe, splitting to reveal **shiny black seeds**. Aromatic.

**Seeds**
Seeds are dispersed by birds attracted to the showy seeds.

**Morphology**
**Z. americanum** is identified by its **prickly stems**, **aromatic pinnate leaves with translucent glands**, and **citrus-scented foliage**. Chewing the bark numbs the mouth—hence "toothache tree." Related to citrus and Sichuan pepper. The host plant for giant swallowtail butterfly larvae. Important native shrub for wildlife.
